The push for a statewide prescription drug monitoring program failed again. Why is Missouri the last holdout?
body text:
ST. LOUIS — Missouri retained its lonely title as the only state without a statewide prescription drug monitoring program — for the seventh year in a row — after the legislative session ended Friday.Patient advocates, politicians, experts and members of the medical community had hoped this would finally be the year Missouri would create a statewide electronic database designed to help spot the abuse of prescription drugs. After all, Republican Gov. Mike Parson had pushed for it and, more important, its longtime opponent was no longer in office to block it.But, because of ongoing fears about privacy violations tangled up with gun control, the bill never got a full Senate vote. And finance site WalletHub last week ranked Missouri third worst in the country for its drug use based on a review of arrests, overdose rates, opioid prescriptions and other measures.

Katie Reichard, a lobbyist with Missouri Primary Care Association who has been working in and around the Missouri Legislature for almost 15 years and previously pushed for the issue, said this proposal has bedeviled the state capital as none other while the opioid crisis continues to rage nationwide.“I’ve never seen anything take seven years to get anywhere, and especially something that’s going to be put into place to save lives.”Missouri’s cities, neighboring states and the federal government have been forced to create a patchwork of incomplete workarounds. Those include a voluntary program tracking patients’ prescriptions run by St. Louis County that receives federal funding and a statewide monitoring system put into place by former Republican Gov. Eric Greitens that tracks physicians’ prescriptions.And yet, the state cannot seem to legislate a complete fix. “It’s frustrating to watch the rest of the country get this done and watch Missouri be the last one,” said Dr. Sam Page, the St. Louis County prescription drug monitoring program architect and current St. Louis County Executive.To be sure, the databases don’t eliminate the ability of drug abusers to acquire prescription opioids. But the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has called such statewide patient monitoring databases “among the most promising state-level interventions” to improve opioid prescribing and protect at-risk patients.It’s an embarrassment Missouri can’t figure out its own statewide system, said St. Joseph pharmacist JulieMarie Nickelson. “No one in the pharmacy or medical world really understands it,” she said.Privacy, guns and oppositionWhile a drug-monitoring bill has been introduced every year in the Legislature since 2005, it was initially championed by the minority Democratic Party, which meant it didn’t have much of a shot at passing until 2012.Then New Hampshire approved a statewide program in 2012, leaving Missouri as the sole holdout. That pressure, combined with an uptick in awareness of drug abuse, led to a swell of bipartisan agreement.A statewide drug monitoring bill passed the Missouri House handily that year, then met its biggest adversary: Republican state Sen. Robert Schaaf, whose district stretched from Kansas City to St. Joseph along Missouri’s western border.Since then, Schaaf — who is also a family physician — filibustered or insisted on kill clauses that would never pass the House, citing his concerns over privacy and personal liberty issues along with his belief it was an ineffective tool. Year after year, his efforts defeated drug monitoring bills.Schaaf has said the risk of a database of patient information being hacked — and the government having access to the information — far outweighed the potential benefits. He also tapped into underlying fears of privacy violations, driven in part by a 2013 scandal over the Missouri Highway Patrol turning over a database of concealed weapons permit holders to a federal agent.“I’ve always been opposed to taking private citizens’ information and putting it on a government database to which many, many people have access,” he told Kaiser Health News. “My understanding is there is no computer information to which the NSA is not privy. How long is it going to be ’til this is used to pare down the number of people with concealed weapons or weapons at all?”By stoking privacy fears and connecting them to gun rights, Schaaf also helped tap into grassroots far-right opposition that lives on to this day. A YouTube video tweeted by opponents of prescription drug monitoring programs details how the St. Louis County system could be used in “passing your personal information on to the federal government, which could use it to infringe on your right to bear arms.”To date, the only reported hack has been of Virginia’s database, though it is unclear if the hackers were able to access medical records.Over the years, Missouri’s drug monitoring advocates, led by Republican Rep. Holly Rehder, unsuccessfully tried to assuage such concerns by offering amendments to delete records older than three years and to ensure medical information could not be tied to buying a gun. And while Schaaf did an about-face in 2017 and agreed to stop filibustering the proposal, he effectively killed it with his only stipulation: that all physicians be required to use it. That measure, which took away the inherent voluntary aspect of the program, failed in the House.“If they’re going to take our liberty away for something that’s never been proven to work, doctors have to use it,” Schaaf told Kaiser Health News.
The former head of the St. Louis County Health Department, Faisal Khan, who in 2017 helped start the voluntary county-based prescription drug monitoring program that now covers other portions of the state, claims the opposition goes deeper than what he called “totally unfounded” privacy concerns.“They view St. Louis County and St. Louis city and St. Louis, in general, as this liberal Democratic bastion that they don’t want anything to do with,” he said. “It’s the usual nonsense that we’re seeing around the country at the moment, and it’s stymying progress in the parts of the state where we need it the most.”But this year, Schaaf had hit his term limit of eight years in office and did not return to the Missouri Senate. Passing a prescription drug monitor program finally seemed within reach — until a group of six Republican state senators formed a new conservative caucus and filibustered yet again over the issue, citing the same privacy issues and civil liberties.“The conservative caucus has carried his torch on,” Reichard said.A series of workarounds Now, because the legislature has refused to move on the issue, cities, states and the federal government must continue to rely on the stopgaps they created to help address the opioid problem ravaging Missouri.Today, 72 jurisdictions have opted into St. Louis County’s voluntary prescription drug monitoring system so pharmacists and doctors could check a patient’s other prescriptions. It now covers 84% of the state’s population.
Even St. Joseph, one of the areas hardest hit by the opioid epidemic and where Schaaf lives, joined last year.For Nickelson, a pharmacist at Rogers Pharmacy in the city of about 76,000 people, the voluntary database means she no longer has to spend upward of 30 minutes on the phone tracking down whether a patient had prescriptions for drugs elsewhere.“It’s really helpful to us as it makes it so we can make sure that patients aren’t taking medications that interact and can increase risk for an overdose,” she said. “We just want to make sure our patients are safe, and we want to make sure medication that’s not necessary doesn’t get into the community.”Since her city’s voluntary PDMP has been in effect, she estimates she sees a handful fewer people each week who were doctor-shopping, a particular risk considering the pharmacy is less than 5 miles from the Kansas border.Missouri was a premier destination for pill-shopping, Page said, but that’s changed.“Our PDMP is first-class, as any in the country,” Page said. “We have gaps, but those will continue to fill in. If the state continues to not move forward with this, then St. Louis County will continue to do the right thing.”And while St. Louis County built its voluntary database in part with $200,000 from the U.S. Department of Justice, interstate sharing of the data with neighboring Illinois, Kansas and Oklahoma didn’t happen until February. Eight states border Missouri and more states are expected to collaborate with St. Louis County’s system this year. But data-sharing can occur only among states that have managed to bend or rewrite their regulations to accommodate the one state in the nation without a statewide program.Tennessee even created and passed legislation to allow it to communicate with the St. Louis County program while Missouri was still haggling over its PDMP bill, according to Spring Schmidt, acting head of the St. Louis County Department of Public Health.The system that Greitens created when governor, along with Express Scripts, to monitor physicians’ prescriptions for unusual patterns led to 50 referrals to the Missouri Healing Arts Board — the disciplinary board for medical practitioners in Missouri — for prescribing issues since March 2018, according to Missouri’s head of Health and Senior Services, Dr. Randall Williams.Ideally, Williams said, he would love to combine a statewide version of the voluntary PDMP system with Greitens’ physician-monitoring one, but he’s waiting on the legislation.Reichard can’t help but wonder why the state won’t join the rest of the nation in passing it.“I’m not saying do what everyone else is doing,” she said. “But if 49 other legislatures are saying ‘This is important, we need to save lives,’ I don’t understand why Missouri can’t find a way to compromise and do what’s best for its citizens.”Kaiser Health News is a nonprofit news service covering health issues. It is an editorially independent program of the Kaiser Family Foundation that is not affiliated with Kaiser Permanente.

Editorial: Short takes on 'talking telegraphs' and deep-sea trash
body text:
Parson invokes invention of ‘talking telegraph’Missouri Gov. Mike Parson is expected to be the top ambassador touting this state’s hi-tech prowess and modern infrastructure capable of attracting new employers and investors. His six-minute interview on National Public Radio Wednesday accomplished exactly the opposite — not so much for anything he said but for the abysmal quality of the phone equipment he was using.The interview was almost intelligible at the start, but the longer it lasted, the more it sounded as if Parson were speaking through a long irrigation tube on his farm while crushing graham crackers into the mouthpiece. The connection quality degraded to the point where almost nothing was understandable.

We live in cost-conscious times, for sure. But it seems the governor’s office could spring for a few extra dollars to upgrade his phone so he doesn’t embarrass the state and invoke the olden days when Missourians communicated using a new device called the “talking telegraph.”Tree muggersA California couple wanted a massive, protected 180-year oak tree on their property to be in different spot. So they had it dug up and transplanted, killing it in the process. Fittingly, a judge has now fined them almost $600,000 for their little landscape project.For close to two centuries, the majestic tree stood in a wooded area north of San Francisco, on land now owned by Toni and Peter Thompson. Although there’s a conservation easement requiring the land to stay in its natural state, the couple wanted the tree, and two others, moved to another location. So they ignored the easement and brought in the backhoes, to disastrous outcome.In a searing ruling, Judge Patrick M. Broderick sided with the land trust and fined the couple $586,000 to fund restoration efforts. He cited their efforts to hide what they did and obstruct the investigation.The couple’s lawyer protested that they are “responsible, law-abiding citizens” who love the land. Funny way of showing it.Trump 2.0It appears college student John Lambert, a co-founder of the national campus group Students for Trump, is perfectly suited for promoting the ethos of our 45th president: Lambert has been charged with posing online as a high-powered lawyer to fleece unwitting “clients.”During and after the 2016 election, Lambert became a celebrity for young fans of President Donald Trump. He traveled to various college campuses, touting Trump’s policies and pushing back on the narrative that students tend to oppose him.But federal prosecutors allege that Lambert, operating out of North Carolina, invented an online persona named Eric Pope, described as a prominent New York attorney, and used it to bilk unwary people seeking legal services out of tens of thousands of dollars.In Trump’s younger days, he used to talk himself up to reporters while pretending to be a non-existent spokesman named John Barron. He also was sued for ripping off students of the now-defunct Trump University. If Lambert beats the rap, maybe there’s a cabinet post for him.Deep-sea dumpsterThe deepest ocean dive ever undertaken has yielded some intriguing sights, and a depressing one: human trash, in the furthest depths that human eyes have ever glimpsed.
Explorer Victor Vescovo recently unveiled details of his history-making dive in the southern Pacific Ocean, part of a mission to chart the deepest parts of the globe. Inside a submersible called The Limiting Factor, Vescovo descended seven miles, to the bottom of the Pacific’s Marianna Trench. It is the deepest manned sea dive on record.In those never-before-seen depths, Vescovo came across what are believed to be several previously unknown species of fish.He also came across a plastic bag and some candy wrappers.An estimated 100 million tons of trash are in the world’s oceans, with some 8 million more added every year.
Crime shouldn’t payFormer St. Louis County Executive Steve Stenger had been on track to eventually get a county pension despite pleading guilty to corruption in office. But as the Post-Dispatch’s Jeremy Kohler reports, County Council member Tim Fitch wants the council to create a law like the one that already governs Missouri state employees: If they’re convicted of a felony committed in relation to their official duties, they forfeit their pensions.Stenger will be sentenced Aug. 9 and could face three to four years in prison. Yet under current statute, that combined with his resignation in disgrace from office wouldn’t prevent him from collecting his county pension as early as 2032.As Fitch puts it: “If he was committing crimes while he was in his elected position, why would taxpayers want to pay his pension for the rest of his life?” Good question.The next small stepHalf a century after Neil Armstrong first walked on the moon, NASA is planning to release some long-sealed samples of moon rocks to scientists to be tested with technology that wasn’t available when they were first brought to Earth.Much of the more than 800 pounds of rocks and soil collected during the six Apollo moon missions from 1969 through 1972 remain vacuum sealed or frozen, untouched by human hands on Earth.Testing on some samples offered clues about the origins of both the moon and Earth. Other material was preserved on the assumption that future scientists with advanced technology could make deeper discoveries.Scientists will test samples for trapped water molecules and other secrets — an apt way to mark the July 20 anniversary of Armstrong’s first walk 50 years ago.Of course, they aren’t unsealing all of it. Who knows what scientists 50 years from now might be able to learn?EDITOR'S NOTE: The final item in Short Takes has been updated to correct the date of the first moon walk.

Missouri moves to join GOP anti-abortion wave
body text:
Missouri's Republican-led Senate has passed a wide-ranging bill to ban abortions at eight weeks of pregnancy, acting only hours after Alabama's governor signed a near-total abortion ban into law.The Missouri bill needs another vote of approval in the GOP-led House before it can go to Republican Gov. Mike Parson, who voiced support for an earlier version Wednesday.

It includes exceptions for medical emergencies, but not for pregnancies caused by rape or incest. Doctors would face five to 15 years in prison for violating the eight-week cutoff. Women who receive abortions wouldn't be prosecuted.Republican Senate handler Sen. Andrew Koenig described it on Thursday as "one of the strongest" abortion bills yet passed in the U.S.Missouri joins a movement of GOP-dominated state legislatures emboldened by the possibility that a more conservative Supreme Court could overturn its landmark ruling legalizing the procedure. Its senators voted only hours after Alabama's governor signed the most stringent abortion ban in the nation on Wednesday, making performing an abortion a felony in nearly all cases.
Outnumbered Missouri Senate Democrats launched into an attack on the bill before Republican supporters had a chance to bring it up for debate on the Senate floor."So much of this bill is just shaming women into some kind of complacency that says we are vessels of pregnancy rather than understanding that women's lives all hold different stories," St. Louis-area Democratic Sen. Jill Schupp said.
Missouri is among a growing number of states where abortion opponents are working with renewed enthusiasm following President Donald Trump's appointment of more conservative high court justices. Kentucky, Mississippi, Ohio and Georgia have approved bans on abortion once fetal cardiac activity can be detected, which can occur in about the sixth week of pregnancy. Similar restrictions in North Dakota and Iowa have been struck down in court.Supporters say the Alabama bill is intentionally designed to conflict with the 1973 Roe v. Wade decision that legalized abortion nationally in hopes of sparking a court case that might prompt the justices to revisit abortion rights.Missouri's bill also includes an outright ban on abortions except in cases of medical emergencies. But unlike Alabama's, it would kick in only if Roe v. Wade is overturned.

Missouri is on the verge of making hearing aids more accessible to poor people
body text:
JEFFERSON CITY — Missouri lawmakers on Tuesday gave final approval to a proposal that would help people who are deaf or hard of hearing access hearing aids.The bill, sponsored by Rep. Ann Kelley, R-Lamar, creates a hearing aid distribution program that will provide financial assistance for the purpose of buying hearing aids to deaf or hard of hearing people earning less than the federal poverty level.To make less than the federal poverty this year, an individual must earn less than $12,490 per year; a family of four must earn less than $25,750 per year, according to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.

Audiologists will need to perform assessments on patients before they are eligible for the state aide.Legislative budget writers devoted $100,000 to the Statewide Hearing Aid Distribution Fund for next fiscal year, which begins July 1.
The Missouri Commission for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing may accept donations for the fund, and may write regulations for doling out the money.
A nonpartisan fiscal analysis of the plan estimates that 10 percent of Missouri's population is deaf or hard of hearing. The analysis says that people with disabilities are more likely than others to live in poverty.The bill now goes to Gov. Mike Parson, a Republican, for consideration.The legislation is Senate Bill 101.

article headline: Editorial: In-state tuition for Dreamers just makes good business sense
body text:
Missouri state legislators couldn’t seem to make up their minds about the educational fate of the young immigrants known as Dreamers. These are the youths brought here illegally by their parents and who, in most cases, know no other country than the United States. Some legislators seem to want to punish them for being undocumented — a status that none of them chose.Missouri is one of just six states that ban in-state benefits to Dreamers, youths who arrived here before 2007 and who qualified for deportation protection under the federal Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program. House and Senate conferees took the bold step last Wednesday of removing language from House Bill 3, an appropriations measure for higher education, that would have continued denying them in-state tuition.Wednesday’s move seemed a major sign of progress. But on Thursday, conferees re-inserted the in-state tuition ban.

With all the attention President Donald Trump has focused on illegal immigration, this issue has unfairly become immersed in his anti-immigrant crusade. A lot of people, apparently including some state legislators, think this is about Democrats vs. Republicans or Trump policies vs. those of former President Barack Obama. They couldn’t be more wrong.Republicans in staunchly red states like Texas have come to understand that there’s nothing to be gained by holding one class of young people down while advancing others toward educational success. When Dreamers are denied in-state tuition, many if not most give up on the idea of higher education because it’s too expensive. A future full of menial jobs awaits.
Forcing them into this status runs directly contrary to Gov. Mike Parson’s priority of building Missouri’s workforce preparation to make Missouri more attractive for employers and business investors. He should demand they rethink this provision.
General Motors, which is contemplating a major investment in Wentzville, says the corporation “stands with the Dreamers we employ and the hundreds of thousands of Dreamers employed by multiple companies across the U.S.”In Texas back in 2001, long before Obama was president, then-Gov. Rick Perry led his fellow Republican lawmakers in approving in-state tuition for undocumented students. Perry is no liberal. As governor, he recognized that a well-educated workforce would make the Texas economy hum like a race car, as it does today. It made no sense to deny in-state tuition to that state’s large population of undocumented youths and put Texas at a competitive disadvantage.The Texas Association of Business remains firmly behind in-state tuition. In Arkansas, Republican Gov. Asa Hutchinson also backed such a provision for Dreamers. Oklahoma has done likewise. These Republican initiatives are every bit in line with their conservative, pro-business beliefs.Missouri is the outlier. Why? Because politicians are blinded by Trump’s anti-immigrant tirade and refuse to see well-educated Dreamers for what they are — a workforce asset to boost Missouri’s competitiveness.

article headline: Give Dreamers a chance with in-state tuition in Missouri
body text:
I’m not from Missouri; the citizens of your state should make the laws that are best for you. But I know a few graduates of Missouri high schools who lost a big opportunity last week when the Legislature first adopted and then, a couple of days later, took back in-state tuition for those with Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) status.I think Missouri — as well as the Dreamers — would be better off if you gave them the chance to go to college — not by giving them state money, not scholarships, but in-state tuition. The measure hasn’t been signed by Gov. Mike Parson. I hope he’ll persuade the Legislature to change it.Many U.S. citizens are uneasy about current levels of immigration. They don’t want to offer anything to recent border crossers; they don’t like it when immigrants arrive in the country illegally and then commit crimes; and they don’t approve when immigrants arrive here illegally and then ask for federal benefits.

None of these is the case with DACA recipients. They arrived in the country before June of 2007. They’ve never been convicted of a serious crime; if they are convicted, they lose DACA status. And DACA does not give them access to Pell or federal college grants or to loans of any kind.I help run a national college scholarship program for DACA recipients; 3,700 are in college nationally (including 17 Missouri high school graduates attending college in other states). Our average scholarship recipient came here at the age of 4 with his or her parents. I am very strongly pro-law enforcement. Many years ago, I was a patrolman with the Washington, D.C., police department. I arrested felons and sent them to jail; I didn’t arrest any 4-year-olds.When that 4-year-old grows up, there is no way he or she can become a citizen or green card holder — no line they can stand in, no test they can take, no fee they can pay. No, they can’t join the U.S. military.Why should Missouri’s Legislature give the DACA students in-state tuition?1. It costs you nothing. Neither DACA nor the grant of in-state tuition gives the Dreamer students any federal or state money.2. It appears that your colleges could use the revenue. Missouri’s state colleges are down by 22,000 students since 2013. The Dreamers can attend without depriving any Missouri citizen student of his or her place in the state’s colleges (if any college is full-up in enrollment, give the Dreamers access to all the rest).
3. Some legislators appear to feel that because they are the children of undocumented immigrants, the DACA students shouldn’t have all the benefits of citizens — that they should have a higher hill to climb.Believe me, they do.Almost all their low-income high school classmates receive federal Pell grants (up to $6,195 per year for many years); all, regardless of income, are eligible for federal loans. For the Dreamers: no grants and no loans. In addition, there are state scholarship programs (the Missouri Department of Higher Education website lists nine different ones); the Dreamers aren’t eligible for any. Unlike their low-income classmates, the Dreamers will be paying in-state tuition without help from any of those U.S. or Missouri programs. That’s quite a hill to climb.
Despite these obstacles, the motivation of the Dreamer students is remarkable. Our 17 Missouri students are part of a group that also includes students from Georgia, North Carolina and other states that deny the Dreamers in-state tuition. We started paying for them to attend good low-cost colleges in Tennessee, Connecticut, Delaware and elsewhere three years ago. In the last three years, 415 students enrolled. Five have dropped out — a 98 percent retention rate.One state just came off the list of those denying in-state tuition: Arkansas’ Republican Legislature passed, and Gov. Asa Hutchinson has signed this year, a bill to give Arkansas Dreamers in-state tuition.After decades of running scholarship programs for U.S. citizens in my home town, I joined two friends setting up a program to give modest aid ($8,250 per year maximum) for Dreamers to attend the lowest-cost good colleges in their home states. Why? Because I met some Dreamers. I never met students who want to go to college so desperately, and I never met any who face more obstacles.I know a lot of Missourians. Almost all are kind; certainly none is cruel, and I am sure no legislator wants to be. But when Missouri high school students want so badly to go to college, when your colleges could use the added enrollment, when your employers need more educated people, why not give these students a chance? Just open the door. The Dreamers will do the work.Donald E. Graham is co-founder of Thedream.us and a former publisher of The Washington Post.

Chulick: GM and Gov. Parson want to keep Wentzville plant open. Why play politics?
body text:
In a time of automotive plant closures in Ohio and Michigan, General Motors is actually looking to invest $1 billion in its Wentzville plant, which according to Gov. Mike Parson would be the largest private sector investment in our state — ever. The investment would include expansion of the plant, upgrades to technology and an assurance that GM is here to stay for decades to come.We can imagine the great sigh of relief and excitement from GM’s 3,500 local employees and their families, the city of Wentzville and their schools — not to mention the owners and employees of the 200 supply-chain businesses and nearly 9,000 jobs across Missouri the GM plant currently supports. But as of Thursday, the deal was close to falling through — all because some of our local Missouri legislators would rather filibuster and play politics instead of supporting their own governor’s efforts to keep and grow good-paying jobs in Missouri.Here is the story: Earlier this month, General Motors announced it is considering investing nearly $1 billion in its current Wentzville facility. GM has undergone transformative changes over the past year, shuttering five plants in North America, including in two of our Midwest neighbors, Ohio and Michigan. The closing of these plants hit some 14,000 workers, and yet, Missouri has the opportunity to compete for the expansion of our state’s GM plant in Wentzville that produces GM’s most popular truck lines, the Chevrolet Colorado and GMC Canyon.

The governor recently announced a comprehensive plan to “sharpen Missouri’s economic development tools and grow Missouri’s automotive industry.” The plan includes Parson’s key economic and workforce development initiatives: Fast Track, that would give financial grants to adults over the age of 25 to obtain education and training needed to fill high-demand jobs; One Start, which would provide more workforce training opportunities for new and expanding businesses; and The Deal Closing Fund that would allow the Missouri Department of Economic Development more flexibility when incentivizing businesses to locate to Missouri.Finally, the deal includes an incentive package for automakers like GM. According to Parson’s press release, the incentive package would “help retain automotive jobs by granting $5 million in tax credits annually to automotive manufacturers that invest $500 million or more in plant upgrades and agree to retain current workers.” The plan would also extend an additional five years if an automaker like GM makes an additional $250 million investment in the state.
For what seems like a no-brainer, some in the Missouri Legislature are not convinced the incentive package is what is best for all Missourians. Citing corporate welfare, those who would oppose such a plan clearly do not realize that GM has already invested $2.36 billion in Missouri since 2010 and impacts about 1 million Missouri workers including plant employees, suppliers, transportation service providers, and manufacturers and is now considering investing another $1 billion in the state. Missouri is actually a clear winner in this deal.
Gov. Parson and General Motors have made it clear that they think these economic and workforce development programs and the incentive package will be a benefit to every Missourian and every Missouri business. Giving our citizens the ability to climb into high-demand jobs, providing businesses with more resources to train their employees for the future, and attracting GM and other important corporations that provide thousands of jobs and billions to our state is absolutely essential for our state’s growth.In Wentzville and across Missouri, there are thousands of families who depend on their GM jobs to feed their families, pay their employees, keep their restaurants open and support local schools. We know the devastating impacts these plant closures can have on local communities with issues like unemployment and increased drug addiction. Corporate welfare is a problem in the U.S. It can be abused. But this isn’t the case here — this is a vision to grow between two longtime partners, Missouri and GM. Let’s not create another Chrysler closure. The right call was to put these families and communities first and keep GM open in Missouri.Tom Chulick is president and chief executive officer of the St. Louis Regional Chamber.

article headline: 'Debtors prison' legislation heading to Gov. Mike Parson's desk
body text:
JEFFERSON CITY — A proposal to do away with so-called debtors prisons in Missouri is headed to Gov. Mike Parson after the House gave final approval to the measure  Monday.The bill, sponsored by Rep. Bruce DeGroot, R-Chesterfield, was spurred by a series of columns by Post-Dispatch columnist Tony Messenger, who wrote about people across the state who had been locked up multiple times in county jails for minor violations.Counties have charged prisoners what are known as "board bills" for their stays in jail, which can total thousands of dollars. If the person does not pay off the board bill, they can be required to attend what are known as monthly "show-cause" hearings or risk additional jail time.

The legislation approved Monday allows counties to use civil means to collect jail debt, but counties would no longer be authorized to hang the threat of additional jail time over defendants for failure to pay. The measure would do away with the “show-cause” hearings.House members sent the bill to Parson's desk on a 138-11 vote.In one case Messenger wrote about, George Richey, of Appleton City, Mo., was charged a $3,150 “board bill” in 2015 after his 90-day stay in the St. Clair County jail.He was convicted of a misdemeanor for violating a protective order. When he did not pay the board bill, Richey was re-arrested, and he received an additional $2,275 bill after serving more time in jail.
Richey challenged the second bill. The Missouri Supreme Court in March sided with Richey, pouring cold water on counties' revenue collection system.The court said Richey was responsible for his original jail bill, but the court waived the additional $2,275 charged to Richey after his second stay in jail.Messenger wrote last week that the system was still in effect in some localities, despite the Supreme Court's ruling.
Messenger last month won a Pulitzer Prize for his series of columns."We are correcting a problem that a lot of people faced in Missouri," said Rep. Mark Ellebracht, D-Liberty, during debate on Monday on the House floor.The legislation is House Bill 192.

article headline: Abortion, GM subsidies, redistricting: Missouri lawmakers save hot topics for final week
Editorial: Legislators head home this week, leaving LGBT discrimination legal in Missouri.
body text:
The Missouri Legislature will adjourn Friday, leaving behind the same serious piece of unfinished business that it has neglected every session since 1998. For the 21st straight year, a common-sense proposal to protect people from discrimination based on sexual orientation didn’t get across the finish line. In fact — as usual — it didn’t even get a floor vote.State law already prohibits discrimination in housing, employment and public accommodations based on list of factors including race, gender, ancestry, disability and age. The time has long since passed when mainstream America would accept things like whites-only restaurants or male-only job openings. But discrimination based on who people love still isn’t prohibited under Missouri law.The annual attempt to change that failed despite promising signs of reception from some leading Republicans, including Gov. Mike Parson. Supporters should begin working — now — to make an anti-discrimination measure a front-and-center issue next year. Get it done.

It’s a sign of progress that current Missouri laws prohibiting racial and other discrimination are hardly controversial anymore. There’s general acceptance today of the premise that skin color, gender, religion and other traits or beliefs shouldn’t be allowed as impediments to employment, housing or, say, being served in a restaurant.Yet sexual orientation, which doesn’t affect anything but the most personal aspects of a person’s life, can still close doors — to apartments, to jobs, to tables. To the right to be treated like any other citizen.
The Missouri Non-Discrimination Act would have changed that, with two bills adding sexual orientation and gender identification to the existing bans on discrimination by landlords, employers and businesses. Sexual orientation shouldn’t be any more controversial than those other protections.
Yet, as reported last week by the Post-Dispatch’s Lexi Churchill, the Missouri House leadership didn’t even give the measure a committee assignment until late April, just a month before Friday’s scheduled adjournment, indicating a clear lack of interest in actually ushering it to a floor vote.It did get a recent legislative hearing, providing a telling look at opponents of such measures. They include members of Westboro Baptist Church, the notorious Kansas-based bigots who disrupt military funerals with “God Hates Fags” signs to protest what they see as insufficient hatred in government policy toward homosexuality. Legislators apparently see insufficient reason to put such twisted protesters in their place.Then there was conservative activist Ron Calzone, who warned legislators that the measure violates the “God-given right to discriminate.” When these are the voices fighting for discrimination, a bill to do the exactly opposite almost argues for itself.Proponents can’t keep letting themselves get pushed to the bottom of the legislative agenda. They need to start lining up support and rallying their forces before the next regular legislative session opens in January. Get this important work done next year.

article headline: Editorial: Revival of Missouri's low income housing tax credits is urgent, but so is reform.
body text:
Missouri legislators are moving toward restarting the state’s low-income housing tax credit program, which was justifiably halted under former Gov. Eric Greitens because it was inefficient and wasteful. The tax credit is, in concept, crucial to alleviating the state’s housing crunch for low-income residents.With more than 100,000 Missourians on waiting lists for public housing, pending legislation to restart it is not only justified, but urgent. But just as urgent is that the new version contains safeguards to ensure efficiency and accountability that the old program didn’t have.Missouri used to match the federal low-income tax-credit program dollar for dollar, providing an incentive for developers to build housing for low-income residents. It cost the state around $150 million annually but provided important leverage for the creation of affordable housing.

Unfortunately, developers and others took advantage of the program. A 2014 audit found as little as 42 cents of every tax-credit dollar went toward the construction of housing, with inefficiency and assorted middlemen siphoning off much of the rest.Here as around the country, developers enjoying those credits have used cheap building materials, sited low-income housing in already-struggling areas to save on land costs and taken other shortcuts that help perpetuate slum conditions of so much low-income housing.
Still, when Greitens and his allies on the Missouri Housing Development Commission halted the state tax-credit program in late 2017, they left the job only half finished. As we’ve said before, the solution to an important program that is being abused is to end the abuse, not to end the program.
There are promising indications the Legislature, Gov. Mike Parson and others understand that restarting the program, while crucial, has to be done with reforms built in. As state Treasurer Scott Fitzpatrick told a committee last month, a central goal must be to “make it so that we’re getting more than about half the money we’re issuing out the door in credits back in housing.”Among reform ideas is to give the housing development commission broader power to regulate the program. One version of the legislation would create a new scoring method to evaluate projects on a case-by-case basis. It would also allow developers to transfer credits between projects in certain circumstances, which could increase efficiency.The latest version would issue state tax credits at just 72.5 percent of the federal level, instead of the dollar-for-dollar match of the previous program. That would be a move in the wrong direction. There’s still time to restore 100 percent of that funding, and low-income housing advocates should be pressing for that.But the most immediate issue is to reform the program, no matter what level it’s funded at. The need is as pressing as ever, which only makes the necessity of doing it right this time more important than ever.

article headline: Powerful are intentionally denying Medicaid coverage
body text:
Regarding “Revelations cast doubt on Missouri’s claim that ‘improved economy’ shrunk Medicaid rolls” (April 26):Medicaid in Missouri has always been notoriously hard to access due to the program’s severely low eligibility limit, but now, even people who already qualify are losing the coverage they deserve. Since 2018, thousands have lost their Medicaid coverage, and Gov. Mike Parson’s administration is doing nothing about it.

This is suspiciously convenient for legislators who believe the program should be smaller, but potentially fatal for a growing number of Missourians who rely on it for care. While Parson and others in his administration have touted the sharp decline in Medicaid enrollees as proof of an upturn in the economy, it is beginning to look like coverage is being intentionally denied due to the unwillingness of people in power to address the real issues.
For example, if someone has reported their income to the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (food stamps), it is required that states use that data to determine who is eligible for Medicaid. The Department of Human Services is ignoring that — in violation of federal law. I personally have spent hours in a social services office asserting my own food stamp eligibility, and I know how burdensome the enrollment process is, even without these additional unnecessary hurdles.
Carly Langlois • St.Louis

Editorial: Missouri's new marijuana industry is already seeding state politics with cash.
body text:
Missouri’s nascent medical marijuana industry is getting right down to business, and we don’t mean growing plants. Industry players have already donated more than $15,000 to a political action committee controlled by Gov. Mike Parson, whose administration will decide who gets growing licenses and what regulations they’ll face.There’s no law against giving money to politicians as they’re making decisions that directly affect the donor’s business — but, as the Steve Stenger saga in St. Louis County has so freshly reminded us, there should be. The Parson donations also drive home how problematic it is that the state is trying to hide the identities of marijuana license applicants.Missourians in November voted to legalize medical marijuana. With sales expected to top $100 million by 2025, competition is fierce to get licensed by the state for a piece of that action.

It was within that context that the owner of the newly formed medical marijuana company Artemis Therapeutics, and a Perryville greenhouse that Artemis plans to work with, gave $15,000 Parson’s Uniting Missouri PAC. As the Post-Dispatch’s Kurt Erickson reported this week, it came in the form of three $5,000 donations, all on March 4.There’s no proof the donors or Parson have done anything wrong. Of course, the same could have been said, for years, of Stenger, the former St. Louis County executive whose donors were continually getting official favors while giving him money. It took federal investigators to prove those circumstances weren’t just suspicious, but criminal.
Even absent a crime, the act of giving money to politicians who can influence who gets those marijuana licenses and what regulations will apply to them creates an appearance of such impropriety that it diminishes public trust in government.
One solution would be a ban on any political donations from people seeking or receiving marijuana licensing. Or, Parson and other officials could simply declare publicly that they won’t accept such donations. After all, Parson pledged in November that he would uphold the “highest ethical standards.”Instead, they’re just making those donations difficult to identify. The Post-Dispatch is suing the state to force release of the identities of marijuana license applicants, because the state has taken the bizarre stance that protecting those applicants’ proprietary information means even their identities can be hidden from the public.The fact that Parson’s PAC is taking money from prospective marijuana licensees wouldn’t have come to light at all if not for Erickson’s investigative reporting, which began with a tip. Who knows how many other potential licensees are loading up Missouri’s leaders with cash, hoping to steer state policy to their benefit instead of the public’s?By accepting such conflicted donations — and then trying to prevent the public from even knowing about them — Parson’s administration is casting a shadow of suspicion over this already-controversial new industry. There’s still time to set a better course.

Parson surveys St. Louis area flooding, as waters recede but another crest looms
body text:
O’FALLON, Mo. — Gov. Mike Parson was in — and above — the St. Louis area Wednesday, surveying flood damage along the region’s swollen rivers from a U.S. Army helicopter.“We’re here to try to assist you,” said Parson, addressing local officials and members of the media at the St. Charles County Emergency Operations Center in O’Fallon, Mo., following his flight.His aerial survey of the area left from St. Louis Lambert International Airport and initially went south toward River Des Peres before circling north to St. Charles County, where floodplains near the confluence of the Mississippi and Missouri rivers are inundated, and where some levees have succumbed to high water in recent days.

Parson said quantifying estimates of flood-related property damage or evacuations was “an ongoing issue” for state and local agencies.Major flooding has been a persistent problem across Missouri in recent years, including this spring. When asked whether river basins need to be returned to a more “natural” state of management compared to their current confinement by widespread levee systems — which various experts blame for pushing floodwater higher — Parson said the state is open to wide-scale discussions about flooding, but did not elaborate on what ensuing changes or actions may include.“We want a seat at the table about how these rivers are changing,” he said.During his stop in St. Charles County, Parson was briefed on the local flood outlook and response by members of the National Weather Service, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and other agencies.
NWS experts said that the area may benefit from relatively dry conditions over the next week — providing a merciful break as river basins mount a “secondary crest” from the latest surge of rainfall to hit St. Louis and regions upstream.
Kevin Deitsch, a warning coordination meteorologist for the NWS’ St. Louis forecast office, warned that weather conditions over the next month — and perhaps beyond — are “critical,” since precipitation at this stage of the year “tends to be heavy rain.” Such a burst could push rivers back toward dangerous heights.“I don’t want us to let our guard down,” he said.Photos from spring flooding in the region

Mississippi River flooding in Elsah












Alley Ringhausen examines the wall he and other volunteers built around the Riverview House in Elsah, Ill. as floodwater from the Mississippi River seeps through a makeshift barrier on Monday, May 6, 2019. article headline: Missouri lawmakers consider protections for LGBT people for the 21st year
Editorial: Gov. Parson tries to evade Sunshine Law compliance by invoking First Amendment
body text:
Gov. Mike Parson is trying a novel approach to evade compliance with Missouri’s Sunshine Law, concocting a First Amendment exception that allows his office to redact information about the people trying to influence him or seek his help. State Auditor Nicole Galloway, whose job includes monitoring Sunshine Law compliance, is understandably perturbed. The general public should be as well.The controversy arose over numerous attempts by journalists to review Parson’s records and determine whether special interests are seeking favor or trying to influence him. The assertion of a constitutional right to redact information under the First Amendment, if upheld, could render the entire Sunshine Law moot. The public’s ability to hold public officeholders accountable would be shattered.On Tuesday, Galloway asked Missouri Attorney General Eric Schmitt for an opinion on whether information may lawfully be redacted related to individuals conducting business with, lobbying or trying to influence government officials. Galloway is a Democrat; Parson and Schmitt are Republicans.

“Government should not be in the business of finding ways to hide information from taxpayers, but time and again, we have seen continued efforts to do just that ...,” she said in a statement. “There should be no confusion on how the Sunshine Law is applied.”Innovative efforts to evade Sunshine Law compliance are the stuff of legends in Jefferson City. Parson’s predecessor, Eric Greitens, and some senior staffers used a phone app designed to automatically delete text messages after being read by the recipient. The app opened new ways for public officials to unlawfully use their government offices to discuss, say, campaign donations, or coordinate official activities with dark-money groups without any record of the communications being searchable under the Sunshine Law.The state Legislature has long exempted itself from the Sunshine Law and is advancing a bill to weaken the law and circumvent new requirements under the “Clean Missouri” amendment approved statewide by voters in November. An exemption blocking constituent emails from discovery would extend even to local governments and school boards.
The problem is that “constituents” could also include lobbyists, developers, contractors or others seeking to influence officials free from public scrutiny.Parson’s communications director, Steele Shippy, says the First Amendment applies because constituents communicating with the governor might fear having their personal information exposed. Thus, it could have an inhibiting effect on their free speech.
Permitting the redaction of phone numbers from official records blocks journalists’ and the general public’s ability to link phone numbers of lobbyists and other special interests with the officials they’re trying to influence.In November, Parson pledged to “lead by example” and abide by the “highest ethical standards.” He committed himself to “provide transparency and uphold the rule of law.”That’s some example.If Schmitt sides with the governor, a gigantic cone of darkness and silence would descend on Missourians’ right to know.

article headline: Industrial farms good for business, bad for neighbors
body text:
Something smells about the recently passed Missouri Senate Bill 391. The bill will soon move to the House: “Overnight filibuster in Missouri Senate ends in win for ag groups that want to lure big farms” (May 1).The legislation means that local environmental regulations of 20 Missouri counties would revert to the already inadequate state standards. Water pollution from liquefied manure and its resulting odor would be rampant. Tough luck if you live anywhere near these gigantic operations.

Whereas Gov. Mike Parson touts this as a win for Missouri farm and ranch families, what it really means is that large, out-of-state operations can move in to take advantage of this weak legislation.
Poisoning land and water is both wrongheaded and unsustainable. Missouri is already one of the nation’s largest cattle- and hog-slaughter states. The lobbyists from the Missouri Cattlemen’s and Missouri Pork Associations will effectively ensure that the Republican-dominated House and Senate continue to expand animal agriculture at the expense of both our human and nonhuman residents unless we let our legislators know this bill is totally unacceptable.
William Ash • University City

article headline: Missouri's beleaguered public defenders poised to earn a small win in this year's budget
body text:
JEFFERSON CITY — The Missouri public defender’s office will be able to re-open its juvenile advocacy units in St. Louis County and Jackson County if funding for the endeavor isn’t zapped in the coming days and months.The $913,786 appropriation for the two units represents a small victory for the office, a long-underfunded agency that represents indigent defendants across the state.The units will be able to hire attorneys who specialize in juvenile issues.

“For the kids, they don’t have any public defenders who are experienced in juvenile law,” said Rep. Ingrid Burnett, D-Kansas City, who had advocated for the funding.A House-Senate conference committee approved the spending Tuesday, but the line-item still must clear the full House and Senate later this week.














        
            Missouri children are waiving their right to legal counsel. That's a problem, some lawmakers say.

"Children, and particularly children who get into trouble, don't exercise good judgment," said Rep. Ingrid Burnett. "And so, expecting them to exercise good judgment when it comes to waiving their rights I think is a stretch."




Gov. Mike Parson, a Republican, also could veto the spending, like he did last year, when he nixed $487,000 that was supposed to go toward juvenile advocacy.“This funding will provide a hopeful future for young people involved in the juvenile system and will also reduce the stress on our prison system,” Michael Barrett, the director of the public defender’s office, said in an email. “I seriously hope the Governor shares the legislature’s support for reducing the prison population and protecting the rights of poor children.”Core funding for the public defender’s office will probably remain constant, at about $50 million for the fiscal year that starts July 1. That means the office will still be underfunded by about $30 million, the office has said.
The inadequate funding ultimately leads to more juveniles and adults being incarcerated rather than returning to their communities, Barrett has said. He argues this increases costs to the state in the long run.“Each unit will pay for itself,” Barrett said of the juvenile units. “Each unit will only have to divert 26 children away from state prison in order to generate enough savings to pay for one of these units. The units will serve hundreds of children annually around the state.”The public defender’s office is also poised to receive an extra $500,000 to help address its case backlog.
“The $500,000 is to hire private attorneys to help reduce the current wait-list of individuals charged with an offense who don’t yet have counsel (because of excessive caseloads),” Barrett said. “This is causing people to sit in jail longer, driving up costs for the counties and the state.”While the office has remained underfunded, legislative leaders and Parson have moved forward with several criminal justice reform initiatives this year.The office in the past has tried to raise the profile of its funding issues.In 2016, Barrett ordered then-Gov. Jay Nixon, an attorney, to represent an indigent client amid budget woes within the agency. A judge ultimately said Nixon, a Democrat, did not have to do so.The legislation is House Bill 12.

article headline: In pursuit of an expansion of GM's Wentzville plant, Missouri offering up $50 million in subsidies
Expect the rivers to rise again — soon
body text:
ST. LOUIS — Major rivers in the St. Louis area are receding — temporarily, at least.But even as water levels fall, concerns remain. That’s because with significant rainfall expected over the next couple days in St. Louis and regions upstream, another major crest is projected about a week from now.That crest is expected to be about a foot lower than the one that just passed, which, if confirmed, ranks as the seventh-highest in St. Louis’ recorded history. Data from the U.S. Geological Survey said the Mississippi River topped 41.3 feet downtown Monday — more than 11 feet above flood stage.

The slightly lower crest that’s on its way may not pose a greater threat overall, but it could prove especially problematic in areas where flood protection has already faltered. Thirteen area levees have been overtopped by the spring’s extended flooding, with 11 happening in recent days, according to the St. Louis District of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. All of the structures are agricultural levees, and some were breached by floodwater after being overtaken.The St. Louis District of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers continues to operate its Emergency Operations Center and provide local officials with supplies and technical assistance amid the flood fight.“We’ll continue to have our folks in the field,” said John Osterhage, the district’s chief of emergency management. “We’re still staying engaged.”And although the coming floodwater may not creep as high, continued flooding can still take its toll, particularly on earthen levees. Even if the structures do not breach or become overtopped, water can still find ways to seep through or beneath them.
“There is some risk, the longer that we see elevated river levels,” Osterhage said, “the more saturated levees become and the more likely we are to see seepage issues.”Some area residents in low-lying areas have been evacuated from their homes, but Osterhage did not know how many.Starting Tuesday night, weather forecasts called for flash flooding and some heavy rain to move into upstream regions including Kansas City and parts of Iowa. Wet conditions are expected to move east through Wednesday across central Missouri, where “thunderstorms will be capable of producing heavy rain over already saturated ground,” according to the St. Louis forecast office of the National Weather Service.
Missouri Gov. Mike Parson is scheduled to receive a briefing on area flooding on Wednesday at the St. Charles Emergency Operations Center in O'Fallon.The Mississippi River around St. Louis has been at flood stage since March, and it is not clear when it will return to normal levels. If the latest crest is made official, four of the city’s nine highest floods will have occurred in the last six years — joining events from 2013, 2016 and 2017.Various experts account for the increasingly common floods by pointing to factors such as more extreme precipitation fueled by climate change, and the constriction of rivers by expansive levee systems that push water higher, instead of allowing it to spread out.

Tsichlis: STEM Education Needs HELP
body text:
For over a decade, the dizzying pace of scientific and technological innovation has prompted educators to place greater emphasis on instructing K-12 students in science, technology, engineering, and math, or STEM. To better meet the needs of a tech-driven workforce, Gov. Mike Parson signed a bill in October authorizing the Missouri Department of Elementary and Secondary Education to create a “STEM Career Awareness Program,” that encourages students to explore those fields beginning in sixth grade.Few challenge the need for quality education in those fields. What is often left out of the conversation, however, are the potentially challenging ethical quandaries that can result from scientific innovation. For example, many would consider it a noble goal if medical advances supported by work in genetics, nanotechnology and cybernetics produced treatments and cures that lengthen our lifespan and enhance our quality of life. On the other hand, are we willing to accept the risks to privacy and possible discrimination that go with others accessing our genetic profiles?Expect a Pandora’s Box of such questions to be unleashed in coming years. Who will benefit from such applications? Who will not? Will there be a choice? Are we prepared to relinquish such important ethical decisions to tech elites or the algorithmic conclusions of artificial intelligence itself? Is this the path for a society that claims to live by democratic values?

The challenge with today’s children is how to best steer them through such ethical dilemmas. Such guideposts are readily found in the fields of humanities, ethics, literature, and philosophy, or HELP.HELP directly ties to STEM. Corresponding to the all-encompassing, multi-disciplinary term “science,” humanities refers to that broad array of studies in human experience — particularly history — that traces the trajectory of human development and its related progress, challenges, and dangers.Paralleling technology is the study of ethics, the tools by which we understand and make moral choices. As engineering concerns the language of design, so too does literature provide the narrative language of human experiences, such as life lessons and moral dilemmas pondered in works like “I, Robot,” among others. Finally, as mathematics is the study of the world by numeric precision, philosophy suggests ways to navigate the imprecise world and messy relationships between human perception and action.
The disciplines of humanities, ethics, literature, and philosophy will not only be essential to future workers in scientific research and development, but for all who grapple with the proper applications and limits to these developments in a democratic society. The emphasis is not principally to ask “How do we do it?” but rather “Whom will it benefit?”, “How might it do harm?”, and ultimately “Should we do it?” It’s about what millennia of collective experience has shown us. It’s about wisdom-building.Science doesn’t happen in a value-free vacuum. Developing a research question or hypothesis is itself an exercise laden with presuppositions based on one’s priorities and values. If society is to remain built on freedom and participation — and not merely a race to keep up with advances in science, technology, engineering and math with little reflection on their consequences — HELP subjects will be essential to the K-12 education. The lessons of humanities, ethics, literature and philosophy are as vital as their STEM counterparts.
There is also a diversity of personal, family, cultural, and faith-based foundations that undergird students’ ethical and moral decision-making developed outside of public schools. But K-12 students spend the bulk of their young lives in a school-based setting, and the least we can do is ensure the instruction they receive includes the fundamentals of how to make the best possible choices.If we fail to engage our children in the discernment between right and wrong, it will be left to others to do it for them, be they corporations, government entities or the next upgrade in artificial intelligence.Michael G. Tsichlis holds a doctorate in Public Policy and is on the Lindbergh Schools Board of Directors.Vasilika Terss Tsichlis has an educational specialist’s degree in Educational Leadership and is working on a Ph.D. in curriculum and instruction at Saint Louis University. After a 30-year career as a teacher and administrator she currently works in higher education.

article headline: Overnight filibuster in Missouri Senate ends in win for ag groups that want to lure big farms
Trish Gunby for House District 99
body text:
TRISH GUNBY ANNOUNCES CANDIDACY FOR STATE REP IN HD99Manchester, MO, April 29, 2019– While celebrating her 30th wedding anniversary, Manchester residentTrish Gunby has announced her candidacy to represent Missouri’s 99th House District on the

Democratic ticket. The seat is up for grabs in a special election called for November 5, 2019 by Gov.Mike Parson.“Time and time again, our state legislature has failed to represent constituents’ voting interests,” Gunbysaid. “I can no longer sit two hours away from Jefferson City, while representation for my district, anddistricts statewide, gets trampled on.”For years, Trish has volunteered in her district and across Missouri to further the interests ofunderserved communities.At Manchester United Methodist Church, she served as Social Justice Coordinator, elevating thecongregation’s awareness of issues related to gun violence, hunger and poverty in the U.S., LGBTQrights, mental health and racial justice. As co-leader of West County Community Action Network’s
Voting Rights Team and Board Secretary for Women’s Voices Raised for Social Justice, she’s continued toeducate herself and others on the evolving world we live in.“Whether it’s voting rights or marriage equality or school lunches, Missouri needs to face forward, not
backwards, to establish fairness and equity. And don’t just ask me, ask the 62% of voters who stoodfirmly in favor of Clean MO and a fair wage.”Trish has lived in the District for 25 years with her husband Mark, joined by their children Kyle and Bryn.Both she and her children are graduates of Parkway Schools, while her husband grew up a Cubs fan inChicago’s suburbs.After 30 years, she has learned to be exceptionally forgiving.# # #If you would like more information about Trish’s campaign, please contactCampaign Manager Rosetta Okohson-Reb at 314-225-6658 or at rokohsonreb@gmail.com.

Editorial: Captain awaits justice from Missouri National Guard after sexual assault
body text:
Just when it appeared that women's voices were finally being heard around the country demanding justice for sexual assault and a halt to inappropriate behavior, the Missouri National Guard has taken a giant step backward on those same fronts. Heather Sexton, who was an Army captain but left active duty after 10 years of service, is living a kind of #MeToo nightmare: National Guard investigators confirmed she is the victim of sexual assault, yet they won't go after her assailant.If the military's decision is allowed to stand, Sexton will have received no more justice than if authorities had ignored her case in the first place. It's time for members of Missouri's congressional delegation to take charge and insist her case receives the full hearing it deserves.As the Post-Dispatch’s Tony Messenger reported, Sexton summoned her courage and came forward immediately with her charges, only to be met with the legal equivalent of a pat on the head. The investigating team confirmed that after a social event at Camp Williams in Utah, a sergeant grabbed “the victim’s groin and breast and stomach” without her consent. But the same team “found insufficient evidence to determine the reported perpetrator’s intent of the physical contact, thus we are unable to establish that intentional sexual contact occurred.”

After the investigation, Sexton was included on an email addressed to the entire unit from Gen. David Boyle, the Guard's joint task commander, admonishing the group for serving alcohol at the Utah event and calling for them to “exercise better judgement and comport yourselves appropriately” in the future. Her inclusion in the email made it appear as if she was also being admonished.
Achieving justice in sexual assault cases is particularly difficult when the allegations boil down to he-said/she-said. But in this case, investigators had ample testimony to support Sexton's allegations. The findings were as if a jury handed down a guilty verdict, only to grant the defendant a pardon and a clean record.“I’m an officer, and this happened to me,” Sexton said. “What happens when a private gets sexually assaulted? I felt a strong responsibility as a leader to make sure this doesn’t happen to other women.”
It almost feels as if the Missouri National Guard wants Sexton to be content just knowing she was right. But leave weighty questions of justice to the menfolk.Merely acknowledging a crime is not, and has never been, justice by itself. Sexton has written to various Republicans — Gov. Mike Parson, Sen. Josh Hawley, Sen. Roy Blunt, and Rep. Ann Wagner — to make them aware of what has happened in her case. If they truly believe in the cause of justice and equal rights for women, they will not allow this case to fade into obscurity.

article headline: Republican-on-Republican angst jams up the Missouri Senate
Messenger: Battle against mass incarceration is making a dent in Missouri's prison population
body text:
The letter from Dent County Jail contained good news.If you get letters from people in custody — and I get a fair amount — good news is a rarity. People locked up generally have plenty of good reason to complain.Not this time.

“You wouldn’t believe the changes that have taken place around here,” the woman wrote.She and I first corresponded last year, shortly after I began a series of columns on men and women in rural Missouri jails, held because they couldn’t afford to pay their jail “board bills” for previous misdemeanor sentences.She told me about the conditions in the jail, about the high cash bails that kept people there, about how they would plead guilty to whatever they were charged with just to get out.She introduced me to people who had been caught up in this debtors prison scheme.She was self-aware enough to know her case wouldn’t be sympathetic, so she was content to point me in the right direction and help those around her.There was a time, about a year or so ago, when the number of women in the Dent County Jail surpassed the men.“Perhaps women are less likely to get the money for bond, or maybe they are just easier to manipulate,” she speculated.That’s no longer the case.Last November, the judge who was most responsible for jailing people in Dent County over failure to pay court costs lost her election. The judge’s friend who ran the private probation company lost her job. When the Missouri Supreme Court ruled that it was illegal to jail people over failure to pay their jail board bills, the presiding judge in the circuit, Kelly Parker, started releasing people from their illegal debts.“What you probably haven’t heard is how the atmosphere has changed,” my friend wrote me last week. “The jail is emptying out. People that do come in are able to bond out quickly. None of the girls here are being held for financial reasons. This place isn’t the terrifying dungeon it used to feel like. The new judges are actually listening to people’s needs instead of sending them straight to prison.”This is progress, and it’s not limited to one rural Missouri county.
Last year, Missouri led the nation in reducing its rate of mass incarceration. That positive detail is contained in a new report released by the Vera Institute of Justice on Wednesday, showing that criminal justice reforms nationally are having a positive effect.Between 2017 and 2018, the Vera report determined, the rate of incarceration in Missouri dropped by 7.1 percent, a more precipitous decline by rate than any other state in the country. The federal decline was 1.3 percent. The report looks strictly at state prison numbers, and the authors point to a few likely reasons for the reduction in mass incarceration in Missouri, says Jacob Kang-Brown, a senior research associate at Vera.First, in early 2017, the state’s first major overhaul of the criminal code took effect. It dropped sentences on many minor crimes, such as marijuana possession; streamlined many repetitive charges; added parole in cases that didn’t previously have it; and added a fifth level of felony for crimes that don’t deserve harsh sentences.Also, in St. Louis, voters elected reform-minded prosecutors, Kimberly M. Gardner in the city and Wesley Bell in the county, and both promised to reform the bail system and stop seeking jail time for some minor offenses, such as child support prosecutions in the county.
While Vera’s study doesn’t address local jail populations, both the city and county have dropped their daily jail counts significantly in the past two years, and often, that is a precursor to a reduced state jail population.Last year, Missouri started a “justice reinvestment” project working with the U.S. Department of Justice and the Pew Charitable Trusts which seeks to reduce recidivism by improving behavioral health treatment options and probation supervision.All of those efforts are contributing to the decline in Missouri prison population. So will Gov. Mike Parson’s effort to close a state prison, and the effect on the Missouri Supreme Court decision on the jail board bills, which should reduce incentives for counties to try to fill the pipeline from county jail to state prison.None of that will help my pen pal. She’s likely headed to prison after her stay in Dent County.Meanwhile, Missouri lawmakers are debating several measures that could continue criminal justice reform measures in the state, reducing the state’s prison population, and sending people who have served their time back to their communities, where they can rebuild lives, contribute to the economy and get a fresh start.“Criminal justice reform is working,” Kang-Brown says.In some respects, Missouri is leading the way.












        

        
            Vera report on prison population

By Tony Messenger

article headline: Life sciences respect essential to Missouri patients and economy
body text:
Missouri’s freshman senator likely had a number of his constituents scratching their heads this month when he attacked a valued economic engine in his own state to promote his newly filed price-control legislation. Republican Sen. Josh Hawley, in his first three months on the job, took a swipe at one of the most important industries we have in Missouri — indeed, in this country — and we need to provide important context to his poor choice of words.Hawley’s characterization referred to “Big Pharma” being “not good actors.” The life sciences industry is incredibly important to our local economy, and the interwoven collaborative work of large and small pharma is vital to every person in this state who has ever needed a prescription.In Missouri, the life sciences industry employs nearly 30,000 people, supporting families from St. Joseph to St. Louis. Innovation in health, biopharma and agriculture technology are creating high-skill jobs — with average annual wages at $76,000 — spurring economic growth and improving the lives of Missourians.

A few recent examples: Boehringer Ingelheim in St. Joseph, celebrated its centennial last year, and today employs nearly 1,000 people. Pfizer is opening a nearly $240 million global research and development hub in Chesterfield next month, employing nearly 600 scientists. Bayer completed its acquisition of Monsanto last year, solidifying St. Louis as its global center for crop science. And that’s just a few. There are hundreds more biopharma enterprises just as important, if not brand-recognizable.In his new legislative role, I hope that Hawley can be a promoter of economic expansion across the state by supporting life science research and creating a pro-business environment for expansion of these fast-growth companies. Innovations led by the life sciences industry — from small businesses and startups to large companies — are an American success story which is good news, not a point of attack.Right now, more than 900 biotech drugs are in clinical development targeting cancer, cardiovascular diseases, Alzheimer’s and thousands of rare diseases. What patients pay for prescription medications is way more complex than simply blaming pharmaceutical companies. Costs for prescriptions are determined by multiple complex factors, including deductibles and co-pays in insurance plans, generic alternatives, employers and what they offer, distributors and pharmaceutical-benefits managers along with research, manufacturing and the decade-long federal approval process.Other state leaders have taken a commendable approach to supporting Missouri’s needs and future.
Gov. Mike Parson visited more than 50 biotech facilities across Missouri during the last decade. He followed up on that listening tour by supporting new funding for research in higher education, and for state programs and policies that will commercialize those discoveries and create new companies. These startups are often the outsourced research and development teams for more mature pharma enterprises.
In March, Sen. Roy Blunt announced that the National Institutes of Health would receive $39.1 billion in appropriated funding this year. This allows for investments in medical research to generate new advanced biologics and lower drug costs. Blunt knows that when the NIH is well funded, Missouri wins. In 2018, Blunt received the national Innovator in Biotechnology award for his leadership.Fifty-seven years ago, noted economist Milton Friedman explored the roles of capitalism and democracy. Politicians, he noted, often are tempted to give government a greater role and markets a smaller one. Friedman explained that economic policy is often not decided on the basis of careful thought but rather on the limited (non-expert) viewpoints of elected officials and their voters.For politicians who want to lead us down the path of government price controls, I’d ask them to support the strength of the free market. Those elected officials can advocate for policies that allow companies to innovate, with competition and the market cycle of ever emerging generics serving as a much more powerful self-regulator.Despite his poor choice of words, my inclination is to believe that Hawley wants to support a major economic engine that provides jobs and saves lives. We invite him to see Missouri bioscience work in action and meet the scientists who toil for entire careers, providing tangible cures and relief for patients.Kelly Gillespie is president and chief executive of the Missouri Biotechnology Association, a statewide nonprofit trade association. His email is kelly@mobio.org.
