body text:
BOWLING GREEN, Mo. • The first recruit showed up at boot camp an hour early, wearing a 2014 letter jacket to keep warm.Then two pals pulled into the icy parking lot together, also eager to become correctional officers. One of them, after a short stint in the Army, craved routine. The other had a daughter to support and felt lucky to have survived an infection that cut his weight to 365 pounds.Bethany Henson, 22, was a third his size. She arrived determined to confront her fear of abusive men for the opportunity to earn enough money to have her own home. Had she not been starting a criminal justice career this day, she said, she’d be looking for a lawyer.
“I want to show all these other single mothers out there who have had as much difficulty as I’ve had that they can do it,” said Henson, who has three children. “When I was younger, I didn’t feel like dreams mattered.”













Missouri Department of Corrections recruits sign in on the first day of correctional officer boot camp on March 4, 2019, at the Pike County Fairgrounds pavilion near Bowling Green, Mo. Photo by J.B. Forbes, jforbes@post-dispatch.com


J.B. Forbes


In all, 46 people — ages 19 to 52 — started the four-week boot camp on March 4. Their backgrounds were diverse, but the reasons why they wanted to be on the front lines of the Missouri Department of Corrections were not.“Right now they need a job. That’s who is coming through the door,” said Jim Wiseman, head of training for the department, which has been hammered by turnover. “And doggone it, we need them.”Wiseman stood under the disco ball at the Pike County Fairgrounds, personally greeting each one of them. “Come on in, welcome,” he said. “You found us.”Under normal conditions, new recruits go to training academies in Jefferson City, Farmington or St. Joseph before being placed in one of the state’s 21 prisons. Staff departures have been so high at Northeast Correctional Center in Bowling Green — and the competition steep for the same jobs in Illinois and Iowa — that the medium-security prison needed a lifeboat of its own.













Carl Lewis, a defensive tactics instructor for the Missouri Department of Corrections, shows trainees the proper way to subdue an inmate and put him in handcuffs in March 2019, at the Pike County Fairgrounds pavilion near Bowling Green, Mo. Photo by J.B. Forbes, jforbes@post-dispatch.com


J.B. Forbes


Shortages have depleted institutional knowledge statewide, while more and more officers quit. In 2018 alone, 1,262 correctional officers left, up from 823 in 2014. There were recently 776 openings for the lowest level of correctional officer, which has a full capacity of 4,773.

Missouri keeps losing corrections officers


The Missouri Department of Corrections lost 5,267 correctional officers in the past five years. Of that number, 75 percent resigned.

Though the state’s largest agency operates on a $786 million annual budget, its 11,000 employees are among the lowest paid in the nation. The average salary last year for correctional officers and jailers in Missouri was $31,650, according to the U.S. Department of Labor — well below both Iowa, $50,750, and Illinois, $62,440. Missouri Gov. Mike Parson, in his budget proposal, calls for pay raises that could be as much as 13 percent for some correctional officers, which officials say will help retention.But the job itself — being hemmed in by a “kill fence” with violent offenders — isn’t for everyone, no matter the pay. The so-called forgotten officers of law enforcement face a bruising cycle. Fewer hands and low morale cut into the quality of programs for the 30,000 inmates, which disrupts prison life and adds more stress for everyone.













Correctional officer trainees Kasey Crisman, Ashley Treiber and Haley Sharrow hitch a ride back to their cars after they passed shotgun testing March 25, 2019, at the gun range next to the Northeast Correctional Center (in the background) in Bowling Green, Mo. All trainees had to pass the shooting proficiency test before they could become correctional officers. Photo by J.B. Forbes, jforbes@post-dispatch.com


J.B. Forbes


It’s also increasingly more costly for taxpayers. In 2018 alone, the department spent $26 million on overtime, more than three times as much as in 2014.That doesn’t include a mountain of unused comp time and more than $113 million that a Cole County court awarded correctional officers in 2018 for unpaid work that they performed before and after their shifts.

Overtime costs climb as correctional officers leave


Overtime paid to correctional officers has soared in recent years, topping $26 million in 2018. That’s more than three times as much as in 2014.

Bethany Henson practices how to take the proper defensive stance when confronted by an unruly inmate during training in March 2019, at the Pike County Fairgrounds pavilion near Bowling Green, Mo. Photo by J.B. Forbes, jforbes@post-dispatch.com


J.B. Forbes


A few officers said voluntary and mandatory overtime are nice for a while, but it’s gone on so long that workers get burned out by not seeing the families they’re trying to support. Some call in sick rather than wait to be relieved from a long shift.One correctional officer getting ready to quit said inmates know staff can be too tired to deal with them, which makes it easier to plant and pass around contraband, such as drugs and homemade tattoo guns, hooch and knives.All the while, those who are stepping up to get hired tend to be younger and less experienced. The minimum age has dropped to 19 from 21. A driver’s license is no longer required. Nor are the agility and problem-solving tests once used to screen applicants. About a third of new hires don’t make it through the first year, which Director Anne Precythe is trying to improve in part through the training program.In Bowling Green, Wiseman encouraged the new class of recruits to ask questions and not give up if they get discouraged. He also promised cookies and punch in a month at a graduation ceremony that their families could attend, an event that had fallen out of practice.“We got you in the door right now,” he told them. “You are employees. Don’t go anywhere, folks.”Biggest employerMany of the recruits were starting the highest paying job of their lives: A base salary of $30,000, or $15 an hour, and benefits.A lot of them came from eastern Pike County, along the Mississippi River, where the loss of industry 85 miles north of St. Louis has made the economic situation look “Third World,” said Chris Gamm, presiding county commissioner.“The Department of Corrections is by far the largest employer in the county,” he said.













New correctional officers listen to instructors during training April 4, 2019, at the Northeast Correctional Center in Bowling Green, Mo. They were practicing in an empty housing building. They are clockwise from lower left: Jacob Hazel, Madison Wilburn, Michael Hagood, Nicholas Vieira, Timothy Snider, and Tracy Davis. Photo by J.B. Forbes, jforbes@post-dispatch.com


J.B. Forbes


Tracy Davis, 48, of Louisiana, Mo., said she’s gone through several jobs in recent years, including waitress, medication tech, and temp at the GM assembly plant. She liked the stability of the prison industry. “I’ve been trying to find something that pays well and has good benefits, so I ended up here,” Davis said.She’s a grandmother with five grown children — one boy, four girls. “It will be OK,” she said about the challenges of dealing with prisoners. “The inmates have nothing on my girls.”Lisa Maxey most recently earned $8.35 an hour at a gas station and didn’t want to say why that job ended.“Bowling Green really doesn’t have any options, to be honest,” she said. “There are a few gas stations and restaurants, and there’s Walmart. You never know when they are going to be hiring. It’s nice to go where they actually need you and you aren’t just expendable.”When she was in high school, she wanted to be a mortician or work in a psych ward. Now 27, with the driver’s license requirement lifted, she was excited to get a flavor of that at the corrections department. Her family was proud of her.“They said I have the mentality for it,” she said. “I can shut off my emotions in a heartbeat.”Austin Borders, 23, was originally from the southeast Missouri town of Doniphan, where he said he grew up working at sawmills and later ran out of opportunity. In Bowling Green, he’s washed dishes at a café and most recently earned $9.25 an hour at McDonald’s, which cut his shift in half over winter.“I can’t get my bills paid on that,” he said.He looked forward to steady paychecks and all the overtime they’d give him. He’d recently put $400 down on a $2,500 pickup and agreed to pay at least $150 a month. Now the transmission was going out and the truck needed other repairs.“My brakes are metal on metal,” he said.Keeping it professionalA few of them had experience working with inmates.Ashley Treiber, 29, formerly worked as a correctional officer for St. Charles County. She had a lot of informed responses to questions in class. She also had a long commute and a 2-year-old son. She arrived late after lunch on the first day of boot camp, in tears. She said her grandfather died over the weekend.“I am trying to make this work,” she said. “I am going to keep trying.”A 5-hour energy drink helped get her through the afternoon session on discrimination, harassment, retaliation and unprofessional conduct.Scott Phillips, of the Office of Professional Standards Civil Rights Unit, told them that professionalism was expected of every employee of the department and that they could set the tone of worksite culture.“We work for the public, the citizens of Missouri,” he told them. “It’s important that we give them a good reason to continue to fund us. If we are behaving badly, do you think they are going to want to fund us the way that we think we need?”While he didn’t need a fake example, he put up a sample story from the “The Daily News” to show possible publicity from doing the wrong thing, like bringing contraband into prison, having sex with offenders or harassing peers.That same afternoon, a headline ran in the St. Louis Post-Dispatch about the state paying $600,000 to a corrections department employee to settle a sexual harassment claim. Shown the story, Jessica Hays, 23, said she hadn’t heard about the case, nor numerous other payouts and reports exposing a culture of harassment and retaliation in Missouri’s prisons.













Correctional trainee Derick Williams takes a turn at using pepper spray (water for simulation) during boot camp in March 2019 at the Pike County Fairgrounds pavilion near Bowling Green, Mo. Photo by J.B. Forbes, jforbes@post-dispatch.com


J.B. Forbes


“They offer really good benefits. The pay is decent. I figured I might as well start something new I can build a career in,” said Hays. “I wanted to see what I am made of.”Other women in the class hadn’t heard about the scandal either.Phillips went through several scenarios to help notice improper behavior among staff and supervisors. For instance, what if a boss invites you out for beers to talk about a test?“Is that a request for sex?” Phillips asked.“Not yet,” said Treiber.Dealing with inmatesTwo weeks later, Angela Nickelson went through more scenarios to prepare the recruits for inmates with special needs and those who will try to manipulate them.“You are going to take a lot of verbal abuse,” she warned. “We don’t care, do we?”Nickelson, 49, made a career out of corrections. She said in an interview that when she was hired in 1994, she was one of the smallest correctional officers in the department — and likely the only one with a fresh college degree in elementary education.“The brain is the most powerful tool you can have here,” she said. “We are not all out there wrestling inmates every day.”













New correctional officers Bethany Henson (left) and Collin Wynn practice the method of bringing inmates out of their cells in handcuffs during training on April 4, 2019, at the Northeast Correctional Center in Bowling Green, Mo. They were practicing in an empty housing building. Photo by J.B. Forbes, jforbes@post-dispatch.com


J.B. Forbes


A year after being hired, she said, she was relieved to be assigned to a death row housing unit at Potosi Correctional Center. Compared to the general prison population, she said, they were laid back. One of them was serial killer Anthony Joe LaRette.
“He was pretty interesting,” she said. “Super friendly. Great personality, which is what you should be leery of.”She said people who work in corrections “aren’t like normal people.” She admitted that she has a potty mouth from working in the industry and prison lingo permeated her household. Instead of being grounded, her kids went to “administrative segregation” at home when they got in trouble.Inmates and low pay don’t seem to scare her. She didn’t discourage her son, a former heavyweight wrestler, from the career. In 2018, his first full year of employment with the department, he made $35,679, according to a state database. Mom, the veteran employee, made $41,382.She specializes in training correctional officers. “Nothing about our job is about punishment, it’s about rehabilitation and treating people as human beings,” she told the class, assuring: “How you present yourself is how you will be perceived.”Many inmates have disabilities such as dementia, schizophrenia and post-traumatic stress disorder.“Some don’t play well with others because of their mental illness,” she said. “Then they are locked up in a prison full of people they’d like to stay away from. They aren’t being rebellious. They don’t get it.”But inmates with antisocial personality disorder are some of the worst to look out for, she said, “(Even) if you have six kids, they will take you out and not care.”She went over how to notice and talk to inmates contemplating suicide. Before showing the recruits how to cut somebody down who tried to hang himself, she gave fair warning for the class exercise.Henson, the 22-year-old recruit with three kids, fled the room and missed hearing Nickelson say this:“When you walk in and see somebody hanging and you’ve never seen it, it’s pretty disturbing. You are going to see it a million more times in your head.”Reacting to violenceDefensive tactics seemed the most emotionally challenging to the class. One recruit, who’d impressed colleagues and instructors through coursework, broke down and cried while working on the mats. She said she’d been the victim of domestic violence.Another said she wasn’t comfortable having anybody even act like they were choking her. An older man in the class also struggled to learn various maneuvers.













Training officer Sgt. Dan Wiley (left) shows correctional officer trainee Kasey Crisman how to take control of an inmate so that he can be safely escorted in March 2019 at the Pike County Fairgrounds pavilion near Bowling Green, Mo. Photo by J.B. Forbes, jforbes@post-dispatch.com


J.B. Forbes


Sgt. Dan Wiley, an Army veteran with three lifesaver awards and another for valor from his work at Northeast Correctional Center, told recruits to breathe and keep trying until various techniques became muscle memory.“This is just practice for when the real thing happens,” he told them.Videos of real attacks weren’t shared at boot camp. Instead, they role-played attacking each other in slow motion with rubber knives and other devices.“Hand me your weapon,” one recruit said.“Why are you stabbing me?” asked another.
In late 2017, an offender at the prison used a homemade knife to stab a correctional officer in the back of the head and hand multiple times as she tried to flee Housing Unit No. 8. The unprovoked “hit and run” happened in about 10 seconds, maybe less, said Jeff Kaufman, a Bowling Green detective.“I am sure it seemed like hours to her,” he said.The injured officer was treated and released from the hospital and later testified that she had lingering injuries and mental anguish. She is still employed by the department. The trainee who was beside her at the time of the attack is not.Wiley was one of the first to respond. He saw the blood and heard the screams of what he said sounded like someone being murdered. He helped restrain the inmate who did it — Jeardin Hutchins, 31, of Bel-Ridge, who was in prison for robbing a Domino’s Pizza on Natural Bridge Road in 2011.Asked if the trainees were prepared to defend themselves, Wiley said: “Were you ready when your child was born? They are going to have to grow as officers before anybody is ready.”‘Part of our family’As promised, there were cookies and punch on Graduation Day. Out of the 46 who started boot camp, two dropped out, including one recruit who described himself on his social media page as a “professional napper.”The rest graduated, but four of them were on provisional status until they passed defensive tactics and shooting a 12-gauge shotgun. About a fourth of them had never fired a weapon.













Correctional trainee Ebony Strickland is shown the proper way to shoulder a shotgun by Case Manager Brook Kurth during boot camp on March 25, 2019, at the Pike County Fairgrounds pavilion near Bowling Green, Mo. Kurth is also a part-time minister. Photo by J.B. Forbes, jforbes@post-dispatch.com


J.B. Forbes


“Wow! This is a big deal,” Wiseman, the training chief, said at the ceremony. “We do graduation ceremonies, and recognition ceremonies, but not this big.”He thanked the 150 people in attendance.“There are a lot of things that happen inside a prison that challenge employees, and they need the support of family and friends,” he said. “We can see, just from looking out here, that they have your support.”













Correctional trainee Jade Martin (left) polishes the boots of fellow trainee Bethany Henson before their boot camp graduation ceremony on March 29, 2019, at the Pike County Fairgrounds. Watching in the background is trainee Brandon Mesey. Photo by J.B. Forbes, jforbes@post-dispatch.com


J.B. Forbes


Dan Redington, the new warden in Bowling Green, also offered congratulations. “We truly are looking forward to getting you back to our facility, making you part of our family,” he said.Twenty-five years ago, he said, he was sitting where they were. He thought being a correctional officer was going to be temporary.“Lo and behold, it got into my skin and I loved this environment,” he said. “I loved the people I am working with. I can truly say this job has been a blessing because it has taken care of my family, and it’s something I enjoy to do. So I hope that you all will feel the same way about this.”













New correctional officer Lindsaylee Webb gets a hug from her daughter, Charla Webb, 8, after a Missouri Department of Corrections graduation ceremony held March 29, 2019, at the Pike County Fairgrounds. Photo by J.B. Forbes, jforbes@post-dispatch.com


J.B. Forbes


After hearing many complaints as a Republican state representative from the area, Rep. Jim Hansen, vice chairman of the House Corrections Committee, said in a speech to the graduates that the department was moving in the right direction.“I am truly grateful for the work you are doing to keep our community safe, to help rehabilitate people,” he said. “That is the No. 1 mission, to get people back into society and be productive citizens. So I wish you the best.”That resonated with Stacey Strickland, 45, of Hannibal, whose daughter Ebony was among the graduates. Another daughter also works in the prison system.“If you can change one person — one individual — sometimes the flowers keep growing,” he said.Stacy Harrison said she was proud of her “headstrong and determined” daughter, Bethany Henson, for taking advantage of one of the biggest opportunities in the area. “It scares me a little bit, but I know the security there is something you can count on,” she said.Michael Davis, 20, of Louisiana, said he was proud of his mother, Tracy Davis — the grandmother with five children.“Over the last year and a half, she’s gone through so many jobs, it’s crazy,” he said.Always opportunitiesThe Northeast Correctional Center, built for 2,100 inmates, hunkers in a former cornfield between the Bowling Green water tower and a sewage treatment plant. A help-wanted sign on the edge of the property stays up all the time.After graduation, most of the new officers had two weeks of on-the-job training there. Armed with pepper spray, handcuffs, radios and rubber gloves, they were slowly introduced to the male inmate population by helping do roll calls and random pat-downs of people leaving the chow hall.“The prisoners don’t like us, but it’s bound to be like that anywhere we go,” said Sean Lambert, 20, who’d served in the Army.Tracy Davis didn’t used to give the prison much thought when she drove by it.“There’s people in here with real problems,” she said. “Some of these guys are 6-foot tall, or 7-foot tall.”Taller than her four daughters.“I want to go home at the end of the day, so I am going to treat them with respect if at all possible,” she said. “Then you have to stand your ground, too.”













Badges with names on the back of new correctional officers were ready to hand out during a Missouri Department of Corrections graduation ceremony March 29, 2019, at the Pike County Fairgrounds pavilion near Bowling Green, Mo. Photo by J.B. Forbes, jforbes@post-dispatch.com


J.B. Forbes


That same day, a job fair kicked off under the disco ball over at the Pike County Fairgrounds, where the boot camp was temporarily held. One hundred job seekers signed in to walk the 30 booths.The corrections department had a basket of peppermints set out. One recruiter touted the ease of being a correctional officer, while another hyped the benefits — three weeks of paid vacation and three weeks of paid sick leave earned in the first year of employment; a dozen paid holidays; health, dental and death benefits; and the opportunity to serve in as soon as two weeks.Neal and Chelsea Breting wandered up to the dangling carrot. They were in limbo, staying with family, after a burst pipe damaged their home. Their 20-month-old daughter didn’t like to be set down long. Neal regretted working so many hours previously selling cars. They needed income.“Money is money at this point,” said Chelsea, 22, who applied.As the department was poised to gain an employee, it lost another.Treiber, who had previous jail experience in St. Charles County, quit Thursday, right before the training wheels came off for the rest of her boot camp peers. She said she landed a job closer to home as a police records clerk. It pays $52,000 — a 73 percent bump.

article headline: Better Together lands second big check in push for St. Louis merger
Messenger: 'Unsubstantiated' — the most painful word in military sexual assault complaints
Missouri governor names associate judge to St. Louis circuit judge post
body text:
JEFFERSON CITY • Gov. Mike Parson appointed Calea Stovall-Reid as circuit judge of the 22nd Judicial Circuit in St. Louis Friday.Stovall-Reid, who currently serves as an associate circuit judge in the district, will fill the vacancy created by the appointment of Robin Ransom to the Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District.

Stovall-Reid, of St. Louis, earned an undergraduate degree in communication arts from Howard University and a juris doctorate from the Washington University School of Law. Her past experience has included time as an assistant public defender and as an assistant circuit attorney.
The court conducts more than 300 jury trials a year — more than any other Missouri court — and staffs a juvenile court, a detention facility and operates a drug treatment court for nonviolent offenders.
Stovall-Reid is a member of the Bar Association of Metropolitan St. Louis, the Mound City Bar Association, and a past member of the Women Lawyers’ Association of Greater St. Louis. Her community involvement includes serving as a volunteer child care provider at Almost Home.

article headline: Editorial: Get ready for return of elected-board rule over St. Louis Public Schools
body text:
Missouri’s State Board of Education meets in St. Louis on Monday and Tuesday for a specific purpose: to decide on restoring the elected school board to power. All indications are that approval will be granted, meaning that the Special Administrative Board’s exclusive, 12-year rule will likely end on July 1.The business and political communities around St. Louis are squeamish, including at least two of the three politicians — Gov. Mike Parson, St. Louis Mayor Lyda Krewson and Board of Aldermen President Louis Reed — responsible for nominating SAB members. This newspaper has long expressed its own doubts about the elected board’s ability to maintain the SAB’s steady track record toward improvement and financial stability without reverting to the kinds of infighting, micromanagement and politicking that led to state intervention in 2007.Suffice it to say that skeptics abound, which means the seven-member elected board will have a lot to prove. But the skeptics must face reality: The SAB has completed its assigned mission of restoring the school system to financial health and full accreditation. The justification no longer exists to continue holding the elected board at bay, powerless. It’s time for a handover and restoration of democratic rule.

“I’ve watched the members of this elected board work very hard to prepare,” says SAB president Rick Sullivan. “They are pursuing every type of preparation they can.”
It’s clear from the elected board’s composition, especially with the addition of newly elected members Tracee Miller and Adam Layne, that the teacher’s union and national organization Teach for America will wield heavy political influence over decision-making. If past is prologue, St. Louisans should expect a return of backroom wheeling and dealing by major contractors and lobbyists.The district still struggles with high teacher turnover. Most students still fail state tests. Enrollment continues to drop. But the elected board has undergone months of intensive training with the Missouri School Board Association to learn how to cope with such challenges.
Superintendent Kelvin Adams has brought progress in large part because of his collaborative working relationship with the three-member SAB. Collaboration could easily turn to confrontation with politicians now overseeing him. St. Louis parents and voters must not allow the elected board to chase Adams away with meddling and micromanaging tendencies. Leaders of his caliber will not come to St. Louis if it regains a reputation as a superintendent’s hellhole.The elected board must accept that it will be operating under a microscope of intense skepticism and scrutiny. The board deserves a chance to prove itself, but the public must not let down its guard. Elected members will have to earn the public’s respect, which will come only through good governance, sound financial management and political restraint — and always with the singular goal of building solid futures for the system’s 21,000 students.

article headline: Missouri Senate reaches 'breakthrough' agreement on road and bridge repairs
Editorial: What's really more important — tourism dollars or education?
body text:
In yet another nose-thumbing gesture minimizing the importance of public education, Republican Rep. Jeff Knight has convinced the Missouri House that tourism dollars are what really matters when it comes to teaching kids in classrooms. The House has narrowly approved a bill limiting the starting date for classes to no earlier than 14 days before the first Monday in September.Knight, of Lebanon, is worried that an earlier start for classes would negatively affect Missouri tourism and the dollars it brings in for entertainment venues, hotels, restaurants and resorts. The fear is that if parents are concerned about getting their kids back home in time for a mid-August start of classes, they would likely be more inclined to limit their vacation plans. Businesses that cater to vacationers could see their profit margins decline as a result.

Well, that’s just terrible. But more terrible is the fact that Knight gives higher priority to those business profits than to the kind of educational rigor that helps boost student performance levels to meet Gov. Mike Parson’s priority of developing a skilled Missouri workforce. Extra terrible is that Knight convinced his colleagues to advance his bill, H.B. 161, to the Senate, where hopefully it will be received with a healthy dose of skepticism.The bill would not take effect until the 2020-21 school year. In 2020, 14 days before the first Monday in September would mean classes could not start until Aug. 24. That would be a full seven school days later than the scheduled start of public school classes in St. Louis this year, on Aug. 13. If school boards decide they still need those extra days in August, the bill would require them to hold a public meeting and board vote beforehand.

Sadly, Knight’s bill has less to do with education than with tourism profits. As the Post-Dispatch’s Kurt Erickson reported, Knight’s bill was supported by amusement park operators and lobbying groups for hotel and outdoor recreation operators.Yes, tourism is important. And yes, there is a therapeutic benefit to giving kids a long summer break from the rigors of academia. But Knight misses the point. By law, Missouri public schools must be in session for a minimum of 1,044 hours each year, which typically requires about 174 days of classroom instruction. When inclement weather forces school closures, missed days must be made up. If Knight’s bill succeeded in delaying the start of classes in August, the result would be shorter Christmas vacations and more days added at the start of summer vacation to comply with minimum requirements.Republicans who so strenuously tout the merits of school choice should take a moment to study the academic calendars of the state’s highest-performing charter schools. Those programs place strong emphasis on shorter summer breaks to keep students focused on what really matters: education.

Man killed in shooting that prompted St. Louis alderman's call for National Guard help in city is identified
body text:
UPDATED at 5:45 p.m. Tuesday with the identity of the shooting victim.ST. LOUIS • A man who died after being shot in the face twice Saturday afternoon was identified by police on Tuesday.Leon Smith II, 33, was shot about 3:35 p.m. Saturday after a confrontation in an alley that started when the shooter wouldn’t move his car, police said. The alley is near the 3900 block of North 20th Street, police said.

Police found Smith, who lived nearby in the 3800 block of North Florissant Avenue, in the alley next to his vehicle. He was taken to a hospital, where he was pronounced dead.The shooting prompted Alderman Brandon Bosley of the 3rd Ward to call for the Missouri National Guard to be sent to St. Louis.














        
            Could National Guard help end violence in St. Louis? Alderman calls for help after daytime shooting



“I’m done waiting,” Bosley said. “Before it gets too bad, we need to do something measurable. Extra hands. Extra guns. Guns bigger than the ones on the street.”On Monday, a spokesman for Gov. Mike Parson issued a statement in response to the call.“It’s certainly sad anytime someone is tragically affected by crime,” Steele Shippy, Parson’s communications director, said in a statement. “While we understand the challenges, we are committed to working with local officials and jurisdictions all across Missouri on practical solutions to reduce crime.”
Police Lt. Ken Lammert said a man in a silver SUV later identified as Smith was driving down an alleyway but had to stop when he saw a black SUV blocking the alley exit. Smith honked, then yelled out his window, asking the man if he was going to move his vehicle.The man declined, and both men got out of their vehicles. Lammert didn’t know exactly what happened next, but the man in the black vehicle soon fired six or seven shots through the front of Smith’s SUV, striking the Smith two or three times, Lammert said. The gunman sped off. The address is in the Hyde Park neighborhood.

Could National Guard help end violence in St. Louis? Alderman calls for help after daytime shooting
body text:
ST. LOUIS • A man was shot in the face twice and left on the edge of death Saturday afternoon after an alleyway confrontation that started when the shooter wouldn’t move his car, police said.The boldness of the crime, on a sunny spring day as sports fans flocked downtown, just three miles south, led the neighborhood’s alderman to call for deployment of the Missouri National Guard before the summer hits and crime spikes.“I’m done waiting,” said Alderman Brandon Bosley of the 3rd Ward. “Before it gets too bad, we need to do something measurable. Extra hands. Extra guns. Guns bigger than the ones on the street.”















St. Louis Alderman Brandon Bosley, Ward 3, shares his disapproval of Better Together's plan to merge St. Louis County and city at a town hall meeting hosted by Senator Jamilah Nasheed on Feb. 11, 2019, at the Emerson Performance Center at Harris-Stowe State University. Photo by Laurie Skrivan, lskrivan@post-dispatch.com


Bosley said he and the city Board of Aldermen’s black caucus had been talking for weeks about petitioning Gov. Mike Parson. He said he hoped to persuade the board to pass a resolution calling on Parson to send troops to the worst city neighborhoods.“We’re going to have tanks on every damn corner,” Bosley said. “These people have to know we’re not playing anymore.”The call for state help would not be entirely without precedent. Then-Gov. Jay Nixon declared a state of emergency in 2014 and activated the Missouri National Guard in anticipation of a grand jury announcement regarding the fatal shooting in Ferguson of 18-year-old Michael Brown.And then-Gov. Eric Greitens, in 2017, sent the Missouri Highway Patrol to police St. Louis interstates, hoping to free city officers to focus on troubled neighborhoods. At times, troopers even backed up city police on calls.Still, the deployment of Guard troops for the day-to-day policing of city streets in St. Louis would be very unusual, if not unprecedented.Parson could not immediately be reached for comment.St. Louis Mayor Lyda Krewson declined to address Bosley’s plea. But she called the shooting tragic and said she was sad for the victim and his family.
“Guns are too often used to settle differences,” Krewson said in a statement.Police were called to the Saturday shooting just after 3:30 p.m.Police Lt. Ken Lammert said a man in a silver SUV was driving down an alleyway between North Florissant Avenue and the 3900 block of North 21st Street, but had to stop when he saw a black car blocking the alley exit.
The SUV driver, whom police did not identify, honked, then yelled out his window, asking the man if he was going to move his vehicle.The man declined, and both men got out of their cars. Lammert didn’t know exactly what happened next, but the man in the black vehicle soon fired six or seven shots through the front of the victim's SUV, Lammert said, striking the victim two or three times. The gunman sped away north on 21st.The address is in the Hyde Park neighborhood.The SUV driver was alive when he was loaded into the ambulance, Lammert said, but just barely. The man later died.A neighbor, Donald Kenny, 50, said he saw a black Audi with tinted windows drive away.“All they do is shoot,” Kenny said. “You can’t even go take your trash out without thinking about getting shot.”• Get crime reports for the St. Louis region• Map: St. Louis-area homicides in 2019

Out with the old: St. Charles, East St. Louis and Fenton all dump their mayors
body text:
Voters in two cities on opposite ends of the metro area — St. Charles and East St. Louis — dumped their mayors Tuesday.In St. Charles, retired business executive Dan Borgmeyer defeated two-term Mayor Sally Faith with more than 55 percent of the vote.In East St. Louis, City Councilman Robert Eastern III, 48, beat 44-year-old incumbent Emeka Jackson-Hicks, 49.7 percent to 31.9 percent.

Trailing in the four-way race were former Mayor Carl Officer and Darnell Thompson, with 16.7 percent and 1.7 percent, respectively.In other mayoral races across the metro area:• Florissant Police Chief Tim Lowery was elected mayor of his north St. Louis County city, rolling up more than three-fourths of the vote over opponent Robert Parson Jr.• Write-in candidate Buddy Russell was overwhelmingly chosen Tuesday as the next mayor of Hillsboro.Russell, a retired welder and community volunteer, mustered 71 percent of the vote; Marcy Wokurka got 18 percent; and former Mayor Dennis Bradley received 9 percent."As a write-in, I had to hit the road and knock on people's doors to have a chance," Russell said Tuesday night.He said voters were receptive to his pledge "to bring back respect to the city" after a year of political turmoil, which featured Bradley and another mayor resigning and a probe of the city's police department.• Alderman Bob Brasses toppled Fenton Mayor Josh Voyles. Brasses had criticized Voyles for allegedly misleading police investigating a hit-and-run he later admitted to. Voyles, who has apologized, wasn’t charged in the case.• Former Democratic state Rep. Tommie Pierson Sr., was chosen over two opponents as the next mayor of Bellefontaine Neighbors, succeeding the retiring incumbent.But another former Democratic state lawmaker, John Bowman, lost his bid to become mayor of Northwoods, losing to 16-year incumbent Everett Thomas. Bowman finished third, with Alderman Marvalda Jones coming in second.• Norman McCourt of Black Jack and Michael George Corcoran of St. Ann were among the incumbent mayors re-elected Tuesday. McCourt has held the office since 1998 and Corcoran has been mayor since 2011.Among other area mayors re-elected in contested races Tuesday were John Miller of Collinsville, Yolanda Austin of Jennings, Terry Epps of Pine Lawn and Mark Chamberlain of Charlack.• In the Frontenac mayoral race, final unofficial returns showed Kate Hatfield, a health care administrator, beating former Alderman Mike Schoedel by only five votes out of 880 cast. The incumbent didn't seek another term.But that wasn't as close as Wildwood's 1st Ward City Council race between Larry Brost and David Hudson. That ended in a tie, 286 to 286, according to final unofficial returns.Eric Fey, a St. Louis County Election Board official, said the result potentially could change if any military or other overseas ballots cast by a Ward 1 resident postmarked by Tuesday arrive in the mail in the next few days.But if the totals stay the same in the official certified count, Fey said, state law says the candidates can either get a runoff election or decide the outcome by a coin flip or a similar method.
In St. Charles, Borgmeyer, the retired head of a marketing company, and Faith, the mayor, had argued in their campaign over whether the city was on the right track in economic development.Borgmeyer, 72, had complained that St. Charles has fallen behind nearby cities such as St. Peters and O’Fallon in attracting jobs-producing development and that he would be more aggressive in that regard.Faith, 73, disputed that and pointed to projects such as the Streets of St. Charles mixed-use development and the planned expansion of the St. Charles Convention Center.In Florissant, Lowery, 54, is following the career path of his late father, Robert Lowery, who was the city’s police chief for 22 years and mayor for 10.His opponent, Councilman Robert Parson Jr., 48, was attempting to become the city’s first African-American mayor.
Lowery had a huge campaign fundraising lead, pulling in more than $115,000. Parson’s total was less than $9,000. Lowery also had the support of incumbent Mayor Tom Schneider, who didn’t seek another term.Lowery said he’d try to attract more businesses and young families to the city and ask the City Council to make the Florissant’s part-time economic development director full-time.Parson had said his council experience and work as a lawyer is more conducive to being an elected official than Lowery’s police background.Florissant write-inA write-in campaign to elect Mary Elizabeth Dorsey as the new municipal judge in Florissant appears to have succeeded.Final unofficial returns show 4,142 write-in votes were cast for judge in Florissant, more than twice the number received by incumbent Daniel Boyle.But Election Board officials said they won't know for sure how many of those actually listed Dorsey's name until each ballot is individually reviewed — a process that could take at least a week.Boyle, the only candidate listed on the ballot, decided to move to Oklahoma after the deadline for withdrawing from the race and endorsed Dorsey, an assistant city prosecutor, to succeed him.

article headline: Missouri auditor says Parson administration illegally changed tax withholding tables this year
Governor fills post of St. Louis County judge who was ousted by voters
body text:
JEFFERSON CITY • Gov. Mike Parson filled a vacant seat on the St. Louis County bench Tuesday, selecting a state labor attorney for the post.Virginia Lay will take over as associate circuit judge for the 21st Circuit from Judge Judy Draper, who was ousted from the position by voters in November.Lay, a Clayton resident, is an attorney for the Missouri Division of Employment Security as well as an adjunct professor at Washington University School of Law. She earned a bachelor’s degree in English and American Studies from Columbia University and a Juris Doctor degree from Washington University School of Law.  

During her tenure with the state, Lay has represented agencies like the Missouri Highway Patrol and the Department of Corrections in cases ranging from false imprisonment to excessive force claims.
Draper failed to receive enough votes to stay on the job, becoming only the fourth Missouri judge since 1940 to have been removed by voters. The last time it happened was in 2016 when nearly 60 percent of voters said St. Louis County Associate Circuit Judge Dale Hood should not be retained.













St. Louis County Associate Circuit Judge Judy Draper



Missouri judges are evaluated by a 20-member judicial performance committee. The committee voted in 2010 that she should not be retained, but in 2014 and 2018 voted that she should be. Editorial: Serious or not, bill to invalidate federal gun laws in Missouri is repugnant
body text:
Just when you thought the Missouri Legislature couldn’t get any loopier on guns after recent proposals to require firearms ownership, here comes more crazy. A new measure seeks to declare all federal gun laws “null and void” within Missouri’s borders.Such a measure will never take force for multiple reasons — not least of which is that its underlying premise that states’ rights supersede federal statutes was conclusively rejected long ago, at places with names like Appomattox and Gettysburg. Whatever message the legislation might be intended to send, the message America is getting is that there must be something in Missouri’s water.An earlier move to require gun ownership was in the form of two bills by state Rep. Andrew McDaniel, R-Deering: one to mandate any adult legally allowed to own a firearm do so, and the other to mandate that young adults buy AR-15 semi-automatic rifles — with the help of a state tax credit.

It’s unclear if state Sen. Eric Burlison, R-Springfield, is serious about his legislation to declare Missouri unbeholden to the gun laws of the United States — what inadequate few there are. Since a serious play for legislation like that would be both legally indefensible and philosophically repugnant, perhaps he should be given the benefit of the doubt with an assumption this is just another soapbox bill.Come to think of it, it’s still pretty repugnant, in light of the tens of thousands of gun deaths America endures annually.
Among the federal gun restrictions Burlison’s “Second Amendment Protection Act” would in theory set aside are background checks on gun sales through federally licensed dealers, as well as federal restrictions on the manufacture and civilian ownership of fully automatic weapons.
Polls show vast majorities of Americans (including Missourians) favor tougher background checks, not their elimination. Background checks are a last line of defense to keep guns out of the hands of criminals and people who are too mentally unstable to have them.And does Burlison think machine guns on the streets would make Missourians feel safer? It didn’t work so well on the streets of Chicago in the 1930s.Missouri’s Republican-controlled Legislature went down this rabbit hole before, in 2014, perhaps secure in the knowledge that then-Gov. Jay Nixon, a Democrat, would veto it. Current Gov. Mike Parson has displayed a more level-headed attitude than many of his fellow Republicans. But if this bill gets to him, who knows?No federal judge in the country would — or should — let such a measure stand; there isn’t a realistic danger of Missouri becoming the next Fort Sumter. But these kinds of ideological games by Second Amendment extremists contribute nothing good to the urgent national conversation America is trying to have about the crisis of gun violence. And it certainly does nothing good for Missouri’s reputation.

Editorial: Legislature conjures magic money to fund a make-believe 2020 budget
body text:
This week, lawmakers waved their magic wand, reached into their hat and, once again, pulled out a dead rabbit. The $30 billion preliminary spending plan for the 2020 fiscal year, approved by House members Tuesday, is legislative sleight of hand to disguise the $353 million shortfall resulting from previous, misguided tax cuts.The state cannot produce the revenues it needs for its most urgent priorities because lawmakers, blinded by tax-cut mania, reject the concepts of simple math. Even when State Auditor Nicole Galloway did the math for them last year, warning that their tax cuts would yield billions of dollars in future shortfalls, they proceeded anyway.

Sadly, we know where this will lead because we’ve seen it before. Instead of restoring a sensible tax base and imposing gasoline taxes to fund much-needed highway and bridge repairs, lawmakers ultimately will try to balance the budget by cutting programs that help the state’s neediest and most vulnerable.This disastrous magic act has been assisted by former Gov. Eric Greitens and his successor, Mike Parson. On his last day in office, Greitens signed a bill to cut the state’s corporate tax rate from 6.25 percent to 4 percent. Shortly after assuming office, Parson signed another bill cutting individual income taxes from 5.8 percent to 5.4 percent.

“Reducing taxes is beneficial to Missouri families and will play a vital role in our state to restoring our economy,” Parson said as he signed that bill. The idea was that tax cuts would spur consumer spending and business investment, leading to higher employment and an aggregate increase in revenue. The actual result after more than two dozen tax cuts since 2014, however, is that Missouri’s revenue collections are down by 5.3 percent from this time last year.The irony in this scenario is that Parson has actually set some admirable goals for infrastructure improvements and workforce development. But those are expensive endeavors, and the money isn’t there to pay for them. The Legislature has always had the power to increase gasoline taxes to fund much-needed highway and bridge repairs, but Republicans won’t allow it. So the infrastructure deterioration deepens. Lawmakers won’t even let Parson fund his bridge projects by borrowing the $350 million he needs.Stay tuned for the Legislature’s next magic act, in which they wave a wand to balance the budget by underfunding public defenders’ offices, school transportation and vital social programs that help drug addicts recover or poor people house and feed their children. That’s the old razzle-dazzle.

Judges would have more flexibility on prison terms under plan Missouri lawmakers are studying
body text:
JEFFERSON CITY • In the latest bid to overhaul Missouri’s criminal justice system, a Senate panel voted unanimously Monday to give judges more flexibility when they are sentencing people to prison.The legislation, which now heads to the full Senate, would make minimum prison terms discretionary for offenses that do not involve the use of force or result in serious physical injury. Also exempted are crimes of sexual conduct against a child and offenses that include the use of a firearm.The action came against the backdrop of a visit to the Capitol Monday by Matthew Charles, a former federal prison inmate who was released in January following the approval of a criminal justice reform effort signed by President Donald Trump in December.

Charles, who was Trump’s State of the Union guest, is traveling across the country urging lawmakers to support sentencing and prison reforms.“This mass incarceration or long, extensive sentences need to be changed because it’s not actually thwarting people from committing crime,” Charles said at a press conference.Senate Bill 8, sponsored by Sen. Ed Emery, R-Lamar, is similar to a House bill also working its way through the Legislature.The Missouri Department of Corrections estimates the changes would reduce the prison population by 466 inmates by 2023, saving the state an estimated $3 million.The state has already seen a drop of about 2,000 inmates from a high of more than 33,000 last year, which is allowing Gov. Mike Parson to close the Crossroads Correctional Center in Cameron, Mo.The change in sentencing laws is among a number of criminal justice reform efforts that have won support from Republicans and Democrats in the first half of the Legislature’s annual session.Rep. Shamed Dogan, R-Ballwin, announced Monday he would introduce a package of legislation later this week that would include a number of changes to the state’s criminal code in an effort to lessen the number of people in prison and ease the way for ex-offenders to get jobs and stay out of prison in the future.
“We’re locking up the wrong people and for too long,” Dogan said.The package will include legislation sponsored by Rep. Justin Hill, R-Lake Saint Louis, designed to reduce the incentive for private probation companies to drug test defendants charged with misdemeanors that have nothing to do with alcohol or drugs.
Also included is a bill co-sponsored by Rep. Bruce DeGroot, R-Chesterfield, that eliminates jail time as a penalty for failure to pay a county jail board bill.Democrats are tracking the legislation, but were hoping the various proposals would have been further along in the legislative process.“We are definitely in support of some of the measures that are going through,” House Minority Leader Crystal Quade, D-Springfield, said Monday.But, she added, “I was hopeful that we’d have things going through faster.”Dogan said combining various reforms into one bill could get the changes over the finish line before lawmakers adjourn for the year in mid-May.Charles, 52, was released from a Kentucky jail after Trump signed a new law in December designed to reduce recidivism among federal prisoners.Charles was sentenced to 35 years in prison for selling crack cocaine in 1996. He served for more than two decades without facing any disciplinary action while also taking college courses.

Missouri governor visits three state prisons to promote pay raise plan
body text:
JEFFERSON CITY • Armed with the promise of a long-sought pay raise for Missouri prison workers, Gov. Mike Parson visited three of the state’s 21 lock-ups Friday.Parson, a Republican, made stops at facilities in Farmington, Bonne Terre and Charleston, where workers at the state’s largest agency could see raises of as much as 13 percent depending on how long they’ve worked for the Missouri Department of Corrections.The money is included in the House version of the proposed state budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1. The estimated $8.3 million cost comes on top of $1,050 raises that went into effect last year in an attempt to slow the high rate of turnover in the agency.

“The governor continues to work to boost staff morale,” Parson spokesman Steele Shippy told the Post-Dispatch on Friday.In January, the Parson administration announced plans to consolidate Crossroads Correctional Center and Western Missouri Correctional Center, both in Cameron, and use the savings to give raises to most of the 11,000 workers at the department.Employees in the agency are among the lowest paid in the nation, with correctional officer salaries starting at $28,000 and topping out at $44,476.The pay rate has hampered the department’s recruitment and retention of corrections officers. The job vacancy rate peaked in September 2018, when 848 of the 4,733 guard positions were open. The most recent numbers available show turnover rates of over 18 percent.The lack of adequate staffing was partly blamed for conditions that sparked a riot by inmates at the Crossroads facility last year. Inmates were angry about being forced to stay in their cells because of a staffing shortage.On May 12, more than 200 inmates staged a sit-in at the dining hall over reductions in recreation time and other programs. Prison workers were able to convince 131 inmates to end the standoff, but 78 prisoners spent the next six hours rampaging in a central services building.
The Missouri Highway Patrol and local police had to be called in to help quell the disturbance.Once the facility is shuttered, the staff at Crossroads will drop to nine from 386, with the remaining workers maintaining the empty facility. The budget will fall to $310,000 from more than $13 million, according to the budget plan pending in the House.In mid-2017, Missouri had the eighth-highest incarceration rate in the U.S. Officials say recent changes in the criminal code, coupled with criminal justice reform initiatives, have caused the state’s prison population to drop by more than 2,000, placing the department in a position to shutter Crossroads.
“Our efforts to restructure state government is driven by this administration’s dedication to finding efficiencies wherever we can,” Parson said. “While restructuring is important for the people of Missouri, I also want to be very clear that the problem is not our state workforce. As a former law enforcement officer, I understand and appreciate the value and challenges our correctional workers face.”The budget plan backed by Parson, a former Polk County sheriff and state lawmaker, calls for all state workers to receive a 3 percent raise on their current salaries.Under the separate pay raise proposal for Corrections, workers would get the 3 percent boost and then also a 1 percent raise for each of the two years that they have been working, up to 20 years. Someone who is earning $44,000 and has been with the agency for two decades would see his or her salary jump to $49,720.Parson, who was accompanied on his prison tour by Corrections Director Anne Precythe, met with corrections officers, support staff and supervisors, as well as each facility’s administrative team during the tour.“I appreciate Gov. Parson’s vision to restructure state government and his willingness to make the tough decisions necessary to support our team,” Precythe said.

article headline: Editorial: What's the Legislature's rush to redo laws on university sexual assault cases?
body text:
The Missouri Legislature seems suspiciously in a hurry to embed in state law a series of changes to the way universities handle sexual assault cases. Some of the changes would go far beyond those being contemplated by the Trump administration at the federal level. Dark-money influences appear to be behind this effort to rush into law a measure that deserves far more careful consideration and debate.The legislation, House Bill 573 and Senate Bill 259, is opposed by a wide range of private and public universities and colleges in Missouri. A major fear is that the proposed changes would discourage sexual assault victims from coming forward, in part because the bills outline ways accusers can be held financially liable if they fail to prove their cases.The bills also could escalate legal confusion if they conflict with new Title IX guidelines under review by U.S. Education Secretary Betsy DeVos. Title IX outlaws gender discrimination at educational institutions that receive federal assistance. The Obama administration tightened Title IX requirements in 2011 to encourage sexual assault victims to come forward, but the changes are under attack for circumventing due process. There is some justification for those complaints, which is why DeVos’ review is necessary to ensure victims as well as the accused receive fair treatment.

The Missouri Legislature doesn’t want to wait for DeVos to finish the job. What’s the hurry?Universities have long held autonomous status in America, relying on campus police and private disciplinary processes to investigate and adjudicate cases involving students. Many universities allow student-faculty disciplinary councils to adjudicate even rape cases. Serious criminal offenses belong in the hands of police and skilled prosecutors, not student-faculty panels.
Laws should direct universities to encourage victims of serious criminal cases, first and foremost, to go to the police. Students should be warned that it can be invasive. “The rape victim is always on trial. What she has to go through is horrific at times,” says Joe Bednar, a former sexual assault prosecutor in Jackson County. There’s always a careful balancing act between securing justice and protecting the victim’s privacy.
University motives are always in question. Do they seek to keep serious cases “in house” to avoid news coverage when an athlete, faculty member or major donor is involved? A common complaint involving campus disciplinary panels is that there is too often a rush to judgment because of a lower standard of proof than what applies in criminal court proceedings.There are no easy answers here. Missouri lawmakers, however, suggest there are, and they want to rush their flawed solutions into law even before the new federal Title IX guidelines are announced.None of this reckless approach makes sense. If legislative leaders won’t put a stop to these bills, Gov. Mike Parson should intervene with a veto.

Editorial: Making the case for clemency for Renae Greene
body text:
No one was physically hurt when Renae Greene held up a Joplin pharmacy in 1989. Yet, Greene has spent as much time in prison as a woman incarcerated for first-degree murder — 28 years. She is effectively serving a life sentence for a crime that didn’t deserve such a harsh punishment.In reviewing Greene’s case, Gov. Mike Parson might not walk away feeling warm and fuzzy about her. She was no angel. She did the kinds of reckless and dangerous things drug addicts are prone to do. But more than enough time has passed in which she has been able to prove her rehabilitation.Greene is in her mid-60s. At the time of the robbery, she was 32 and had been addicted to drugs since her teens. She entered a Medicine Shoppe pharmacy operated by David and Sheree Starrett with a gun and demanded “green alcohol.” Greene ordered the Starretts to lie on the floor. She fired shots near their heads and demanded Dilaudid, synthetic morphine.

David Starrett gave Greene 50 tablets of Dilaudid. She fired another shot into the ceiling of the pharmacy before leaving through the front door. The Starretts remembered the day well and, as of a 2014 report in The Joplin Globe, opposed clemency, which is understandable for people who experienced what they did.Greene was tried three times because of errors made by attorneys. She was eventually convicted, receiving a 30-year sentence for pharmacy robbery and a life sentence for armed criminal action. Her clemency petition notes that in Missouri the average sentence for an offender convicted of first-degree robbery, which accounts for use of a firearm during the crime, is 17.9 years. So why such a disproportionate and harsh sentence for Greene?
Her early family life put her on a predictable path. She ran away from home at age 13. Prostitution followed. After becoming addicted to drugs and alcohol, she forged checks and was convicted of carrying a concealed weapon.
In prison, she finally got sober and attended years of Alcoholics Anonymous meetings. She also completed an Impact of Crime on Victims class and accepts responsibility for the pain and suffering she caused others by her actions.Greene will be eligible for parole in 2029, when she will be 74. A life sentence seems overly harsh for a crime in which the victims were certainly terrorized with fear at the hands of a drug addict — but no one was physically injured. She has been rehabilitated by addressing the root cause of her criminal behavior — addictions that caused her life to spiral out of control.Greene deserves to have her case reviewed with an eye toward commutation. She didn’t physically harm anyone, yet she is paying a far greater debt than others who have.

Editorial: Legislators approve harsh anti-abortion measure, inconsistencies be damned
body text:
Missouri’s Republican state legislators are betting the conservative shift on the U.S. Supreme Court will usher in a new era of abortion restrictions and eventually an outright revocation of a woman’s right to chose. Never mind that their devotion to the rights of fetuses stands in stark contrast to their absence of concern for children and mothers beyond the womb.State legislators have passed a “heartbeat” bill, House Bill 126, that would ban an abortion as soon as a fetal heartbeat can be heard, typically around eight weeks. It would effectively criminalize most abortions in the state.The law would become one of the most restrictive in the country if the GOP-controlled Senate advances it. The bill includes provisions declaring “that God is the author of life,” requires that both parents be notified before a minor can receive an abortion; bans abortions on the basis of race, sex or whether the baby has Down syndrome, and establishes a so-called “trigger clause” that would completely ban abortion, except in cases of medical emergency, if the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade.

This bill doesn’t even offer an abortion exception for cases of rape or incest.Sen. Jamilah Nasheed, D-St. Louis, pledges to filibuster this effort to deny women the fundamental right to make their own medical decisions and to jeopardize the health and welfare of abuse victims.
A familiar name is behind this measure: Rep. Nick Schroer, R-O’Fallon, who also has sponsored bills to restrict public access to government information, including information covered under the Clean Missouri amendment approved by voters in November.
He and other zealots in the Legislature are clearly out of touch with a substantial number of, if not most, Missourians. In a 2014 Pew survey, 45 percent of Missouri respondents said abortion should be legal in all or most cases. The state’s lawmakers want to impose their religious and personal beliefs about the most intimate of medical decisions a woman can make.The religious right’s self-proclaimed devotion to the unborn would ring more true if these same legislators didn’t consistently disregard people’s access to health care and food benefits for the poor — often critical to keeping people alive. In Missouri, the number of children without health care coverage rose from 71,000 in 2016 to 75,000 in 2017, up about 5.6 percent. Gov. Mike Parson, touting legislators’ “bold stand” for life, is the same man who earlier this year vowed to cut health care spending for the poor.Legislators voted down a proposal last year to have a committee study the factors contributing to the shockingly high number of deaths of mothers during pregnancy and childbirth. Missouri has one of the highest maternal death rates in the country. But those aren’t the lives our state’s lawmakers are rabidly focused on saving.

Hiring people with disabilities is a win for all
body text:
The largest untapped workforce in our booming economy is made up of people with disabilities. As a premier provider for people with intellectual and developmental disabilities, St. Louis Arc is pleased to see the progress in inclusive hiring that is happening in the St. Louis region and across Missouri. We applaud Gov. Mike Parson’s effort through the Employment First initiative to advocate for additional funding to support employer growth and successful employment of people with disabilities. And while we are on track to becoming a model employer state for individuals with disabilities, there is still much more to be done to ensure that people with disabilities have services to help them gain meaningful, independent employment.Partnerships forged among employment service providers, local and state legislators and state funders are paramount to the success of disability employment opportunities and inclusion overall. St. Louis Arc has begun to develop relationships with state Rep. Sarah Unsicker, D-Shrewsbury; St. Louis Alderman Christine Ingrassia; and St. Louis County Councilwoman Lisa Clancy to help move forward bills and resolutions that address inclusion and employment at the local level. We are encouraged that more people in positions of civic and political leadership recognize the need for inclusion and employment support for those with disabilities.Even with support and new initiatives, the message of hiring people with disabilities only truly works when we get buy-in from employers, even if it is one employer at a time. It’s only when employers see the benefits that a person with a disability can bring to their business that true success can take place for the employer and the employee. Employers tapping into the disability workforce have already recognized many benefits, including lower turnover rates, increased productivity, employer brand enhancement and the financial benefit of potential tax credits.

As a nonprofit organization, St. Louis Arc empowers people with intellectual and developmental disabilities and their families to lead better lives by providing a lifetime of high-quality services, family support and advocacy. This includes assisting people with finding and retaining meaningful employment and helping employers understand the benefits of hiring someone with a disability.
St. Louis Arc’s employment services team provides skills assessment, job coaching and ongoing retention services to more than 350 people with disabilities annually. We also work with approximately 180 employers throughout the St. Louis area, helping them to develop and maintain inclusive hiring practices. This service is a win-win for everyone involved.Making a good job match is the underlying philosophy of employment success for all people with and without disabilities. Statistically, there are 56 million people in America with disabilities, and 84 percent are unemployed — which makes them the largest untapped pool of talent in the nation. A typical business can slash turnover rates and achieve significant cost savings by taking advantage of this proven dependable workforce. We encourage businesses not to overlook qualified individuals because of perceived limitations.
While some people may see limitations, service providers such as St. Louis Arc see untapped potential and opportunities for growth and inclusion for people with disabilities.Brian Hubler is director of employment and transition services for St. Louis Arc. 10 years. In 2016, was named Missouri Rehabilitation Association’s Administrator of the Year.

article headline: Editorial: Parson and the Legislature should try again to ask voters for a fuel tax hike.
body text:
It’s good that Gov. Mike Parson is proactively addressing Missouri transportation infrastructure issues that are approaching an emergency situation. And his proposal to borrow toward fixing it isn’t intrinsically unreasonable.But he is too quickly ruling out another go at the voters to raise the state’s fuel tax — by far the smartest way to fund this. Parson says voters had spoken “loud and clear” by defeating that idea last year. However, there was nothing “clear” about the muddled ballot measure that failed. Voters should get another shot at doing this right.The fuel tax is the best approach to funding roads because the taxes are paid by those who drive the highways, including out-of-staters passing through. But Missouri last raised its fuel tax, to the current 17 cents a gallon, in 1996. It’s now among the lowest rates in America and far below what’s needed. The state’s highway infrastructure is crumbling under two decades of fiscal neglect.

Much of that system is 50 years beyond its original life expectancy. Almost one in 10 bridges are rated in poor condition. Studies show such infrastructure neglect has had real economic costs, to say nothing of the obvious safety implications.The Legislature tried to address it last year with Proposition D, asking voters to raise the fuel tax by 2.5 cents per year until it hits 27 cents in mid-2022. Despite the overwhelming need for it, and bipartisan promotion from Parson and leading Democrats, voters decisively defeated it.
But as this newspaper and others have argued, that result doesn’t appear to have been a vote against adequately funding roads as much as a reaction to a poorly worded, badly explained ballot measure.
The wording was so convoluted that it made it look as if much of the new money was going to the Missouri Highway Patrol instead of roads. That wasn’t the case — the Highway Patrol was just a funding pass-through — but a reasonable reading of the ballot didn’t make that clear. This likely wasn’t a case of a bad idea or even an unpopular one, just a poorly executed one.Nonetheless, in the wake of that ballot defeat, it would be unacceptable for the Legislature to pass a fuel tax hike now. Lawmakers should have done that first, but that car has left the off-ramp.What they still can do is try again to convince the voters this has to be done, with clear and unmistakable ballot language. Parson’s alternative plan to borrow $350 million to address the problem is already drawing legislative opposition, and in any case wouldn’t provide the continuing revenue stream that’s needed.Voters would do the right thing if they’re given the information in a clear and persuasive way. Parson and the Legislature should get back to the drawing board on this one.

Editorial: Short takes on charity, kindness, meanness and the weirdness of R. Kelly
body text:
Keeping Josiah on the moveThe thief who made off with a 3-year-old’s prosthetic leg deserves all the scorn society can heap on him or her. Chances are, the person had no idea what was inside the backpack that his mother, Brie Rainey, inadvertently left inside her car as she carried her sleeping daughter into their Belleville apartment last week. It was akin to a smash ’n’ grab. But at some point, the thief opened the backpack and realized that it contained a small child’s prosthetic leg. Even for the lowest of lowlifes, that’s the moment when a good conscience is supposed to take over and compel the thief to return the item to its owner.The leg belonged to Rainey’s 3-year-old son, Josiah, who was born with multiple birth defects that included a missing left leg. A $10,000, custom-made prosthetic leg allowed him to walk. Without it, Josiah lost what little mobility he had.

But Shriners Hospitals for Children stepped forward to announce that it would replace the prosthetic. Josiah was measured on Monday, and a new one should arrive shortly. Shriners Hospitals for Children has 22 nonprofit hospitals across the country, many of which provide orthopedic care for children regardless of their ability to pay. Sadly, Shriners hasn’t developed a prosthetic conscience for those sorely in need of one.‘I’m not Lucifer’Grammy-winning artist R. Kelly came unglued in an interview that was slated to air Friday on “CBS This Morning.” The interview was his first since being charged with sexual abuse last month. Kelly also was arrested in Chicago for failing to pay more than $160,000 in child support. So, clearly, there’s a lot weighing on his mind.When interviewer Gayle King attempted to drill down on specifics about the sexual abuse charge, Kelly exploded over all the wild accusations flying his way: “Got little girls trapped in the basement ... helicopters over my house trying to rescue someone that doesn’t need rescuing because they’re not in my house,” he said. “Handcuffing people, starving people. I have a harem, what you call it — a cult. I don’t even really know what a cult is. But I know I don’t have one.”He continued: “Everybody says something bad about me. Nobody said nothin’ good. They was describing Lucifer. I’m not Lucifer. I’m a man. I make mistakes, but I’m not a devil, and by no means am I a monster.”He stood up and began flailing his arms, hovering menacingly over King while shouting toward the camera. King flinched and braced as Kelly appeared to lose control. His publicist intervened. Not exactly the display of calm self-control Kelly’s handlers were hoping for to repair his tattered public image.An easy Medicaid fixMissouri cancels Medicaid coverage when recipients are incarcerated, since their medical needs will be handled by the state. But after they’re free, they have to reapply to get their Medicaid coverage back, with the usual paperwork and long wait times. Inevitably, there’s a gap in their medical coverage.
A bill before the Legislature would change that so Medicaid coverage is suspended but not canceled. Newly released inmates who have mental health issues can wait more than a month during the Medicaid re-enrollment process before they’re again eligible for their medication. For some, it means mental breakdowns that can lead them right back into jail.As the Post-Dispatch’s Blythe Bernhard reported, at least 35 other states already take the cost-free, commonsense approach of suspending rather than canceling inmates’ Medicaid. The Legislature and Gov. Mike Parson should get this change on the books as soon as possible.Bigotry on display
A poster displayed at a Republican Party event in the West Virginia state Capitol featured a picture of the burning World Trade Center interposed with an image of Rep. Ilhan Omar, D-Minn., one of Congress’ first Muslim members. The poster showed the burning towers on the day of the 9/11 attacks, under the words, “‘Never forget,’ you said …” Under that is an image of Omar in her hijab, next to the words: “I am the proof — you have forgotten.”Omar, of course, had nothing to do with the attacks, but this crass display certainly tried to create a fake connection. It’s unclear who brought in the poster, but it was set up at a GOP event. Yet when Democrats in the state’s House of Delegates condemned the poster and its sentiments, Republicans delayed and changed the subject.When Omar made allegedly anti-Semitic remarks recently, there were no delays by congressional Democrats condemning her. Why is it taking Republicans so long to respond when examples like this underscore religious bigotry in their ranks?‘Back to Kenya’Rep. Mark Meadows, R-N.C., reacted with horror and was nearly moved to tears during a high-profile hearing last week when Rep. Rashida Tlaib, D-Mich., implied that a tactic he used was racist. Meadows brought Lynne Patton, an African-American regional director for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, to challenge allegations by President Donald Trump’s former lawyer that Trump was a racist. Patton was appointed by Trump.Tlaib said the use of a black employee at the hearing was a racist act of tokenism. Meadows reacted emotionally to the comment, after which Tlaib clarified she was not calling him a racist. They later hugged it out.But what explains the videos of Meadows, taken while he was campaigning in 2012, in which he made repeated racist tropes about sending President Barack Obama back to Kenya? Obama was born in America.
