article headline: Missouri needs long-term investment to fix its infrastructure
body text:
In response to Gov. Mike Parson’s State of the State address last week, the Kansas City and St. Louis sections of the American Society of Civil Engineers are glad to see infrastructure mentioned as a top priority for our state. We were happy to hear that Gov. Parson highlighted investing in critical infrastructure as one of the priorities to be addressed this legislative session, and one of the major issues he’s looking to tackle as a means of moving Missouri forward.As indicated in the 2018 Report Card for Missouri’s Infrastructure, our roads and bridges need improvement, so it was relieving to hear the governor propose a repair program for 250 bridges. Unfortunately, we have almost 3,200 bridges in the state of Missouri that are structurally deficient, and over $4 billion is needed for repairs and modernization. While not unsafe, structurally deficient bridges require significant maintenance, rehabilitation or replacement of load-carrying elements. In order to remain in service, structurally deficient bridges are often posted with weight limits, which can be an inconvenience as posting can increase commute times for our emergency vehicles and school buses.Many of our roads are also in poor condition, which costs each motorist $604 per year in vehicle operating costs. It was just last year that ASCE released infrastructure grades for Missouri, and our cumulative grade was a C-minus.

In his speech, the governor called for using $350 million in freed-up state and federal resources to repair the estimated 250 smaller bridges across the state. The governor’s proposed infrastructure plan would accelerate MoDOT’s list of larger infrastructure projects. These are steps in the right direction.While Gov. Parson’s plan is promising, he also stated that we need to find creative ways to invest in our infrastructure without a tax increase. Our state’s fuel tax has been frozen at 17 cents per gallon — one of the lowest in the country — since 1996. Imagine trying to live off of your 1996 salary. It wouldn’t go very far. Increasing project construction costs and inflation have reduced the purchasing power of Missouri’s state fuel tax from 17 cents to 8 cents per gallon. With fuel tax being the state’s major source of transportation funding, Missouri’s ability to fund future transportation maintenance and capital projects is in jeopardy.In St. Louis, the city is working hard to position the Gateway to the West as a critical national freight hub. St. Louis has America’s third-largest inland port, four interstates with national access, five airports with capacity and six class I railroads. To capture a share of the 40 percent increase in national freight volume expected over the next 30 years, state legislators must focus on infrastructure improvements that can help ensure our freight network can accommodate future growth.
The St. Louis Regional Freightway has identified critical multimodal projects and is working with its regional partners to accomplish their goals. Those public partners must be ready to contribute their share of funding to improve our public road system. Our freight network is only as strong as its weakest link, and our economy depends on this freight network.Missouri needs an all-hands-on-deck approach that will involve state, local and the federal government. Proposition D, which was rejected last November, would have addressed some of our surface transportation infrastructure challenges. However, the proposition was poorly worded and confusing. It did not clearly state that the funds would be used to fund new roads and bridges. Nevertheless, we cannot let that vote deter us from identifying critical funding for our state’s roads, bridges and transit systems.
In looking to our neighbors, Iowa, Nebraska, Oklahoma and Tennessee have all raised their fuel taxes and Kentucky set a floor, meaning that the impact of a decrease in wholesale gasoline prices on the state’s 9 percent excise tax on motor fuel will be limited. These states are starting to see the benefits of their legislative actions.Let’s put Missouri on equal footing with our neighbors and ensure we remain competitive for businesses and provide a good quality of life for residents. Let’s move forward by enacting funding solutions that provide long-term, sustainable investment to modernize our roads. We need to act now.Sheryl Gallagher is chair of the Report Card for Missouri’s Infrastructure.

article headline: What is Parson doing about plague of gun violence?
body text:
Some time ago at the introduction of his director of public safety, Gov. Mike Parson said:"Probably one of the first things I’ll ask her to do is to be building those relationships to see what those issues are, and see if there’s ways that we can help. I’ve been pretty open all along that I’m a very strong supporter of the Second Amendment, but I also realize at times if there’s ways we can do things better, then I’ll look at that.”

The plain-speaking governor has yet to come back about that statement, not in his State of the State address, and not in response to my phone calls. Just what did he mean? With the plague of gun violence in our major cities and surrounding counties, this concern easily ranks alongside bridges as a top priority.
Does "there's ways we can do things better" mean that he would consider some form of gun control or regulation in conjunction with the Second Amendment and Missouri's own "inalienable right" firearms amendment? Does he recognize that in Missouri there are two fundamentally different gun cultures, rural and urban, yet the rural conservative agenda seems bent on turning our state into an armed camp primed for street justice and class warfare?
One would expect Gov. Parson, a former county sheriff, to be forthcoming about guns and crime.Terry Beckmeyer  •  New Haven

Editorial: Another test of lawmakers' will to clean up Jefferson City
body text:
In case Missouri lawmakers missed the unmistakable walkaway message from the Nov. 6 election, we will restate it clearly for them: Missouri voters want cleaner, more transparent government. They want to put an end to the domination of Jefferson City by special interest groups. They want legislators to be elected based on the power of their ideas, not the microscopic gerrymandering of districts to predetermine their partisan makeup.Hoping to capitalize on overwhelming voter support for the “Clean Missouri” amendment on Nov. 6, state Sen. Scott Sifton, D-Affton, proposes to go one step further by lifting the veil that currently prevents Missourians from knowing the extent to which big donations influence the awarding of major state contracts. The donations Sifton is specifically targeting in his Transparency in Government Contracting Act (Senate Bill 148) are those that go to “dark money” political organizations.Although dark money has had pernicious effects on state and national politics for years, most Missouri voters were probably oblivious to it until Gov. Eric Greitens’ 16-month term in office ended in scandal last year. Millions of dollars in donations from invisible sources poured into Greitens-controlled dark money organizations. The extent of those donations’ influence on his advocacy as governor might never be known because investigations into potential influence-peddling fizzled with his resignation in June 2018.

But that doesn’t mean dark money and pay-to-play governance are gone from Jefferson City. Without legislation to uncloak the legally protected secret-donor web, there’s little to stop lawmakers and state executives from continuing down the corrupt trail Greitens blazed.
“Taxpayers don’t know whether government business is being affected by the corrupting influence of secret, dark money,” Auditor Nicole Galloway said in a statement endorsing Sifton’s bill. “This bill would bring transparency to the contract process by making sure Missourians know when taxpayer dollars are being used in state contracts that go to dark money contributors.”Sifton’s bill would require individuals or entities engaged in contracts worth $5,000 or more to report the political contributions they make to 501(c )(4) dark money organizations. All donations of $500 or more would be covered under his measure, and reporting requirements are retroactive to the 12 months preceding the awarding of the contract. The general public would have access to those reports.
Big donors accustomed to the quid pro quo of donations in exchange for special legislative favors no doubt will hate this bill and expend no small effort to kill it. They reportedly panicked when investigations into Greitens’ fundraising practices threatened to reveal donor identities.If the GOP-dominated Senate and House truly wanted to honor the voters’ call for cleaner, more transparent governance, they’d embrace this bill and quickly send it to Gov. Mike Parson’s desk. But given Clean Missouri’s tepid reception so far in Jefferson City, we won’t be holding our breath.

Editorial: Short takes on blindfold challenges and blinder bigotry
body text:
The Darwin challengeIn the Netflix film “Bird Box,” a mysterious force overtakes Earth, causing masses of people to do suicidal things. The only protection is to wear a blindfold for all outdoor activities — canoeing, driving, shooting guns — because the force enters people’s brains through their visual cortex.So, of course, there’s a new fad called the Bird Box Challenge, in which people around the country are attempting incredibly dangerous things, like driving or giving each other tattoos while blindfolded. It’s almost as if their brains have been seized by a mysterious force that makes them do suicidal things.

The results have been as disastrous as you might expect, including a Utah teenager who crashed her car into another vehicle while driving blindfolded. Netflix felt compelled to issue a plea to all viewers to be careful (translation: Stop being stupid).And that also goes for anyone thinking of a twerking challenge, too. Do not ride atop a car going down an interstate highway (as happened in St. Louis this week) while twerking. Just don't.Good morning, Nashville!President Donald Trump tweeted that he was really excited about his address to farmers during his Monday trip to Nashville. “Love our farmers, love Tennessee — a great combination!” he tweeted. Just one problem: His scheduled speech to the American Farm Bureau’s annual convention that day was in New Orleans.The presidential gaffe couldn’t have come at a worse time for that particular sector of the electorate. Trump is trying to shore up flagging support among farmers after his shutdown sharply curtailed U.S. Department of Agriculture services and forced suspension of payments to farmers under a $12 billion bailout package he arranged after provoking a trade war with China.Previous administrations maintained strict policies requiring multiple layers of review before presidential communications were released to the general public. Under Trump, no one but the president is to blame for his communication screw-ups — or his shutdown.So long, GeorgeA Hawaiian land snail named George died recently at age 14, apparently taking his whole species with him. George was of the species Achatinella apexfulva, which once covered the Hawaiian island of Oahu. He lived in Kailua, Hawaii, in a terrarium. He is believed to have been the last of his kind.Scientists who publicized George’s plight hope it will wake people up to the real-world impact of climate change.Many types of once-plentiful land snails and other species have gone extinct on the Hawaiian islands in recent years, with the effects of climate change among the culprits. For George’s relatives (the ones who didn’t have benefit of an aquarium), the drying of the Hawaiian ecosystem proved too much to handle.
“He’s been a constant for a really long time,” David R. Sischo, who directs the state-run Snail Extinction Prevention Program, told The New York Times. “If anything good comes out of this extinction, it will be the recognition that we have a lot to lose, and we don’t have a lot of time.”The King of bigotryRep. Steve King, the Iowa Republican, has long shown himself to be arguably the most irredeemable bigot in Congress. But a recent interview, in which he expressed genuine befuddlement about what was so wrong with being a “white supremacist,” was too much even for the previous enablers in his party.House Republicans this week stripped King of his committee assignments. Some top GOP leaders have suggested he should resign. In case he doesn’t, efforts are underway to recruit a 2020 primary challenger.This burst of Republican wokeness is welcome — though it’s worth asking what took them so long. This is the same Rep. King who for years has cozied up to Nazi sympathizers and who enthusiastically promoted the racist “birther” movement. He once tweeted, “We can’t restore our civilization with somebody else’s babies.” The list goes on. King's tenure in Congress should not.
What about concealed dogs?New Missouri House rules prohibiting lawmakers from bringing their dogs to work make sense, even though a lot of politicians could use the examples of sincerity and loyalty that dogs provide.The new rule is especially ironic given that, even as officials are barring man’s best friend from the Capitol, they’re considering letting visitors bring in concealed guns.The gun proposal, by Gov. Mike Parson’s administration, has whipped up some strong public opposition that, hopefully, will get him to back off on this plan. Some opponents have said, reasonably, that they won’t let their kids go on field trips to the Capitol if they allow guns in.Staying putMissouri Gov. Mike Parson was right to reject a request to transfer state workers out of a downtown St. Louis office out of concern over crime. Crime is a concern downtown, but the solution — especially for a state government — isn’t to run from it. That would’ve sent a terrible message.As the Post-Dispatch’s Kurt Erickson reported, the Missouri Department of Revenue sought to move seven employees out of the Wainwright State Office Building downtown to an office in Clayton. The reason, said the written request, is that employees are “increasingly concerned about their safety while walking to the parking garage and the MetroLink station.”Parson’s office has effectively said to the employees, “Stay put,” which is exactly right. As the region’s economic engine, where many others work (and live), St. Louis needs the state to set that kind of example. If the city wants to continue counting on that, it would do well to continue working to make downtown safer.

article headline: Missouri wants more time to negotiate agreement on 144-mile Rock Island Trail
After May riots, Missouri to close maximum-security prison
body text:
JEFFERSON CITY • Eight months after hundreds of inmates rampaged through a short-staffed maximum-security prison in northwest Missouri, the facility is being shuttered as part of Gov. Mike Parson’s reshaping of state government.On Friday, the governor and Missouri Department of Corrections Director Anne Precythe said mothballing the 1,440-inmate Crossroads Correctional Center in Cameron will result in no layoffs and could provide savings to pay for long-needed raises for the state’s 11,000 prison workers.“This was all a business decision at the end of the day,” Parson told reporters during a press conference in his office, adding that no other prisons are being eyed for closure.

The decision to close Crossroads is part of Parson’s $30 billion budget proposal, which includes numerous changes to other state agencies in what he calls an attempt to streamline government.Precythe said one factor in deciding to close the prison is a drop in the number of inmates in the 21 prisons across the state. The current population of 30,196 inmates is down from a high of more than 33,000 just a few years ago.The decrease, she said, is partly because of changes to the state’s criminal code that went into effect in 2017, which have led to fewer people being sentenced to prison. The state also has launched a $5 million pilot program  aimed at keeping inmates from returning to prison after they serve their sentences. Parson has earmarked another $1 million for the program in his budget proposal.“We are very confident that we’re going to be able to sustain this new level of population,” Precythe said.The estimated $20.6 million saved from the closure will allow for additional salary increases over the 3 percent that Parson is proposing in his budget. Precythe said correctional officers would receive an additional 1 percent increase for every two years of service in an attempt to reward senior employees.The average salary for prison guards of $31,300 is among the lowest in the nation.The low pay has led to a high turnover rate and was blamed for the riot that occurred in May.
The disturbance started when 209 inmates refused to return to their housing units. They were upset that staffing shortages had left less time for recreation and other programming.In order to keep the facility operating, Corrections’ officials had resorted to busing officers from other prisons.After six hours of unrest, in which dining halls, the kitchen and storage areas sustained an estimated $1.3 million in damage, the prison was brought back under control.Precythe emphasized that Crossroads workers have been offered jobs within the system, which has an estimated 800 openings.
As for the inmates, most will be transferred to the adjacent Western Missouri facility after part of it is upgraded to handle maximum-security inmates. Adding a new security fence around the perimeter will cost at least $3 million.Cameron’s mayor and city manager could not be reached for comment, but Precythe said her staff has received positive reaction from community leaders about the changes.The two state senators who represent the region praised the proposal.“Nobody has to lose their job,” said Sen. Denny Hoskins, R-Warrensburg.“We’ve had a somewhat chronic understaffing problem going on there. Quite obviously it’s a safety concern and a security concern,” added Sen. Dan Hegeman, R-Cosby.While closing a prison is a rarity in Missouri, Illinois has shuttered three in the past six years, including the all women's facility in Dwight, a super maximum-security lock-up in Tamms and a youth prison in Murphysboro.

article headline: Editorial: Parson's infrastructure focus is correct, but debt-funding it is a mistake
body text:
Missouri Gov. Mike Parson will get no argument from us in his call, reiterated Wednesday in his first State of the State speech, for the Legislature to approve funding for workforce development and infrastructure upgrades. Our big problem is with the funding mechanism he proposes, which will send the state deeper into debt.Yes, state voters rejected a ballot item on Nov. 6 that would have raised fuel taxes to pay for highway improvements. But the item was so badly worded it created unnecessary confusion and presented a wedge for its opponents to defeat it. Parson needs to champion a new ballot question that presents the issue clearly.Missouri’s need for an infrastructure overhaul is beyond debate. Some 10 percent of its bridges are rated in poor condition; its road system is aging and inadequate; its unmet transportation needs have been estimated at more than $800 million a year. The state’s 17-cent-per-gallon fuel tax, the main source of road funding, is one of the nation’s lowest. It hasn’t been increased in more than 20 years.

Last year’s Proposition D sought to address that with a good idea wrapped in a terrible presentation. It would have raised the fuel tax by 10 cents a gallon over four years. The measure had strong bipartisan support, including Parson’s backing, but it was hobbled by a complex funding plan that would have funneled some of the money through the State Highway Patrol.It was a bureaucratic workaround that still ended up with most of that money going to roads and bridges — but it didn’t look that way in the ballot language and its supporters failed to adequately explain it. The measure was soundly defeated at the polls, despite indications the public favors the concept of a fuel-tax hike for infrastructure.
It was disappointing that Parson didn’t use Wednesday’s address to make a strong appeal for another go at a fuel-tax ballot measure this year. Instead, he proposes sending the state deeper into debt by borrowing $351 million to pay for improvements.
That would leave the state with less money to cover his other priority goal: workforce development. He wants to fully fund K-12 education, which is great, but the real workforce development opportunities are in higher education, which gets no additional funding. Why? Because there isn’t enough money for it. Why? Because the state needs money for other priorities, including debt service.The Legislature should have raised the fuel tax long ago rather than shirking its duty and forcing a ballot measure, but that car has exited the highway. The voters’ decision, however tainted it was by an incompetent ballot campaign, cannot in good conscience be overturned now by lawmakers.But there’s nothing to stop Parson and other leaders from making the case for another go at the ballot. Raising Missouri’s woefully inadequate fuel tax is still the right way to address our crumbling infrastructure. Sending the state further into debt isn’t.

Editorial: Young futures hang in the balance as Warren County adopts four-day school week
body text:
The Warren County School District is joining about 33 other Missouri districts on a risky experiment with four-day school weeks. Minimal evidence exists to suggest a four-day week improves academic performance, while it could lead to potentially serious social side effects for youths. Are the slight cost savings and potentially higher teacher-retention rates worth it?As the Post-Dispatch’s Christine Byers reported Monday, Warren County’s teacher turnover rates reached 20 percent last school year. The district, about 60 miles west of St. Louis, lacks funding to compete with neighboring districts’ higher salaries, so the gamble is that a shorter workweek would entice teachers to stay.The savings, however, are only about $300,000 a year, or less than 1 percent of the district’s budget. The district plans to add 33 minutes of class time to the remaining four days of school to meet the state minimum of 1,044 hours of instruction. But adding two hours and 12 minutes per week hardly substitutes for the loss of a full, uninterrupted academic day.

Research compiled by Harvard University and the Carnegie-Knight Initiative offers a murky assessment of the cost-benefit of a compressed academic week. Most of the 560 public school districts in the 25 states that adopted shorter weeks are in rural areas.The justification for switching more often leans toward accommodating adults than serving the academic needs of children, research suggested. A 2018 survey of 136 faculty and staff members in three Missouri districts that adopted a four-day week found higher adult morale and what they perceived to be a positive impact on academic quality. Any actual improvement in academic quality is unproven.
One major drawback, according to a 2018 study in Colorado, was that teens tend to have more free, unsupervised time on their hands, yielding a 20 percent increase in juvenile criminal offenses — including a 73 percent increase in property crimes — attributable to the four-day switch.
In New Mexico, consistently among the nation’s lowest in academic proficiency, lawmakers imposed a moratorium on districts switching to a four-day week pending further study of the costs and benefits. Several indicators suggest that poorer students suffer the most from the compressed schedule, although the research to date is hardly comprehensive.To their credit, Warren County officials plan to make adult supervision available for students on Mondays when they don’t have school. Morning and noontime meal service also will be available along with some tutoring.The gamble is significant for what could amount to a minimal payout. But the sad fact that it’s happening reflects increasingly dire economic conditions among Missouri public schools and the low priority state legislators give to funding and resources. Workforce development — one of Gov. Mike Parson’s top priorities — won’t happen unless the Legislature’s mindset changes about the importance of public education.

Editorial: 'Clean Missouri' means what it says, Gov. Parson. Don't mess with it.
body text:
Gov. Mike Parson has made precious few missteps since taking over in June, and this is no time for him to mess up that record. He should rethink his suggestion of legislatively overriding the “Clean Missouri” ballot measure overwhelmingly approved by voters on Nov. 6.The people have spoken, and if Parson or any other politician in Jefferson City proposes to ignore their will, they deserve whatever voter backlash that comes their way. Parson in particular should be mindful of his own short leash. He was not elected to the governor’s office but arrived there only by virtue of his predecessor’s badly skewed moral and ethical compass.Parson promised a return to the straight and narrow path. First and foremost, that means upholding the will of the people. On Nov. 6, they voted overwhelmingly for Constitutional Amendment 1, the Clean Missouri ballot proposition. What Parson and others in the Republican majority don’t like is that Clean Missouri would revoke their party’s ability to gerrymander political districts in ways that effectively predetermine election outcomes and ensure one-party dominance.

Clean Missouri empowers the state demographer to map districts with emphasis on greater partisan fairness and competitiveness. Candidates would be forced not to rely on partisan affiliation as much as the power of their ideas and their ability to sway voters across the political divide.It’s a formula designed to encourage greater centrism, which is the space most Missourians occupy on key social issues. On Nov. 6 ballot items where there was no political party affiliation attached to the issue, voters across the state rejected hard-right extremism, overwhelmingly supporting Clean Missouri, legalization of medical marijuana and a mandatory increase in the state minimum wage to $12 an hour.
Whether Parson or other Republicans don’t like the result isn’t the point. It’s whether they’re willing to respect the democratic process. A slippery slope toward dictatorship awaits anyone who believes in legislatively invalidating elections that don’t go their way.
They are sending ominous signs: “Fundamentally, you think when the people vote you shouldn’t be changing that vote,” Parson told The Associated Press last month. “But the reality of it is that is somewhat what your job is sometimes, if you know something’s unconstitutional, if you know some of it’s not right.”Sen. Dave Schatz, now the Senate president pro tem, agrees: “I think it’s a major concern for this majority, in how that (Clean Missouri) is going to impact the future. And I do think those issues are going to have to be addressed there” with corrective legislative action.Even some Democrats, such as state Rep. Maria Chappelle-Nadal of University City, are expressing discomfort over the demographer’s new powers.All seem united in their dirty desire to protect political fiefdoms over democracy. Missouri voters should let them know, loud and clear, that Clean Missouri means what it says.

article headline: Secretive phone apps installed on state phones during Greitens tenure
HUD Secretary Carson cancels visit to Missouri because of federal shutdown
Lobbyists have gotten away with paying for votes
body text:
It is against the law in all 50 states to pay people for their vote, but for decades in Missouri, some lobbyists have been getting away with exactly that — by giving meals, sports tickets, trips and who knows what else to members of the Legislature in exchange for legislation favorable to their clients.If legislators take a gift from anyone and vote for or against legislation accordingly, they are being paid to vote one way or the other. Obviously then, state Sen. Dave Schatz was wrong when he said that the standard person can’t understand that, because 62 percent of the voters said yes to the "Clean Missouri" amendment, which will prevent that crime from happening all over Jefferson City.

The amendment also changed the process for drawing legislative districts so that it will be more fair and prevent people like Sen. Schatz and Gov. Mike Parson from so easily overturning the will of the people in the future, which is probably why they are trying to do it again now.
As for all the restaurants and places that will lose business by not being able to supply those freebies any longer, I say that if buying legislators' votes is a crime, then they were aiding and abetting those crimes.
The people have spoken, so listen up.Ric Haberstroh  •  Ferguson

article headline: With new leaders in charge, Missouri lawmakers return to action
Political adviser to Eric Greitens exerted authority over state workers, records show
body text:
JEFFERSON CITY • A political consultant from Georgia directed taxpayer-paid employees in Missouri during the early days of then-Gov. Eric Greitens’ doomed administration, according to a Post-Dispatch review of emails generated by the Republican governor’s team.Austin Chambers, now 23, was one of the architects of Greitens’ winning “conservative outsider” strategy in 2016.When Greitens took office in January 2017, Chambers approved policy rollouts, was copied on multiple drafts of Greitens’ first State of the State address, and had access to pending media inquiries, according to the emails.

The records, produced over the last several months to the Missouri attorney general’s office as part of an investigation of Greitens, so far cover a small time period: the post-election transition phase, plus Greitens’ first 3½ weeks in office.But the documents still offer a glimpse into the inner workings of the notoriously opaque administration.The records show that press secretary Parker Briden crafted posts for Greitens’ personal Facebook page, which could constitute a violation of the law because taxpayer resources cannot be expended on political purposes.Production of these records comes at a particularly awkward time for the Missouri attorney general’s office.Former Attorney General Josh Hawley, a Republican who was sworn in Thursday as a U.S. senator, faces an investigation by Secretary of State Jay Ashcroft, a Republican, and state Auditor Nicole Galloway, a Democrat, into whether he broke the law by allowing campaign consultants to direct taxpayer-paid staff.Now, Hawley’s successor, Eric Schmitt, a Republican, possesses evidence showing Greitens’ aides acted in similar ways.Hawley has denied any wrongdoing, arguing it was acceptable for campaign consultants to help with his official duties so long as they were not paid by the state.Schmitt said Wednesday that he would establish a “bright line” dividing his campaign operation from his office’s official duties, and added that he would not comment on any ongoing investigations.Steele Shippy, spokesman for Gov. Mike Parson, a Republican, told the Post-Dispatch that although it is normal for outsiders to offer advice and counsel to the administration, outsiders do not have “sign off” authority on press releases or on other matters.“Sign off does not come from an outside source,” Shippy said.Scott Holste, who worked as a spokesman for then-Gov. Jay Nixon, a Democrat, said Nixon trusted his taxpayer-paid staff to pull the levers of government. Before becoming governor in 2009, Nixon had served 16 years as attorney general.Nixon “had great confidence and trust in them,” Holste said. “Many of them came with him after serving with him for several years.”
In 1993, Missouri Attorney General William L. Webster, a Republican, was sentenced to two years in prison for conspiracy and embezzlement of state resources after an investigation revealed Webster was using state resources for political purposes.As an example of how Chambers directed staff, he signed off on a budget letter that was to be published at the front of an official state manuscript, which detailed Greitens’ plans for the state’s $28 billion annual budget.The letter includes digs at “insiders, special interests, lobbyists, and career politicians” who “have made a mess of our budget.”“Approved,” Chambers wrote on Jan. 27, 2017, after receiving the final draft.Parson’s legal team, responding to an open records request that the attorney general’s office made on May 11, is now producing thousands of records to investigators working for Schmitt.
Hawley, Schmitt’s predecessor, opened the probe when The Kansas City Star raised questions about Briden’s writing posts on Greitens’ Facebook page.Greitens’ administration had denied an open records request seeking information from the account, saying the account was private. Hawley, who enforces the state’s Sunshine Law, sided with Greitens.But when the newspaper pointed to records showing that Facebook messages were crafted by Briden, the attorney general’s office opened an investigation into misuse of official resources.In addition to showing that Briden had a direct hand in posting to Greitens’ social media accounts, emails that the attorney general’s office and the Post-Dispatch obtained suggest that Greitens’ political advisers had wide latitude to engage with taxpayer-paid staff.Mark Bobak, a long-time Greitens confidant, was allowed to park in a parking space at the Capitol reserved for the governor’s staff, according to emails.Campaign treasurer Jeff Stuerman and Greitens fundraiser Meredith Gibbons, who was paid $140,000 by Greitens’ dark-money nonprofit A New Missouri in 2017, also were in contact with state employees.Besides running Greitens’ campaign, Chambers worked for A New Missouri, which took in $6 million in 2017 and has not revealed the source of any of the money.The records show that while Greitens was in Washington for President Donald Trump’s inauguration, he was scheduled to meet briefly with then- Rep. Dana Rohrabacher, R-Calif., who has advocated for warmer relations between the United States and Russia.Monu Joseph, a California venture capitalist, was described as the “on site contact” for the meeting. Joseph is listed as the current president of A New Missouri.One of Greitens’ former campaign aides has testified that Joseph had discussed ways to solicit campaign donations from foreign nationals, which would be a violation of federal law.

article headline: Opponents say guns in the Missouri Capitol 'unnecessary and dangerous'
Democratic, Republican parties drown out independent voices
body text:
Missouri citizens need better government representation. Our Republican and Democratic parties have become the largest and most powerful self-serving corporations in our nation. Too many of their work force, the elected members of their parties, owe allegiance to their leaders' platforms. Their job description includes raising money for their party's war chest, and when it comes time to speak up and vote on issues, they infrequently go against party positions.Today, these two political machines are so wealthy and well-honed that it is almost impossible for an independent candidate to compete against their treasure chests, political district alliances and their highly specialized image marketing teams. If a person wants to get elected, he or she is highly encouraged to give allegiance to the Democratic or Republican "corporations."

Dissatisfied with this predicament, the public has discovered new success via the citizen initiative petition. Now that these citizen initiatives are beginning to infringe upon party turf, Missouri Gov. Mike Parson intends to make it harder for citizen initiatives to make it to the ballot. Further, he intends to rewrite the recent "Clean Missouri" citizen initiative state amendment to be more what he wants, not what the voters approved.
Our leaders have already rewritten past successful citizen initiatives regarding puppy mills and handguns. Gov. Parson has lost the spirit of government by the people and for the people. If we do nothing, he will make citizen initiative petitions harder to institute, rewrite ones that do pass and continue gerrymandering to his "corporation's" advantage. This is outright tyranny of the people's representation. We need independent voices.
John and Stephanie Burns  •  Kirkwood

article headline: Move to stack clean water panel with farm-friendly allies wins round in court
Missouri gets a new attorney general, officials hope for calm
Opioids in Missouri: Taking on a massive public health crisis
body text:
In 2016, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported that 67,265 Americans died from drug-induced causes, six times the number of people that died from gun violence in the same year. The opioid crisis also creates a significant economic hindrance. In Missouri alone, opioid use disorder and overdose deaths cost the state $34.5 million each day — or $12.6 billion per year. This was 4.2 percent of the state’s GDP in 2016.There are steps being taken to combat this public health epidemic. At a forum Dec. 6, Gov. Mike Parson, along with St. Louis Mayor Lyda Krewson, proposed a statewide prescription drug monitoring program through a database that tracks controlled substance prescriptions. We are currently the only state in the U.S. without one despite the CDC’s belief that they are “among the most promising state-level interventions to improve opioid prescribing, inform clinical practice, and protect patients at risk.”I commend the governor and Mayor Krewson, and am in full support of their proposal. Additionally, I hope we can take our efforts a few steps further. A problem of this magnitude requires a diversity of solutions, and taking on such a massive public health crisis requires a deep and intimate knowledge of opioid use, misuse and abuse across Missouri.

Indiana has recognized the need for a more robust understanding of this issue. In response, they have implemented a tool that makes law enforcement and the public more equipped to defeat the scourge of overdose deaths in their state. The Naloxone Administration Heat Map is a visual database that allows anyone to see exactly where first responders are administering naloxone in Indiana. Naloxone, or Narcan, is a medication that reverses the effects of an opioid overdose without any tangible side effects, increasing the amount of lives saved.I believe Missouri needs to implement our own statewide, easily accessible Naloxone Heat Map. If we were to do so, we would accomplish a few important goals, and move closer to significantly decrease the lives damaged by opioid narcotics.This step would ensure that our state can properly allocate life-saving resources to the areas where they are needed most. This way, first responders in areas with the highest levels of risk could go into each 911 call ready for anything. There is a common misconception that one dose of Narcan is sufficient in each case. In fact, first responders can sometimes administer many doses, depending on the amount and method of injection of the drug.
This interactive map would also improve public awareness. Missourians would be able to see that the opioid problem is not distant, but a local issue that reaches every part of our state. My hope is that this tool could shine a light on the reality that opioids have the potential to affect all Missourians, regardless of socioeconomic status.In St. Louis, the fire department is already tracking Narcan administration in the city, and the city’s health department has been conducting interviews after an overdose by reaching out to family members to gather demographic data about victims. By taking the good work that these entities are already doing and simply implementing their efforts statewide, we can begin to move toward an effective solution without reinventing the wheel.
I hope that the residents of Missouri will join me in the call to establish this statewide tool. Although it won’t solve all of the problems surrounding the opioid crisis, it can be a leap in the direction of putting our state at the forefront of containing and eliminating this significant national public health crisis.To make your voice heard, call your state representative and let him or her know that you would like to see Missouri implement a statewide Naloxone Administration Heat Map.Missouri State Rep. Donna Baringer is a Democrat from St. Louis and a formerSt. Louis alderman.

article headline: Delayed swearing in date could help new Missouri treasurer skirt term limits
Editorial: Old problems and a few new ones await Legislature's action in 2019
body text:
Missouri’s highways are crumbling. Its most vulnerable citizens lack health care access. And local court systems are running debtor-jail schemes that abuse the rights of poor defendants.These are just some of the top-priority issues that Missouri lawmakers must address in the 2019 legislative session. Others include opioid-prescription monitoring, internet sales taxes and a troublesome little phone app that just won’t go away even though it’s great at making public records disappear.Missouri’s dilapidated transportation infrastructure is the product of years of legislative neglect. Our state has one of the lowest fuel taxes in America at 17 cents a gallon, which lawmakers have refused for two decades to raise. Drive our highways to feel the results.

So organizers this year steered a fuel-tax increase onto the Nov. 6 ballot — containing, unfortunately, a convoluted funding plan and confusing ballot language. Its defeat may well have been the result of that confusion and not a rejection of the solid underlying idea of modernizing the fuel tax rate to fix and modernize our roads.The conundrum for legislators is that the voters have spoken. They’d rather have crummy roads than pay a few cents more for gasoline. State lawmakers should respect the will of the people and not try to override the Nov. 6 vote by approving their own fuel tax hike. But they should try to come up with better ballot language for a new referendum to raise the fuel tax for infrastructure improvements.They should offer it as soon as possible, written in clear language and stripped of any confusing side issues. Gov. Mike Parson and legislative leaders in both parties recognize the need for some kind of improved funding mechanism and should unite behind a new referendum. And this time, the voters of Missouri should get it right.Missouri’s health care situation is even more politically fraught, entangled with entrenched partisanship and bullheaded ideology. It’s time for ruling Republicans to set that aside and serve their constituents — including the poorest and sickest.The Affordable Care Act of 2010 was designed to include a state-by-state expansion of Medicaid, the federal government’s health care program for the poor. In Missouri, that would extend health care coverage to as many as 300,000 citizens, aid our struggling hospitals and pump billions of dollars into the state’s economy.But because of the ACA’s unofficial nickname — “Obamacare” — Republicans in 14 states, including Missouri, are still saying “thanks but no thanks” eight years later to extra federal dollars that would help fund health care for the uninsured.As those Republicans continue their stubborn stand, the ground has shifted under them. Polls show Americans now see health care access as a fundamental right. A Republican Congress has been unable to repeal Obamacare, and the GOP was decimated nationally on Nov. 6 in House races that hinged largely on health care.
By continuing this fight, Missouri Republicans are denying Missouri’s poorest citizens a basic right they would have in most other states. Enough. The Legislature and governor should, at long last, expand Medicaid.That promises to be a heavy lift. A much easier one should be ending the shameful practice in too many rural Missouri court systems of squeezing poor defendants for profit and jailing them for their poverty.Post-Dispatch columnist Tony Messenger has charted the practice for months in a series of columns exposing a Dickensian system of debtors jails. People who are arrested and tried for minor offenses are charged for their jail time. If they can’t pay, they are sometimes jailed again, racking up still more expenses.No one is suggesting that people who break the law, even in minor ways, shouldn’t face consequences — but they shouldn’t face repeated jail stays and years of indebtedness for misdemeanor offenses. Bipartisan legislation has been filed to end the practice. Residents from the state’s Republican-dominated rural districts are the ones suffering most from this abusive system, which means that legislators from rural Missouri should be leading this charge.
Another slam-dunk should be approval of a statewide prescription drug monitoring program of the kind Parson has been calling for.Despite the growing cost of opioid addiction, Missouri remains the only state without a statewide system to adequately prevent “doctor shopping” and other practices used to obtain often-lethal doses of opium-derived painkillers. Concerns about privacy have prevented approval of such a system in the past, but with term limits forcing out the main legislative opponents to a statewide database, the issue can be addressed anew with a strong likelihood of passage. Parson should have full legislative support on this.Among other 2019 agenda items:• A U.S. Supreme Court ruling last year opens the way for states to tax internet sales, even when the seller has no physical presence in the state. For small Missouri brick-and-mortar businesses, it’s a matter of basic fairness. The roughly $200 million a year Missouri could realize sweetens the deal. The Legislature should tax internet sales.• The phone app Confide, which erases text messages after they’re exchanged, was a controversy at the start of 2018 when it was revealed then-Gov. Eric Greitens and his staff were using it for official business. In effect, it meant they were complicit in the destruction of public records they were required to retain. Additional revelations about Confide’s use in other offices have since arisen. Public records are public records regardless of format; this modern version of disappearing ink should be banned by law from all government communications.• The tax paid on income earned in St. Louis is an important part of the city’s budget, provided largely by people who live outside city limits but use and enjoy the city’s amenities. The latest effort to kill the earnings tax is especially galling, as it’s coming from a legislator who doesn’t even live in the city, state Sen. Bill Eigel, R-Weldon Spring. With all due respect, senator, please butt out.

article headline: Will Missouri lawmakers make it harder to change the state's constitution?
Parson and Schatz show disregard for Missouri voters
body text:
In "Parson wants repeal of redistricting law" (Dec. 24), Gov. Mike Parson was quoted as saying that undoing the overwhelming voter approval of Amendment 1 in the Nov. 6 election is "what your job is sometimes, if you know something's unconstitutional, if you know some of it's not right." Of the voter-approved changes to the redistricting process, he said "I think that's so questionable."In the same article, state Sen. Dave Schatz is quoted as saying "there's a lot more to it (Amendment 1) than what the standard person can understand."

How dare they insult the 62 percent of Missouri voters who approved Amendment 1 (nearly 1.5 million voters) by saying we didn't understand or that we voted for something that's not right. Is Parson now the judge of what is "right" or unconstitutional in Missouri? What evidence does Schatz have that voters did not understand what they were voting for?
They are showing their disrespect and disregard not only for Missouri voters, but also for our essential democratic processes.
Presley Barker  •  Shrewsbury

article headline: Raasch: 2018 was the 'Shock Me' year in Show Me politics
Missouri weighing whether to build another nursing home for veterans
Editorial: For Missouri, 2018 brought toppled politicos, jobs lost to trade wars, and vanishing data
body text:
For Missouri, 2018 was a year of political exits that rocked the state and drew national attention. The year began with a sex-and-violence scandal that would ultimately take down Republican Gov. Eric Greitens. It ended with the defeat of two-term Democratic Sen. Claire McCaskill, giving national Republicans one of their few bright spots in the midterms.In between, Missourians changed state labor and drug laws in some decidedly un-conservative ways. President Donald Trump’s trade wars hit some of his strongest Missouri supporters. Data-wiping technology was revealed to be in wide governmental use. And 17 people lost their lives when a tourist “duck boat” overturned in the Ozarks.Greitens, a charismatic ex-Navy SEAL and bestselling author, exploded onto the scene in 2016 to win the governor’s office. His brash populism echoed Trump’s, as did his chaotic governing style.

Long-swirling rumors of a lurid extramarital affair broke open in January. Greitens’ former hairdresser alleged that, during an encounter in his St. Louis home in 2015 in which she was bound and blindfolded, he snapped a picture of her and threatened to publicize it if she revealed their affair.Greitens issued an extraordinary statement Jan. 10 — hours after his second annual State of the State speech — acknowledging the affair but denying the rest. Later, the woman further accused Greitens of physical and sexual violence.The Legislature began talking impeachment. St. Louis Circuit Attorney Kim Gardner filed criminal charges over the alleged photo threat and, later, over unrelated allegations of illegal campaign fundraising. Greitens defiantly vowed to fight the allegations.But on May 29, he abruptly announced — with a breaking voice — that he would resign, effective June 1. Gardner dropped the criminal charges. Lt. Gov. Mike Parson, Greitens’ level-headed polar opposite in every way but party affiliation, became governor.Greitens has since disappeared from public view, save one bizarre postscript: The man who was known for his infinite ambition, and whose books were all about never giving up, is rumored to be quietly raising money for a future run at office.McCaskill, on the other hand, says her name won’t appear on a ballot again, after losing her bid for a third Senate term on Nov. 6 to Republican state Attorney General Josh Hawley. It leaves Missouri, a former battleground state, with just one statewide Democrat: Auditor Nicole Galloway, who won her first full term in the same election.The combination of Greitens’ resignation and Hawley’s departure for the Senate set in motion a bizarre succession chain reaction. As of January, half of Missouri’s statewide elective offices will be filled by people who were never elected to those offices.
Hawley faced controversy over his decision, as attorney general, to join Missouri in a multistate lawsuit by Republicans seeking to dismantle the Affordable Care Act, threatening the health care coverage of a million or more Missourians. In response, Hawley put out a campaign ad vaguely claiming to be the true champion of universal coverage — an ad so obviously misleading that it drew national condemnation.Hawley nonetheless easily toppled McCaskill, furthering Missouri’s inexorable march in recent years toward solid red-state status.But even as Missourians elected conservative candidates this year, they approved policies at odds with the conservative agenda. In a ballot measure in August, they overwhelmingly defeated a Republican-passed law that had made Missouri an anti-union “right-to-work” state. Then ballot measures in November hiked the minimum wage and legalized medical marijuana.It was the first statewide general election to employ Missouri’s controversial voter ID law, created by legislative Republicans to solve the nonexistent problem of individual voter fraud. As expected, the requirements created confusion at polling places.
Amid the busy year of Missouri politics came a tragedy that stunned America. On the night of July 19, a duck boat set out on Table Rock Lake in the Ozarks near Branson, with 31 people aboard. The boat capsized and sank in high winds, killing 17 people ranging in age from 1 to 70. The dead included nine members of the Coleman family of Indianapolis. Multiple lawsuits, proposed safety legislation and manslaughter charges against the captain are pending.Trump’s trade wars this year tested the resolve of Americans who have provided his strongest political support, including the people of the southeastern Missouri.Mid Continent Nail Corp. of Poplar Bluff, America’s biggest producer of nails, gets its steel from the Mexican company that owns the factory. That steel now costs 25 percent more than it used to, thanks to Trump’s tariffs on Mexican imports. The factory this year shed more than a third of its workforce as it was priced out of the market. The company warns it could yet close completely.Missouri’s political class ended 2018 talking about a technology issue that has been humming all year: the cellphone app Confide, which automatically erases text messages after they’re exchanged. Then-Gov. Greitens and his staff were first caught last December using it for government business. Hawley, as attorney general, conducted a weak investigation of whether destroying records of official conversations in real time violated sunshine laws — a no-brainer, this newspaper has argued.It was later revealed that at least one person on Hawley’s staff was using Confide as well. More recently, it was revealed that the chief of staff of state Treasurer Eric Schmitt, Hawley’s soon-to-be-seated replacement as attorney general, also was using the disappearing app.Which makes it fair to ask, as 2018 draws to a close, whether there will be any government records left to report on by this time next year.

article headline: Sinquefield writes $850,000 check to PAC supporting Missouri's governor
Parson, Legislature anxious to overturn the people's vote
body text:
I read with interest the front-page story “Parson wants repeal of redistricting law” (Dec. 24). It has now become obvious that the Legislature thinks of the voters as a bunch of misinformed, ill-advised idiots.We passed a law outlawing open carry, and they reversed it. We passed a law against “puppy mills,” and they severely limited its effectiveness by removing the 50-dog limit.

Now we find out that the man who was largely responsible for removing that limit has another voter initiative in his sights. He feels that he knows better when it comes to these initiatives, and voters don’t really know what they’re talking about.
Well, it certainly appears the voters didn’t know what they were doing when they elected Parson, first to the Legislature and then as lieutenant governor, the position that made him the governor when Eric Greitens resigned. There is also talk of the Legislature finding a way to get around our recent vote against “right to work.”
Perhaps if we have a nonpartisan demographer work with the Legislature in setting the new district boundaries, as required by the initiative, we will get a Legislature that is not so anxious to overturn our vote.Rich Potvin  •  St. Louis

article headline: Voters told governor they want to clean up politics
body text:
Regarding “Parson wants repeal of redistricting law” (Dec. 24):

Why doesn't Gov. Mike Parson listen to the voters concerning the redistricting law? I responded as a Missourian who wants to clean up politics in my state when I voted.

I am insulted by Sen. Dave Schatz's comment that "there's a lot more to it (initiative petition) than what the standard person can understand." That statement could also apply to standard politicians.Lois Bundschuh  •  St. Louis County

article headline: State seeks dismissal of lobbyist gift ban lawsuit
Expanding Medicaid could help treat opioid addiction
body text:
It is disappointing to hear that Gov. Mike Parson is not an advocate for Medicaid expansion in Missouri despite research showing that states that did not expand Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act have seen more struggles in rural hospitals. Is Gov. Parson also going to ignore that Medicaid programs are taking the lead in identifying and tailoring strategies to prevent and treat opioid use disorder?The 2016 National Survey on Drug Use and Health reported that among non-elderly adults with opioid addiction, those with Medicaid were twice as likely as those with private insurance or no insurance to have received treatment. American families with private insurance are reluctant to seek care because private plans impose higher out-of-pocket costs or more stringent coverage limits. Due to high levels of stigma and discrimination, individuals with employer-sponsored coverage are not pursuing treatment because they worry that their employer will find out about their opioid use disorder.

Expanding Medicaid in Missouri won’t just help lower-income individuals. It can also help middle-class Americans have access to a medically needy program. Medically needy programs allow middle-class families to qualify for Medicaid if they have medical expenses that significantly reduce their income.
Many middle-class families are taking out second mortgages, emptying out 401(k)s, and going broke to pay for opioid treatment to save a son or daughter. Expanding Medicaid in Missouri will provide greater access to effective and affordable opioid treatment for all Missourians regardless of their income levels.
Nam Phuong Dang  •  St. Charles County

article headline: Governor resigns after months of investigations
body text:
Missouri Gov. Eric Greitens leaves the podium after announcing his resignation in the governor's office on Tuesday, May 29, 2018 in Jefferson City. Photo by Robert Cohen, rcohen@post-dispatch.com


Robert Cohen • rohen@post-dispatch.com



On the night of Jan. 10, Gov. Eric Greitens stood before legislators in the Missouri House chamber and promised to unveil the “boldest state tax reform in America.” But something else was troubling him.Barely an hour later, KMOV-TV broadcast a report alleging the governor had taken a partly nude photo of a woman in 2015 and threatened to release it if she revealed their affair. Greitens and his wife, Sheena, issued a statement confirming the affair. His lawyer denied the blackmail allegation.

Less than five months later, Greitens resigned, calling himself the victim of “legal harassment.”Greitens, a native of Maryland Heights and a former Navy SEAL, burst into politics with a carefully choreographed campaign for governor in 2016 that featured lots of military-style gunfire and a grand promise to crush corruption. But his hypocrisy over campaign finance — he doggedly refused to identify many of his own donors after pledging to do otherwise — caused tension with the GOP legislative majority.An investigation by St. Louis Circuit Attorney Kim Gardner, a Democrat, led to an indictment. A grand jury accused him of felony invasion of privacy for allegedly taking a nonconsensual cellphone photo of his partly clad lover. Greitens assembled a dream team of defense lawyers, including former federal prosecutors and a former St. Louis judge.  
Back at the capitol, a legislative committee took riveting testimony.Gardner bypassed St. Louis Police and hired William Don Tisaby, a former FBI agent, to do her investigative work. But they had to admit that the video recorder they used while questioning the woman had malfunctioned. Tisaby swore he took no notes. When an IT specialist recovered the video, it showed Tisaby with pen and pad. The dream team pounced, demanding to question Gardner under oath.
On May 14, three days into jury selection for Greitens' trial in St. Louis, Gardner dropped the charge after the judge ruled she had to testify about Tisaby, who already had taken the Fifth Amendment. Greitens was ecstatic.But numerous GOP legislators called for his impeachment and demanded information on his campaign finances. On the morning of May 29, a judge in Jefferson City ordered Greitens to hand over the records. That afternoon, he resigned.He was replaced by Lt. Gov. Mike Parson, an Ozarks farmer and former sheriff and legislator.

article headline: Missouri officials have yet to decide on new cross-state hiking, biking trail
body text:
Two years after then-Gov. Jay Nixon announced plans to turn a 144-mile stretch of the old Rock Island rail line into a state biking-hiking trail, it’s still not known if current Missouri officials will follow through with the idea.The state parks division under Gov. Mike Parson faces a Feb. 21 federal deadline for deciding whether to accept the planned donation of the rail corridor by Ameren.At issue, parks officials say, is the potential cost of developing the corridor into something similar to the long-established Katy Trail and its effect on the state’s financial ability to operate its many existing parks.

“We don’t want to do anything to impact our stewardship of the facilities we have,” Mike Sutherland, a deputy state parks director, said Friday.Now, as the deadline fast approaches, a national nonprofit trails advocacy group is urging people to contact Parson and other state officials on behalf of the plan.“Missouri officials may pass up a once-in-a-generation opportunity” to preserve the corridor for future trail use, the Washington-based Rails-to-Trails Conservancy warns on its website.The conservancy’s effort follows similar lobby campaigns over the past two years by the Missouri Bicycle and Pedestrian Federation and Missouri Rock Island Trail Inc., a booster group for the trail.Supporters also include leaders in towns along the corridor, which would reach from Beaufort in Franklin County to Windsor in western Missouri.









Bolstered by a study done for the booster group by University of Missouri Extension, backers say the trail would boost tourism and provide an economic shot in the arm for the area.The Missouri Farm Bureau Federation, meanwhile, remains opposed and says the trail would disrupt nearby farms and lead to increased road and public safety expenses.State officials in 2017 said fully completing the trail could cost $65 million to $85 million. That was a preliminary estimate based on experience from 47.5 miles of trail opened in 2016 along a Rock Island segment west of Windsor.That’s now called the Rock Island spur of the Katy Trail. The Katy itself goes from St. Charles County through Windsor and further west.
Sutherland said a detailed study of the corridor’s condition carried out since then hadn’t changed the estimate.Among the state’s options are accepting just part of the corridor or working with private groups. “Anything’s an option potentially,” he said.Greg Harris, executive director of Missouri Rock Island Trail Inc., argues that the state need only make “the bare minimum” initial investment.
“They could leave it largely unchanged in the short term” while working with private organizations and towns along the corridor to gradually develop parts of the trail over many years, Harris said.Harris said it could be used at first in its current rough state for hiking, horseback riding and mountain biking — stopping and starting on either side of the route’s many bridges that require renovation work.Sutherland said that even if the corridor sat idle without improvements for many years, there would still be a significant cost to the state because it would have the responsibility of keeping it safe and monitoring it.He added that a bill passed by the Legislature this year could add to the expense.The measure requires the state parks system to maintain any fencing between land owned by private parties and any part of the corridor taken over by the state.If the state rejects the corridor, Harris said, his group will explore other options such as a private organization’s accepting the Ameren donation. But he said the state parks system was the logical entity to oversee it.The state’s reconsideration of the Ameren offer began under Eric Greitens, the Republican who succeeded Nixon, a Democrat, in January 2017. Parson, also a Republican, became governor when Greitens resigned last June. Ameren bought the corridor in 1999 through a subsidiary.The state won last year from the federal Surface Transportation Board a yearlong extension of the deadline for accepting the rail corridor.Sutherland said that although the parks agency was working to reach a decision by Feb. 21, it could request a further extension if officials determined additional time was needed.

article headline: Editorial: Clergy abuse probe should be top priority for Missouri's next attorney general
body text:
An investigation by the Illinois attorney general into child sexual assault in the Catholic Church echoes what’s been found in other states: a widespread, decades-long pattern of abuse and coverup involving hundreds of priests.Missouri’s own investigation continues, with victims’ advocates complaining that outgoing Attorney General Josh Hawley hasn’t been aggressive enough. With Hawley heading to the U.S. Senate, his replacement, Eric Schmitt, has an opportunity to start on the right foot by making the investigation a top priority.America was stunned this year when an investigation in Pennsylvania determined that some 300 priests had abused roughly 1,000 children over a 70-year period, as the church actively covered the abusers’ tracks. Those findings spawned similar investigations in other states, including Missouri and Illinois.

Illinois Attorney General Lisa Madigan announced her office’s findings last week, and it was, again, stunning. As the Post-Dispatch’s Nassim Benchaabane reported, Madigan’s investigators uncovered allegations of sexual abuse against at least 500 clergy that the church knew about but never made public.In many cases, they found, the church declined to even investigate allegations. Some abuse survivors weren’t told that others had been victimized by the same clergy members. There were also instances in which church officials used details of the victims’ personal lives to discredit them.
In a statement, Madigan aptly laid out the scope of this betrayal, saying the church “has failed in its moral obligation to provide survivors, parishioners and the public a complete and accurate accounting of all sexually inappropriate behavior involving priests in Illinois.”
In Missouri, Hawley announced his office’s own investigation in August, shortly after the Pennsylvania report broke. Hawley — who heads to Washington in January — has faced criticism from victims’ advocates who say the attorney general has not pursued the investigation aggressively. Hawley has disputed that.Part of the challenge with the Missouri investigation is that the attorney general’s office has no subpoena power over church entities here; that rests with local prosecutors. Hawley’s investigation from the outset has relied on voluntary cooperation from the church, an approach victims’ advocates don’t believe will work.Schmitt, the current state treasurer whom Gov. Mike Parson appointed to fill Hawley’s vacancy, will inherit that problem along with the rest of the investigation. There are ways around it, including a coordinated effort to get local prosecutors involved in the probe. He also could seek the appointment of the attorney general’s office as a special prosecutor, which would give it subpoena power.As Schmitt prepares to assume this investigation, he should explore those and other options available to make this an aggressive, full-fledged investigation like those conducted in Pennsylvania and, now, Illinois. Relying on the cooperation of a church hierarchy that was complicit in the coverup for generations is unacceptable.

Horrigan: Probe-o-rama
body text:
If there’s one thing we Missouri Republicans are good at, apart from winning elections, it’s investigating ourselves.Winning elections is the easy part. The state is 82 percent white, and half of that 82 percent are evangelical voters. We’ve got a guy in the Legislature who videoed himself lopping the heads off chickens to make a point about abortion and he won re-election by 48 points. We’re easy.The investigations are the hard part. It’s a tricky balance: You have to appear to be concerned about a fellow Republican’s transgressions without actually doing anything about it, unless he’s Eric Greitens, who referred to you as vultures, liars and sociopaths. Him you chase like Jean Valjean.

(Speaking of Greitens: Outside of people in the witness protection program, has anyone ever dropped out of sight more thoroughly than the former governor and pull-up coach? For five months he’s on the front page every day and then poof! He’s gone. It’s like he moved to Abbottabad.)During Greitens’ legal troubles last spring, the Republican-led House conducted an actual, legitimate pre-impeachment investigation. The findings became moot when Greitens resigned June 1 and prosecutors dropped their cases against him. However, several investigations that Missouri Attorney General Josh Hawley was conducting into his fellow Republican’s alleged transgressions are supposedly alive-ish.Hawley held press conferences and sprinkled subpoenas like confetti and used words like “impeachable offense.” It got him a lot of good publicity as he prepared to run for the U.S. Senate. It put some distance between himself and Greitens. But how serious the effort was is a matter of some dispute. His office’s first whack at finding out if Greitens’ staff had used Confide, a text-message zapping phone app, was limited to asking Greitens’ staffers whatever questions could be squeezed into a 15-minute interview.“Did you use Confide?”Yup.“Do anything wrong?”Nope.“OK. Good to go.”Now it’s Hawley who’s being investigated by yet another Republican state office holder, and there are signs that this investigation will be equally hard-hitting.
The Missouri secretary of state’s office is going to look into charges that Hawley allowed political consultants for his U.S. Senate campaign to direct the work of his state-paid workers in the attorney general’s office. The Kansas City Star broke the story, complete with a paper trail that clearly showed the consultants making decisions that turned state workers into campaign drones.I am of two minds about this. One, it’s illegal and people have gone to prison for similar crimes back when we took such matters seriously. Lest we forget, Hawley even made noise about investigating Greitens for using state resources for political purposes.Probably a special prosecutor should be looking into this, not Secretary of State Jay Ashcroft. He only has authority over election laws and doesn’t even have subpoena powers.On the other hand, Hawley’s office was such a mess in his brief tenure there that it’s good to know that someone was in charge, even if it was an illegal someone. The New York Times reported that lawyers came and went, mostly went, leaving the office’s civil litigation section badly understaffed and outmatched, costing the state a lot of money. Experienced litigators — the people who stand up in court and argue — quit willy-nilly. Hawley was busy running for Senate, and we Republicans were happy to elect him. We don’t care if the people we elect are good at their jobs — look who we elected as president.
But now a liberal legal group has complained about the role that consultants played in running the AG’s office. Ashcroft is going to investigate another Republican. Grudgingly.“This office will commence an investigation into the alleged offense,” Ashcroft’s deputy counsel wrote to the legal group, asking the group to pass along any information it might have.Some investigation this is going to be. Got any tips? Any ideas where we should look? Last week the office asked state Auditor Nicole Galloway if it can borrow her office’s subpoena power. This could be a problem. Galloway is not only a Democrat but doesn’t mess around.As if this cake needed any more icing, it turns out that while Hawley was “investigating” Greitens’ staff for using Confide, his own chief of staff was zapping public records with Confide. So was the chief of staff for state Treasurer Eric Schmitt, who will become attorney general whenever Hawley steps down.I’m thinking that as soon as he takes office, Schmitt ought to investigate Ashcroft for something. Nepotism, maybe. Then the new treasurer, whoever that turns out to be, can investigate Mike Kehoe, the new lieutenant governor that the old lieutenant governor, Mike Parson, appointed after he succeeded Greitens, even though he didn’t have clear authority to do so.And people wonder why Missouri is stuck in the mud.Kevin Horrigan, a retired member of the Post-Dispatch editorial board, is a freelance writer in St. Louis.kfhorrigan@gmail.com
