Editorial: Medical marijuana is legal in Missouri. So don't punish its legal users.
body text:
The Missouri Department of Social Services is grappling with the decision of whether to allow medical marijuana users to receive welfare benefits. Voters’ decision on Nov. 6 to legalize medical marijuana use across Missouri placed this question squarely in a legal gray area, but this question has an easy answer: People who are exercising their legal right to use clinically prescribed medicine should not be punished for it with restricted welfare benefits. The new law took effect Thursday.The department would be within its legal right under federal law to prevent marijuana users from accessing welfare benefits. Under the federal Controlled Substances Act, marijuana — medical or recreational — remains a Schedule I illegal drug, regarded as equal in danger to heroin even though it clearly isn’t. But another piece of federal legislation, the Rohrabacher-Farr Amendment, prohibits the government from using the restriction of federal funds to inhibit state marijuana laws.Even though the federal government can’t enforce the medical marijuana prohibition in Missouri, the state still could exercise its discretion to bar users of medical marijuana from receiving welfare. Missouri now joins 33 other states that openly defy the federal government regarding public access to medical marijuana.

The Supreme Court has repeatedly upheld a principle known as the anti-commandeering doctrine, which dictates that the federal government cannot “command” state officials to enforce federal laws. It’s because of this doctrine that the federal government can only request, but not demand, that local law enforcers assist with detaining criminal undocumented immigrants targeted for removal.If the federal government wants to enforce medical marijuana laws in the states, it must use its own resources.
As the Post-Dispatch’s Kurt Erickson reported, the Missouri Department of Social Services finds itself in legal limbo when it comes to restricting welfare recipients’ access to medically prescribed marijuana.
Welfare is designed as a social safety net to protect the most vulnerable in society, who include not only families in financial straits but also people who cannot work because of medical conditions or disabilities. The state government has no business deciding which medicine welfare recipients should be allowed access to, and which should not. The government especially should not be making such determinations based on purely punitive and subjective motives.Medical marijuana is widely accepted by doctors as having therapeutic value; 64.2 percent of medical marijuana prescriptions go to patients with chronic and severe pain. It also has been useful in easing the effects of Parkinson’s, post-traumatic stress disorder, epilepsy, glaucoma and cancer. These aren’t partiers trying to sneak a legal high. They’re patients struggling with physically and financially debilitating illnesses.While the letter of the law doesn’t compel the state to provide welfare to medical marijuana users, Gov. Mike Parson should yield to his own sense of compassion and not punish people who already are suffering enough.

article headline: Work in a bipartisan manner to provide jobs to Missourians
body text:
Missouri’s economy is facing pressure, and I’m disappointed that Gov. Mike Parson may be inclined to support the false solution of "right to work" on a county-by-county level across Missouri as revealed in a recent press investigation.Missourians rejected "right to work" in August, with 67.5 percent of Missourians voting against this so-called solution to our economic ills. It is time for Republicans to stop blaming organized labor for Missouri’s economic ills and instead start offering real solutions, like investment in higher education by offering all high school graduates the opportunity to earn an associate’s degree or professional certification at no cost to them.

It costs approximately $10,000 a year to train an apprentice, and unions pay this cost so Missouri can benefit from an increased ability to meet demand for skilled workers. Labor unions support investment in our crumbling infrastructure because we know the benefit of investment in Missouri’s transportation network that creates quality local jobs and moves goods across our state.
Two-thirds of the Missourians who voted in August voted no. My hope is that the Republican legislative majority and Gov. Parson do not waste more time considering these divisive anti-worker issues, but that we work in a bipartisan fashion to put Missourians to work, provide quality educational opportunities and move the state forward.
State Sen. Gina Walsh  •  D-Bellefontaine NeighborsPresident, Missouri State Building and Construction Trades Council

article headline: Hawley greets his successor with smiles as under-the-radar issues, and changes, loom
Parson calls for a 'long overdue' statewide prescription drug monitoring program during St. Louis visit
body text:
ST. LOUIS • Missouri Gov. Mike Parson said Wednesday in St. Louis that he’d like to sign a statewide prescription drug monitoring program into law next year, a move he says is “long overdue.”“We’re the only state in the United States that doesn’t have that,” said Parson, flanked by members of his cabinet and St. Louis officials, who gathered for a discussion on the opioid epidemic. “The reality of it is, people are losing their lives every day from a terrible situation. And we’ve got to figure out to make sure we have all the tools everybody needs to be able to fight that.”Bills creating a prescription drug monitoring program, or PDMP, have been debated in the Missouri Legislature for years, but none of the proposals has made it across the finish line.

Last year, Parson’s predecessor, Eric Greitens, issued an executive order calling for his own version of a monitoring program, but Republicans and Democrats alike said his plan fell short of providing a comprehensive approach to fighting drug abuse.Under Greitens’ measure, the Department of Health and Senior Services pays Express Scripts and other pharmacy benefit management companies such as UnitedHealthcare and CVS to analyze doctor and pharmacy prescription and dispensing data for schedule II through IV controlled substances.The agency then uses the information to identify activity indicating that controlled substances are being inappropriately prescribed, dispensed or obtained.But Greitens’ plan differs significantly from what is in place in other states and in local counties and jurisdictions across Missouri, including many in the St. Louis region. Those programs track when patients are prescribed an opioid painkiller, typically making that information available to doctors — a feature absent from Greitens’ order.PDMP proponents argue that it allows doctors and pharmacists to identify “doctor shoppers,” or individuals who go from physician to physician to continually be prescribed the same drugs. The hope is that they can intervene before the addiction spirals out control, or identify anyone who may be selling the drugs.“We all know prescriptions is where a lot of this problem started. Prescriptions is where some of this problem will end,” St. Louis Mayor Lyda Krewson said.When prescription drugs become too difficult or expensive to obtain, users often turn to heroin, or worse, cross-contaminated drugs containing fentanyl: a drug that is far more potent and more deadly.
St. Louis city and county are on pace for record-setting overdose deaths this year, after a record 760 opioid-related deaths in the St. Louis region in 2017.There were 951 total opioid-related deaths in Missouri in 2017, according to the state’s Department of Health and Senior Services.Parson offered few details on what potential PDMP legislation would have his support, but the topic will be a familiar one for state lawmakers.Opponents to past proposals feared they would violate citizens’ right to privacy, allowing sensitive information to be stored on a government database, vulnerable to data breaches.
Parson said that with new leadership in the governor’s office, and in the Missouri House and Senate, a measure might finally pass in 2019.The governor will have one key ally in the Senate: Earlier this month, Republicans picked Sen. Dave Schatz, R-Sullivan, to succeed Senate President Pro Tem Ron Richard. Schatz has previously sponsored bills establishing a statewide PDMP.But there remains little appetite to expand Medicaid in Missouri, something officials in states that have expanded, such as Ohio, say helped curb their own opioid crisis by giving low-income adults more access to addiction and mental health services.“I think there’s a lot of things that have to be on the table. But let me first say, most of the states are having problems just like us. So it’s not that Missouri is unique in this by no means, a lot of states are still having problems, even the ones that have Medicaid expansion are still having troubles, too,” Parson said. “We’ve got to fix what we have first before we start expanding something that’s a problem.”Also on Wednesday, Parson paid a visit to the St. Louis Missouri Veterans Home and spoke with small business leaders in the region about rising health care costs.

Gov. Mike Parson wants probe of Missouri's public safety department after 'questionable' spending
body text:
JEFFERSON CITY • Gov. Mike Parson on Tuesday asked state Auditor Nicole Galloway to audit the state Department of Public Safety director's office after the agency's new director uncovered "questionable" spending when she took the job.Parson, a Republican, in August appointed then-Missouri Highway Patrol Col. Sandra Karsten to lead the Department of Public Safety. Karsten replaced then-Director Drew Juden, who was appointed by former Gov. Eric Greitens, a Republican.Parson ousted Juden in August. Parson's spokeswoman said then that the new chief executive, himself a former sheriff, wanted to move the department in a different direction. The Parson administration did not elaborate at the time.

Karsten, in a statement on Tuesday, said the state Office of Administration reviewed the department's director's office after she started in August. "Our initial review raised concerns that warranted a more in-depth examination of past public safety administration practices,” Karsten said.She said the state auditor had not assessed the director's office in five years."A state audit is the appropriate next step to ensure the DPS Director’s office is fulfilling its obligations to the people of Missouri," Karsten said.Parson, in a statement on Tuesday, expressed vague concerns about "questionable use of taxpayer dollars," but did not elaborate.“Anytime a department director raises concerns about questionable use of taxpayer dollars, we take them very seriously — that’s why under these circumstances we have requested a state audit,” he said. “Director Karsten is doing a great job leading DPS and has a clear understanding about the importance of keeping government accountable to the people of Missouri.”Parson sent a formal letter to Galloway, a Democrat. The three-paragraph letter offers no other details on potential malfeasance within the office.
"Upon review of the Governor's request, I have committed to performing an independent audit of the administrative practices of the Department of Public Safety," Galloway said in a statement, adding that people with information can contact the auditor's whistleblower hotline.The Department of Public Safety, with 15,000 employees, oversees eight agencies, including the highway patrol, Capitol Police, Fire Safety, Missouri National Guard, Alcohol & Tobacco Control, State Emergency Management Agency, Veterans Commission and Gaming Commission.
Juden's ousting was Parson's first major staff shake-up after Parson took office in June. Prior to joining Greitens’ administration, Juden oversaw both the police and fire departments in Sikeston, population 16,000. He also is a former president of the Missouri Police Chiefs Association.Juden, who has worked in law enforcement for more than 40 years, came under fire last summer when Greitens said Juden had investigated problems at the St. Louis Veterans Home and found no issues.After outcry by then-Lt. Gov. Parson, residents, families and lawmakers, Greitens led a major shakeup of the agency that oversees the home.As a Sikeston police officer, Juden also was involved in a botched case that garnered attention earlier this year.In August 2000, Juden was the arresting officer when David Robinson was charged with the murder of Sheila Box. Juden also supervised the detective who put together the case that led to Robinson being convicted.This year, however, the Missouri Supreme Court ruled that Robinson should be released from prison after 16 years because of serious questions about the case, including witnesses that recanted their testimony.

article headline: Editorial: Missouri should make the anti-transparency Confide app disappear once and for all
body text:
Once again, the text-scrubbing app Confide is in the news in Missouri, this time with the revelation that a top aide to the state’s incoming attorney general downloaded it and may have used it to communicate with associates of former Gov. Eric Greitens.Confide is a mobile phone application that automatically deletes text messages after they’re read, preventing records from being kept and enabling users in government positions to evade the state’s Sunshine Law. Greitens, whose instincts for inappropriate secrecy were obvious throughout his short political career, used it with members of his staff.The issue spawned litigation and debate over whether destroying officials’ text exchanges in real time violates public records laws. We believe it clearly does. Gov. Mike Parson, who last week pledged to abide by high standards of ethics and transparency, should use this latest revelation to establish, by law, that Confide has no place in governmental communications.

Despite rapidly changing technology for communications, some legal standards should remain consistent, including the principle that government officials’ on-the-job communications — whether typed, texted, handwritten, carrier-pigeoned or whatever — must be preserved because they are potentially subject to public review.Greitens seldom paused to consider such principles. After winning office in 2016 with a campaign steeped in dark money, his short tenure as governor was marked by a level of secrecy unprecedented in modern times. It wasn’t terribly surprising when The Kansas City Star reported in December 2017 that Greitens and his top staff were communicating via the smartphone equivalent of disappearing ink.
Greitens, under pressure, banned Confide from his office, though subsequent reporting found he and others kept the app on their phones, leaving open the question of whether they actually stopped using it. Attorney General Josh Hawley investigated and found no evidence of wrongdoing — which, of course, is the whole point of using Confide in the first place: to erase the evidence.
Hawley has been elected to the U.S. Senate, and Parson has appointed state Treasurer Eric Schmitt to become attorney general in January. In the latest twist, the Post-Dispatch’s Jack Suntrup reported that Andrew Dziedzic — a former member of Greitens’ transition team and now Schmitt’s chief of staff — had the Confide app on his phone in 2017, and records indicate he may have used it to communicate with other Greitens associates.This, too, isn’t evidence of wrongdoing. But it presents an opportunity for both Schmitt and Parson — who just last week signed an executive order imposing tougher ethical standards on his administration — to push for legislation officially banning Confide and apps like it from all governmental communications.A legislative attempt at such a law this year vanished like a Confide text. But with these two prominent voices behind it, the message could get through next time.

article headline: Editorial: Thanksgiving toasts to good works by good people
body text:
The Thanksgiving table is traditionally the place where friends and family gather to take stock of their blessings and appreciate all the ways, big and small, that we make life better for one another. Out there in the wider world, first responders, homemakers, artists, military service members, office workers and, yes, even politicians have had a positive impact on the lives of people around them. Though we’ve expressed appreciation to many of them before, it’s time to raise a glass in praise of good works and offer our Thanksgiving toasts …To St. Louis Fire Capt. Leon Whitener and 29 of his colleagues at the fire department, whose heroics were recently honored by Gov. Mike Parson, for exemplifying the kinds of quick thinking and self-sacrifice that save lives and keep our communities safe. Whitener was driving home from work on April 22 when alerted to a nearby fire that had trapped a wheelchair-bound woman inside. Whitener, assisted by civilian Raymond Rayford, rushed into the blaze and carried the woman to safety.To the staff of the Capital Gazette in Annapolis, Md., which rallied after a deadly shooting in their offices in June. A gunman with a vendetta entered the newspaper building and killed five employees with a shotgun. Surviving members of the staff, steeping in grief, stayed on the job and covered the story like the professionals they are.

To Kate Wynja and Kaiden Whaley, two young athletes whose conduct in competition should serve as inspiration to other youths and a valuable lesson to adults about the importance of prioritizing character over the blind pursuit of victory. Wynja, a star golfer on her South Dakota high school golf team, led her teammates to two Class A state championship finals. On their second try at the state title, scorekeepers had under-counted the number of strokes Wynja had taken on one hole in the final round. She didn’t notice the error until after she had signed and turned in her scorecard. No one else did, either. She could’ve kept quiet and retained the individual and team championship. Instead, she spoke up and acknowledged the mistake, knowing the error would disqualify her and bump her team out of the championship. Winning wasn’t the important thing for Wynja; honesty was. Whaley was the goalie for his junior hockey team near Washington, D.C. The opposing team’s goalie couldn’t make the game. They had to sub a 10-year-old forward, Leopold Hylton — who had never played goalie in his life — in a game against Whaley’s team. In the first period, Hylton gave up seven goals. When the period was over, Whaley skipped the break with his team and, without consulting his coach, skated over to Hylton, where he conducted a crash course in goalkeeping. The lesson proved valuable. Hylton survived the next two periods, giving up “only” four more goals. It wasn’t winning that counted for either. It was all about being good sports. Wynja and Whaley were honored at Saturday’s Musial Awards in St. Louis.To John “J.K.” Reed, believed to be the last Missouri veteran to have survived the 1941 Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. Reed, of Troy, was eating breakfast when the attack began. He and other enlistees grabbed the only weapons they could find — service rifles — and began firing skyward in a desperate but futile attempt to ward off the attack. He served until 1945 in the Pacific, surviving mines at sea and repeated kamikaze attacks. He died Nov. 12, one week before his 97th birthday.
To Walter Carr, the 20-year-old college student who walked 20 miles overnight to make his first day on the job at Alabama’s Bellhop moving company after his car broke down; and to police who came across him and bought him breakfast; and to Bellhop CEO Luke Marklin, who gave Carr his personal car to reward his admirable work ethic.
To Howard Brown, football and life coach at McCluer South-Berkeley High school, for his efforts beyond the call of duty to provide love, structure and guidance to the at-risk students on his team in the Ferguson-Florissant community. As was noted when his team received a $25,000 donation in honor of his efforts, Brown has used his own money to supply food, clean uniforms and gear for his players. Football talent isn’t the top priority to make the team, he says, asking them only to be “good citizens, good people, good students.”To Aretha Franklin, the Queen of Soul. The woman Rolling Stone magazine praised as “one of the greatest singers of all time” was much more than that: musical pioneer, civil rights activist, feminist icon for decades. Her anthem “Think” is advice for the ages. Franklin, 76, died Aug. 16.To Southwest Airlines pilot Tammie Jo Shults, who kept a cool head after an engine exploded and blew a hole in the cabin of the Boeing 737 plane she was commanding. One passenger was killed after being partially sucked out of the hole. The deafening roar inside the cockpit forced Shults and her co-pilot, Darren Ellisor, to communicate by hand signals. Despite chaos all around her, Shults calmly guided the plane through a harrowing 32,500-foot descent, landing it and saving the lives of all but one of the 149 people on board.To the dead and the survivors of the mass shootings in 2018: Parkland, Fla. (17 dead); Santa Fe, Texas (10 dead); Thousand Oaks, Calif. (12 dead); and the Tree of Life Synagogue in Pittsburgh (11 dead). Space limitations prevent us from listing the other more than 300 additional mass shootings this year. We raise a glass to toast their cut-short lives so that we may never forget.

article headline: Top aide to Greitens looks to national role
Missouri school board rehires commissioner ousted by Greitens allies last year
body text:
JEFFERSON CITY • In a stinging rebuke to former Gov. Eric Greitens, Missouri education officials are rehiring the commissioner who was ousted from her job last year.Margie Vandeven, who was dismissed last year by a board that had been revamped by Greitens, will resume the $191,544 post she had held since 2015, officials said Tuesday.“It is an honor to return to the department, and I remain committed to doing what is best for the children of Missouri. I look forward to working with stakeholders from across our state — urban, rural and suburban. Through active collaboration among state and local leaders, educators and our families, we will — together — advance opportunities for each student,” Vandeven said in a statement.

Vandeven was among four finalists for the position, which had been vacant since December after Greitens’ failed attempt to bring in his own candidate to lead the 1,650-employee agency.The scandal-plagued ex-governor spent much of last year stacking the school board with his own appointees. Without any public explanation, the new board members then moved to fire Vandeven, despite her receiving high marks from school advocates and other education observers.The board, however, was unable to hire a replacement after members of the state Senate – angered by the governor’s actions — blocked the confirmation of the appointees, leaving the board with too few members to officially meet.After Greitens’ hasty departure, Gov. Mike Parson nominated new board members who were not opposed during a less-confrontational Senate confirmation process.In a statement, Parson highlighted that Vandeven was chosen by an “independent” state board.“Moving forward, we will continue working with Missouri’s Department of Elementary and Secondary Education to focus efforts on ensuring our students have the skills to succeed and meet the demands of tomorrow’s workforce,” Parson said.Vandeven’s rehiring comes after a monthlong application process drew five applications and seven nominations. Vandeven said she was among those nominated.The board winnowed that down to four with an eye on getting the new commissioner on board in January and agreed on Vandeven after a 90-minute interview with her on Monday.Other candidates included Rockwood School District Superintendent Eric Knost, who is retiring from the St. Louis County district at the end of the school year.
“We were blessed with really great candidates,” said school board President Charlie Shields.Shields said Greitens was not a factor in the hiring process.“This was never about righting a wrong,” Shields said. “This was about the ability to continue to move the state forward when it came to education.”“I really don’t hold any grudges at this point,” Vandeven added. “I plan to hit the ground running.”
Vandeven launched her career in 1990 as a communication arts teacher in private schools in St. Charles County. From 1995-2002 she taught high school English and served as an administrator in Maryland, before returning to Missouri as an English teacher and administrator.She started in the state’s top post in January 2015.Vandeven had been working in the private sector as director of educational partnerships for the SAS Institute.Roger Dorson, interim commissioner, has led the department since December.“I want to thank Roger for his amazing leadership during a challenging time as well as express my appreciation to the education community for its support,” Shields said. “We look forward to continuous progress for the department under Margie’s leadership.”School advocates also signaled their support of the move.“The State Board of Education has made an excellent choice to rehire Dr. Margie Vandeven as commissioner of education. Dr. Vandeven has a proven track record of effective leadership for both the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education and for public education in Missouri,” said Melissa Randol, executive director of the Missouri School Boards’ Association.

article headline: Governor fills open St. Louis County court seat
body text:
ST. LOUIS COUNTY • An administrative law judge was appointed on Tuesday to fill an associate judge seat with the St. Louis County Circuit Court.The appointment of Lorne J. Baker was one of three announced by Gov. Mike Parson's office. Baker, of Olivette, will fill the vacancy created by the promotion of John N. Borbonus III to circuit judge.

Baker has been an administrative law judge in St. Louis County for two years.
He is a graduate of the University of Michigan in 1990 and the University of Missouri-Columbia School of Law in 1993. From 1994-1999, he was an assistant public defender in St. Louis.
The other two judicial appointments were in outstate Missouri.

article headline: Editorial: Light at the end of the dark tunnel where Greitens left Missouri schools
body text:
Gov. Mike Parson has been very clear about his major legislative goals heading into 2019, with workforce development ranking among his highest priority items. He can make no bolder step toward improving employers’ workforce choices than by getting the state’s public schools back on track after the damage inflicted by disgraced former Gov. Eric Greitens.Margie Vandeven was the person spearheading that effort long before Parson took over from the scandal-plagued Greitens. But Greitens, seemingly hellbent on making a mess of everything he touched, decided to force Vandeven out as the state’s school commissioner. On Tuesday, she was rehired for the job she never should have been forced to leave.Greitens meddled where he had no business tinkering. The state school board was designed to be an independent, bipartisan, consensus-building group whose goals were supposed to supersede political agendas and focus solely on giving Missouri children the best education they could receive.

Despite Vandeven’s superior qualifications and high praise from education professionals, Greitens wanted to put his own stamp on public education. He never publicly explained his reasoning or legal justification since the governor has no power over who gets the job. But to get what he wanted, he tried to stack the state board with loyalists who would vote Vandeven out.As we wrote almost exactly one year ago, Greitens handled this issue exactly like the neophyte, inexperienced politician he was. Someone with political experience would’ve been skilled in the art of persuasion, compromise and negotiation to get what he wanted. Instead, Greitens drew on the only background he knew, as a former Navy SEAL, and attempted to muscle his way to victory. The result was an unmitigated disaster, which Parson inherited and is methodically working to correct.
After waiting for the 2017 legislative session to end, Greitens engineered a series of interim appointments to the school board. He threatened appointees who wouldn’t do his bidding. Friends of big donors took priority as appointees even if they had no interest or track record in public education. As pressure intensified to get rid of Vandeven, some appointees declined to serve or withdrew from consideration.
This game of musical chairs went on and on for months. This year, the Senate refused to confirm Greitens’ appointees, leaving in limbo a body that oversees about 900,000 K-12 students, including the roughly 24,000 attending St. Louis Public Schools.One of the state board’s unfinished items of business is setting the timetable for St. Louis schools to transition from appointed to elected governance. A long-awaited evaluation system for statewide school performance also is due. None of this can happen as long as the board and its commissioner remain in flux.Vandeven is an excellent choice to bring the state’s education needs into closer alignment with Parson’s priorities.

article headline: Parson alters lobbyist gift ban rules imposed by Greitens
Former Missouri school chief seeking old job
body text:
JEFFERSON CITY • The woman ousted last year as part of former Gov. Eric Greitens’ ill-fated push to install his own state school commissioner may be on track to get her old job back.Margie Vandeven, who was dismissed last year by a school board that the scandal-plagued governor had stacked with his own appointees, was among four finalists interviewing for the post Monday.Vandeven confirmed she was seeking her old job as she entered a closed meeting of the board before 3 p.m. for an interview.

“That’s what we’re here to find out,” Vandeven said.Board President Charlie Shields said the board made a unanimous decision Monday to hire one of the candidates after spending about 90 minutes with each of them.An announcement, pending an acceptance of the $191,544 per year job, is expected Tuesday.Sources said Vandeven likely has the inside track because of her experience running the agency.Vandeven’s reappearance in the offices of the board comes after a year of turmoil set in motion by Greitens.Greitens, who resigned under a cloud in June, spent much of last year stacking the board with his own appointees. They then moved to fire Vandeven, who had received high marks from education advocates and other education observers.














        
            Governor finally fires Missouri's schools boss

Eric Greitens named five new people to the education board in the past four months so he could get rid of Margie Vandeven.  




Greitens’ appointees then attempted to rush through the hiring of a replacement. But members of the state Senate who were angry over Greitens’ meddling with the independent board blocked the confirmation of the appointees, leaving the board unable to meet.Greitens’ replacement, Gov. Mike Parson, nominated new board members who were not opposed during a less confrontational Senate confirmation process.
The search for a new commissioner got underway in October, when a month-long application period drew five résumés and seven nominations.The board winnowed that down to four with an eye on getting the new commissioner on board in January.To qualify, the candidates must have a doctorate. The commissioner oversees an agency with about 1,650 employees, who monitor the state’s 518 school districts.Vandeven said she did not send in an application, but rather was nominated.
Vandeven began her education career in 1990 as a communication arts teacher in O’Fallon. From 1995-2002 she taught high school English and served as an administrator in Maryland, before returning to Missouri as an English teacher and administrator.She started in the top post in January 2015.Roger Dorson, interim commissioner, has led the department since December.Shields has praised Dorson for his leadership and said the board could opt to remove the “interim” tag from Dorson’s title.Another finalist, Rockwood School District Superintendent Eric Knost, interviewed with the board after lunch Monday.In October, Knost announced his retirement after 31 years in public education.Knost, 53, has been at the helm of the west St. Louis County district — the third largest in the state — since 2014.The name of the other finalist was not available.

article headline: Missouri Civil Air Patrol Recognizes Members at Annual Conference
body text:
Missouri Wing Headquarters, Whiteman AFB, Mo. – More than 100 members of the Missouri Wing, Civil Air Patrol, U.S. Air Force Auxiliary, and guests attended the annual Missouri Wing Conference held the weekend of October 19-20, 2018, at the Radisson Hotel in Branson, Missouri.

The Saturday general session featured speakers CAP National Command Chief Master Sgt. Robert Dandridge, North Central Region Commander Col. Regina Aye, and CAP-USAF North Central Liaison Region Commander Lt. Col. Jeffrey Meyers, USAF.  Chief Dandridge delivered the National Commander’s report highlighting CAP’s successes and clearly defining the organization’s priorities and path for the next two years.  Col. Aye discussed where Missouri Wing stands regarding certain metrics in comparison with other wings in the region – and there was much the wing could be proud of.The general session ended with an afternoon of learning labs including information on the wing’s new glider program, cadet programs update including information about encampment and the annual cadet competition, how to prepare for a subordinate unit inspection, psychological first aid, corporate aircraft and vehicle management and maintenance, how to properly account for CAP property, and information about CAP’s new small unmanned aircraft system program.The keynote speaker for the Saturday evening awards banquet was CAP National Command CMSgt. Robert Dandridge.  The conference’s honored guest for the afternoon learning labs and banquet was Col. Gordon Meyer, the new Director of Staff for the Missouri Air National Guard.  Col. Meyer takes over from Col. Grace Link, who was the keynote speaker at last year’s wing conference banquet.  Col. Link was recently appointed as the executive director of the Missouri Veterans Commission by Missouri Governor Mike Parson.“The Missouri Wing conference celebrated another big year of service to community, state, and nation and I enjoyed the various sessions provided during the morning agenda. Similarly, the conference provided an opportunity for members to gain education, networking, and fun,” said Command CMSgt Dandridge.  “It was great to see our volunteer members being recognized for their achievements throughout the past year as we also rejoiced in another milestone anniversary this year — the Civil Air Patrol’s 70 years as the official civilian auxiliary of the United States Air Force.”Special guests throughout the conference weekend included: Col. Erica Williams, North Central Region Deputy Chief of Staff, Professional Development; Col. David Winters, North Central Region Deputy Chief of Staff, Cadet Programs; SMSgt. Rick Franz, North Central Region Deputy Chief of Staff, Logistics; Chaplain (Lt. Col.) Donald Mikitta, North Central Region Chaplain; Lt. Col. Bonnie Braun, North Central Region Drug Demand Reduction Coordinator; Lt. Col. Anna-Marie Bistodeau, North Central Region Historian; and Col. Art Formanek, Arkansas Wing Commander.“Our annual conference was an outstanding opportunity to recognize the successes of Missouri Wing’s members, units, and programs over the last year,” said Col. John O’Neill, Missouri wing commander.  “It’s through these individual efforts that the wing can continue its long tradition of supporting the people and communities of Missouri in times of need.”Highlights from the conference included:• The presence of three former Missouri Wing commanders (alphabetically, Cols. John Mais, Erica Williams, and Bill Winkert, Sr.); former Ohio Wing commander Col. David Winters; as well as former Middle East Region commander Col. Gene Hartman.• Recognition of the following Missouri Wing members for their participation in CAP’s Hurricane Harvey response (alphabetically by grade): Col. Gene Hartman; Lt. Cols. Esther Grupenhagen and Austin Worcester; Majs. Jack Gray and Bobby Redfield; Capts. Stan Edwards, Carroll “Pete” Pilcher, and Timothy Volk; 1st Lts. Robert Dueck, Steve Meinzen, and Sampath Samarasinghe; and 2d Lt. Ryan Maichel.• A. Scott Crossfield Award to Capt. Katrina Everhart, Missouri Wing Director of Aerospace Education.• Gill Robb Wilson Award to (alphabetically by grade): Lt. Cols. Raun Hamilton, Charles “Keith” Harter, Johnnie Nichols, Charles Stone, and Austin Worcester; Majs. Joseph St. Clair and Jennifer Smith; and SMSgt. Robert Miller.• And a special award presented to Col. John O’Neill, a retired Army NCO, from CAP National Command CMSgt. Dandridge for his support of CAP’s NCO program.Annual Missouri Wing unit award winners included:• Social Media Use Unit of the Year: Wentzville Composite Squadron.• Unit with the Most Flight Hours per Pilot: Wentzville Composite Squadron.• Aerospace Activity of the Year: Wentzville Composite Squadron; in recognition of their trip to the Strategic Air Command & Aerospace Museum in Ashland, Nebraska.• Squadron Ground Team of the Year: Wentzville Composite Squadron.• Quality Cadet Unit Awards (alphabetically): Ft. Leonard Wood Composite Squadron, Harry S Truman Composite Squadron, Lake Ozark Regional Composite Squadron, Lees Summit Composite Squadron, Platte Valley Composite Squadron, St. Louis Composite Squadron 1, Table Rock Lake Composite Squadron, Wentzville Composite Squadron.
Annual Missouri Wing individual award winners included:• Legislative Squadron Member of the Year: State Senator (Maj.) Wayne Wallingford, Missouri Legislative Squadron.• Government Relations Officer of the Year: Capt. David Chilenski, Gateway Senior Squadron.• Character Development Instructor of the Year: SMSgt. Charline O’Neill, Ft. Leonard Wood Composite Squadron.• Squadron Chaplain of the Year: Chaplain (Lt. Col.) Mark Lenneville, Table Rock Lake Composite Squadron.• Senior Chaplain of the Year: Chaplain (Lt. Col.) Leonard Hale, Platte Valley Composite Squadron.• Professional Development Officer of the Year: Chaplain (Lt. Col.) Leonard Hale, Platte Valley Composite Squadron.• Historian Officer of the Year: Maj. Lin Redfield, Table Rock Lake Composite Squadron.• Administration Officer of the Year: SMSgt. Bob Miller, Missouri Wing HQ.• Transportation Officer of the Year: Maj. Adam Daubach, Wentzville Composite Squadron.• Public Affairs Officer of the Year: 2d Lt. Jeremy Darling, Excelsior Springs Composite Squadron.
• Property Manager of the Year: Col. John Mais, Missouri Wing HQ.• Director of Finance Officer of the Year: Lt. Col. David Sewell, Missouri Wing HQ.• Finance Officer of the Year: Maj. David Futch, Platte Valley Composite Squadron.• Drug Demand Reduction Officer of the Year: Capt. William Westfall, Ft. Leonard Wood Composite Squadron.• Communicator of the Year: Maj. Steve Vogt, Mineral Area Senior Squadron.• Incident Staff Member of the Year: 1st Lt. Sampath Samarasinghe, Harry S Truman Composite Squadron.• Incident Commander Officer of the Year: Maj. Alan Altis, Excelsior Springs Composite Squadron.• Information Technology Officer of the Year: 2d Lt. Billy Preston, Missouri Wing HQ.• Advanced Technology Officer of the Year: 1st Lt. Jim Gregg, Gateway Senior Squadron.• Safety Officer of the Year: 1st Lt. Craig Thomas, Wentzville Composite Squadron.• Inspector General Officer of the Year: Lt. Col. Dan Ranson, Missouri Wing HQ.• Aircraft Manager of the Year: Capt. Jim Dockins, Charles R. Long Senior Squadron.• Aircrew Member of the Year: 1st Lt. Robert Dueck, Gateway Senior Squadron.• Orientation Pilot of the Year: 1st Lt. Robert Dueck, Gateway Senior Squadron (34 O-rides).• Pilot with the Most Flight Hours: 1st Lt. Robert Dueck, Gateway Senior Squadron (147.9 flight hours).Only a partial list of annual wing awardees was named at the weekend’s banquet.  The remaining wing award winners will be announced at the upcoming wing conference to be held in March of 2019, at the Capitol Plaza Hotel in Jefferson City, Missouri, in conjunction with the wing commander change-of-command ceremony and the North Central Region conference.

article headline: Editorial: Cracks on I-44, and in the funding structure for Missouri highways
body text:
Drivers who regularly use the stretch of Interstate 44 between Shrewsbury and Hampton avenues have every reason to be outraged by the appearance of cracks on a newly renovated overpass that was only reopened a year ago. Can Missouri taxpayers return it and get their money back?A few cracks are normal. The unusual number of cracks in this project is a clear sign of a botched job. The Missouri Department of Transportation was quick on Tuesday to note that the cracks are barely the thickness of a credit card, as if to suggest that there’s nothing for folks to worry about. But if the words of Tom Blair, the district engineer for MoDOT, are to be taken seriously, there’s plenty to worry about.“I’ve never seen anything like this in my 25 years at MoDOT,” he told the Post-Dispatch’s Mark Schlinkmann.

As if to underscore the seriousness, westbound I-44 between Hampton and Shrewsbury avenues will have to shut down this weekend so work crews can seal the cracks. At the same time, major ongoing work on the eastbound half of I-44, just east of Shrewsbury, will force traffic down to the use of a single lane. The inconvenience to truckers and travelers will be unfathomable.Anyone who regularly drives this stretch in either direction can attest to the massive inconvenience resulting from years of much-needed upgrades to improve safety and reverse the steady deterioration that accompanies aging infrastructure. But the renewed and reopened parts were never supposed to be part of this plan. Someone screwed up, big time.
The contractor in question, KCI Construction, wasn’t responding to requests for comment. KCI and its subcontractors are receiving $16 million for the upgrade project’s bridge and paving work.
Despite justifiable public frustration, perhaps this is the time to consider the compromises MoDOT is being forced to make as the state’s road and bridge infrastructure deteriorates while funding fails to keep pace. Highway maintenance has been funded through a 17 cents-per-gallon fuel tax that has not been increased in two decades. The Legislature has consistently punted when presented with the cold, hard financial facts about the state’s pressing infrastructure needs.The Nov. 6 election was Missourians’ last great hope for a solution. Ballot Proposition D would have raised the fuel tax by 10 cents over four years to fund those infrastructure improvements. It had Gov. Mike Parson’s strong support, yet it failed — almost certainly because it was badly worded.The cracks on I-44 require investigation and public answers from all responsible parties. But the symbolism of their discovery, just as the Prop D vote was being decided, shouldn’t be lost on anyone. Rest assured, there will be far more cracks and far greater inconveniences to come unless the state comes up with a long-term funding answer.

article headline: Schatz, Legislature take aim at undoing amendment
body text:
The editorial "Missouri's new agenda" (Nov. 13) lauds Gov. Mike Parson's and new Senate President Pro Tem Dave Schatz's desire for conciliatory politics. But Schatz's record on workforce development, for example, is well-defined by his support for "right to work" and lowering Missouri prevailing wages.Also of concern is Schatz's dislike for the "Clean Missouri" amendment. The editorial noted that Schatz "has made  clear he's no fan of the ... proposition to reduce lobbyist influence and revise the way legislative districts are drawn." This is not surprising, given his leadership in accepting lobbyist gifts; he's currently No. 2 on the list.

According to the Missouri Ethics Commission website, Schatz has garnered $12,400 in gifts, including $800 to see the Missouri vs. Illinois basketball game last year and $450 for two Cardinals games and $400 for three rounds of golf just this year. Two years ago, he took a nearly $4,000 all-expenses-paid trip to Israel on the cuff of a St. Louis religious organization. Nice work if you can get it.
According to the Post-Dispatch ("Challenge likely for ethics overhaul," Nov. 12), Schatz said of the "Clean Missouri" initiative, "I think it's a major concern." The article noted the amendment would "limit lobbyist gifts to no more than $5." So, unless he takes immediate action, it looks like Schatz will be watching the Cardinals next year from the bleachers instead of the executive suites.
While Missouri amendments are guidelines to craft laws, the Legislature also has some authority to undo them. Remember the gambling revenue that could only go to schools? They found a way around that. Now, some legislators (like Schatz) and lobbyist groups (like the Missouri Chamber of Commerce) are ready to undo the "Clean Missouri" amendment.Terry Beckmeyer  •  New Haven

article headline: Save Jefferson County castle as a state park
body text:
It would be a historical disaster for the state of Missouri and Jefferson County leaders to allow the wasting away of Kennett castle ("A Jefferson County castle is about to close — even to the few allowed to enter," Nov. 10).

Gov. Mike Parson, the Legislature and the state parks department should step in to determine how this jewel could be saved as a state park. There is just too much history associated with it to ignore.

Dana Spitzer  •  Kirkwood

article headline: State Treasurer Eric Schmitt to become Missouri AG after Hawley's election to U.S. Senate
31 St. Louis lifesavers awarded medals by governor
Editorial: In a state still reeling from Greitens' chaos, a solid choice for attorney general
body text:
Gov. Mike Parson is making sound choices in the job he inherited after former Gov. Eric Greitens’ scandal-plagued administration ended June 1. Parson’s appointment Tuesday of state Treasurer Eric Schmitt, a fellow Republican, to be Missouri’s new attorney general offers hope that the state’s top lawyer will be someone actually dedicated to the job.Soon-to-be-former Attorney General Josh Hawley was never quite there, having turned his focus to this year’s U.S. Senate campaign soon after his 2016 election. Hawley’s Nov. 6 defeat of Sen. Claire McCaskill, D-Mo., means he will head for Washington in January. All indications are that Schmitt is a serious public servant who will treat the attorney general’s office as the vital one it is and not just another rung in a climb up the political ladder.

Parson now will have to fill Schmitt’s treasurer’s seat, which sets up an unusual scenario: Four of Missouri’s six non-federal statewide offices — governor, lieutenant governor, attorney general and treasurer — will be filled by people who weren’t elected to those offices. This disconcerting situation is an ongoing repercussion from Greitens’ brief, disastrous reign.Schmitt didn’t receive the editorial board’s 2016 endorsement for treasurer. We opted for his Democratic opponent, Judy Baker, who we argued had more relevant experience. But we also noted Schmitt’s positive attributes, including his history of bipartisanship as a legislator and his leadership in sponsoring post-Ferguson municipal court reforms. His performance as state treasurer has been a picture of quiet competence.

That should mark a welcome shift at the attorney general’s office, which Hawley politicized to spotlight attention-grabbing and divisive national issues — including dragging Missouri into a multistate lawsuit attempting to kill the Affordable Care Act — while neglecting less flashy but more crucial functions, like going after illegal polluters. An exodus of experienced litigators from the office was widely blamed on low morale under Hawley, whose ideological fervor and ambitions for higher office were quickly obvious.Parson’s choice of Schmitt is the kind of level-headed decision-making Missouri is learning to expect from the new governor, who has proven to be his chaotic predecessor’s opposite in just about every way. Parson earlier appointed state Senate Majority Leader Mike Kehoe to succeed him as lieutenant governor, another solid choice. It’s safe to assume Parson’s eventual decision on the new state treasurer will be a responsible one.Still, it’s a disturbing statement about what one unfit officeholder like Greitens can do to a state’s leadership landscape that, months later, we’re looking at having most statewide offices held by people the voters didn’t put there. Missouri voters’ choices in the 2016 election serve as a reminder of how important it is to prioritize substance over style and dedicated public servants over ladder-climbers.

article headline: Editorial: Parson, new majority leader signal meeting of the minds on priorities
body text:
Gov. Mike Parson has a new apparent ally in his effort to get lawmakers in Jefferson City focused on his administration’s top priorities. State Sen. Dave Schatz, R-Sullivan, is the incoming Senate president pro tem after being elected majority leader last week. Schatz immediately made clear that he shares Parson’s goals of enhancing bipartisan cooperation while focusing on “workforce development, infrastructure investment.”Missouri is at one of those rare crossroads where both parties can find significant grounds for agreement. Democrats should have few arguments against efforts to boost urban employment and fix the state’s decaying roads and bridges. This is Missouri’s turnaround moment after the chaos and division fomented by Eric Greitens, the disgraced former Republican governor who seemed to make it his mission to thwart political moderation and bipartisan cooperation.Enough already. Parson and Schatz appear to be making healthy and concerted efforts to reduce partisan tension and restore a businesslike atmosphere in Jefferson City. “We hope to have great working relationships with both sides of the aisle,” Schatz said last week.

Likewise, the Senate minority leader, Gina Walsh of Bellefontaine, noted the close working relationship she had with Parson when he was a state senator. Though “philosophically we’re not often on the same page,” Walsh says, the friendship between the two “is an example of agreeing to disagree and still maintain a relationship to work through the things we can agree on. And I really believe that Missourians want that from their elected officials.”Parson seems to have good intentions and is committed to restoring vitality to Missouri’s most troubled urban areas. He outlined his focus on workforce development and infrastructure during a Sept. 7 meeting with this editorial board. The Democratic mayors of Missouri’s two largest cities — St. Louis and Kansas City — joined him.
Workforce development, he said, means adequately training young workers to meet the skills requirements of area employers, especially those in high-tech fields. Opportunities to put more and more St. Louisans to work in the Cortex innovation district and new National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency western headquarters will be lost if schools and professional training centers aren’t giving them the skills that employers need.
Last week’s defeat of Proposition D, which would have boosted fuel taxes to fund highway and bridge upgrades, makes it even more imperative that the Legislature find ways to fund infrastructure improvements.The upcoming legislative session in January will undoubtedly include some pronounced political differences. Schatz, for example, has made clear he’s no fan of the voter-approved Amendment 1 “Clean Missouri” proposition to reduce lobbyist influence and revise the way legislative districts are drawn.It’s up to him to ensure that such differences prove to be the rare exception to an otherwise cooperative and productive session, now that the Greitens mess is behind us.

article headline: Gas tax defeat means Missouri lawmakers will be seeking money for roads
body text:
Missouri voters’ rejection of a gasoline tax increase last week leaves state officials scrambling again for a successful route to solving the Missouri Department of Transportation’s chronic money problems.The measure, Proposition D, was defeated by a vote of about 54 percent to 46 percent. The gradual 10-cent-a-gallon hike carried only in St. Louis city, three metro Kansas City counties and four outstate.Rejection by voters in St. Louis, St. Charles, Jefferson and Franklin counties came despite bipartisan support from the top elected leaders in each one.

They joined Republican Gov. Mike Parson, Democratic Mayor Lyda Krewson and a long list of business and labor groups on the campaign.The loss followed the defeat in 2014 of a statewide sales tax hike for transportation also put before voters by the Legislature. More than 59 percent voted against that proposal.“I am sitting here kind of dumbfounded as to what do we do next” to deal with road and bridge funding needs, said state Sen. Dave Schatz, R-Sullivan, a key player in crafting the defeated measure.But Schatz, who will likely take over as Senate president pro tem when the Legislature reconvenes in January, said he and other state leaders intend to make transportation funding a priority next session — seeing it as a key to economic growth.He said he is meeting with Parson, Lt. Gov. Mike Kehoe, the incoming Missouri House leadership and MoDOT officials to try to come up with a proposal to the Legislature to address at least some of the estimated $825 million a year in unfunded road and bridge needs.Kehoe said the same.“I believe most Missourians feel we do have a shortage in funding for the highways,” Kehoe said. “We just haven’t been able to coalesce around the solution.”The two, in separate interviews, said at this point they weren’t pushing any particular ideas.And it’s unclear now if another ballot proposal would emerge or if the Legislature could be asked to simply pass a more limited revenue infusion itself.Under the state’s Hancock Amendment, tax and fee hikes raising revenue below a certain level — about $101 million last year, according to a report from the state auditor’s office — don’t have to go before voters. Schatz said the allowable level is now more in the $80 million range.Some lawmakers interviewed said increasing various license and registration fees might be one possibility to raise some revenue for MoDOT.Another fix conceivably could have the Legislature itself raise the gas tax incrementally (2 cents for one year would raise about $80 million) without putting it before voters.
But many lawmakers probably would be loath to do that so soon after Tuesday’s rejection at the ballot box. ”You have to respect the voters,” said Rep. Jean Evans, R-Manchester, who supported Prop D.Another idea, said Rep. Kevin Corlew, R-Kansas City, might be assigning to road projects some of a big increase in state revenue considered likely to occur following a U.S. Supreme Court ruling last June that widened the reach of state taxes on online purchases.Giving MoDOT a cut from taxes if Missouri legalizes sports betting also could be looked at, another legislator speculated.Corlew, who lost his own re-election bid last week, had chaired a bipartisan transportation task force which held hearings across Missouri last year and studied the funding issue in depth.The panel, which Schatz served as vice chairman, concluded that a gas tax hike was the best idea for the immediate future. That’s in part because it’s a user fee and paid by both Missourians and out-of-staters passing through on state roads.
Schatz said it’s possible that lawmakers might at some point consider a system in which motorists paid a fee based on vehicle miles driven, not on gasoline purchases.The task force report said that would be in response to increased use of electric or hybrid vehicles and could either be in addition or in lieu of a gas tax.Meanwhile, Kehoe and Schatz said they oppose toll roads, an idea that’s been raised on and off for decades — especially for rebuilding and widening Interstate 70 between the outer edges of metro St. Louis and the Kansas City area.Kehoe said 60 percent of the state’s population lives within 30 miles north or south of I-70 and “before you get to the letter L in toll, they start freaking out.” Moreover, the Legislature last year went on record against the idea.Sen. Bill Eigel, R-Weldon Spring, who opposed Prop D, said a majority of voters simply didn’t believe raising taxes was needed to address MoDOT’s funding issues.The convoluted wording of the proposition, which didn’t refer to legislators’ plans to channel most of the added money to MoDOT, could have been a factor as well.Eigel suggested that the Legislature consider shifting to roads some other existing state revenue, arguing that this is “a prioritization problem” and not “a money problem.”He also said the Legislature should discuss “what is the right size and scope” of the state road system. That was an apparent reference to proposals to shift some smaller lettered state roads to county responsibility.But Corlew said that wouldn’t save much. Under a state ban on unfunded mandates, he noted, the state would have to send counties money to cover their extra road costs. He added that counties would lose “economies of scale” achieved when MoDOT maintains those roads statewide.

article headline: BenFred: Compared to other markets, St. Louis should look even better to MLS
Republicans pick next leader of Missouri Senate
The gas tax won't go up, so what happens to roads and bridges?
body text:
A vehicle follows a detour for a closed road near the state Capitol in Jefferson City, Missouri, on Friday, Nov. 2, 2018. AP photo. 


David A. Lieb


The short answer? Triage.State officials had called the gas tax that Missouri voters rejected Tuesday a first step toward meeting more than $800 million a year in road and bridge needs. The measure would have raised the current state tax (17 cents a gallon) by 2.5 cents each year until it hit 27 cents in 2022. 

It would have assigned an estimated $123 million a year, when fully in effect, directly to cities and counties for local road and bridge improvements and $288 million to the Missouri Highway Patrol.
That's a significant amount of money transportation officials will just have do without, MoDOT Director Patrick McKenna said Tuesday night.
So now, it means "setting priorities among the many equally important transportation projects will be a tough job with limited resources," he said.Infrastructure remains a top priority for Gov. Mike Parson's administration. Parson had traveled throughout the state to campaign for Proposition D.A spokesperson for the governor could not immediately be reached about Parson's next steps for road and bridge improvement.

article headline: The Hawley win could have domino effect on Missouri Republicans
body text:
JEFFERSON CITY • For the second time in his short tenure as Missouri’s chief executive, Gov. Mike Parson may be appointing someone to a statewide office .If Missouri voters elect Republican Josh Hawley to the U.S. Senate on Tuesday, Parson will be charged with filling the vacant attorney general post, just as he filled the lieutenant governor’s seat after he took over as governor on June 1.On Monday, however, Parson and other top GOP officials were staying tight-lipped on any deliberations they might be having over picking someone to serve out the remaining two years of Hawley’s term if he beats Democratic U.S. Sen. Claire McCaskill.

“The governor is very much focused on ensuring Josh Hawley is successful in the election Tuesday,” Parson spokesman Steele Shippy said.Parson was on the campaign trail with Hawley and other top Republicans Monday urging voters to back the 38-year-old candidate in a tight race that could determine which party controls the U.S. Senate.Aides said no decision has been made about the appointment process and there is no short list of potential replacements.To qualify as the state’s chief legal officer, the attorney general must be a citizen of the United States, a resident of Missouri for one year and be licensed to practice law.Earlier speculation had former Missouri House Speaker Todd Richardson, an attorney from Poplar Bluff, as a possible pick, but Parson last month appointed Richardson to a $225,000-per-year job overseeing the state’s Medicaid program.Republican Treasurer Eric Schmitt, a former state senator from Glendale who is in his first term in statewide office, has been active on the campaign trail for Hawley, speaking last week at Hawley events in Chesterfield and La Plata.He also endorsed a ballot initiative last week to raise the state’s 17-cent per gallon gas tax by 10 cents, which has been championed by Parson as a way to rebuild the state’s roads and bridges.But Schmitt said Monday he said he’s not lobbying for the appointment.“I’m focused on getting Josh elected,” Schmitt told the Post-Dispatch.Republican Lt. Gov. Mike Kehoe, who was appointed by Parson to take over his old job, said he’s unaware of any front-runners for the attorney general post.
“I haven’t been involved in any behind-the-scenes conversations. I don’t think the governor would think that’s appropriate anyway,” Kehoe said.Republican Secretary of State Jay Ashcroft, also an attorney, said he doesn’t plan to discuss the opening with Parson.“That’s up to the governor. I’m not going to tell the governor what to do,” Ashcroft said.
Another name in the mix is St. Louis attorney William Corrigan Jr., who ran as a Republican for St. Louis county executive in 2010. Corrigan, who works at the Armstrong Teasdale law firm, was among those vying to become U.S. attorney in Missouri’s eastern district last year.Attorney Bev Randles, who was beaten by Parson in the 2016 Republican primary election for lieutenant governor, also could be considered. A Sikeston native, Randles now practices law in Kansas City. Randles served on the board of the Missouri Club for Growth, a political action committee funded largely by retired St. Louis financier Rex Sinquefield.A potential internal selection could happen with Darrell Moore, a former Greene County prosecutor who is serving as Hawley’s $130,000-per-year deputy attorney general.If either Schmitt or Ashcroft were chosen, that would open up another statewide office for Parson to fill, potentially leaving four of the five statewide offices filled by someone who was not elected to that particular post during the 2016 election.Parson, for example, was elected as lieutenant governor, but took over when former Gov. Eric Greitens resigned amid scandal.He appointed Kehoe as his successor on June 18.Editor's note: This article was published in print on Nov. 6.

article headline: Hawley knocks off McCaskill in bid for Missouri's U.S. Senate seat
body text:
Updated at 11 p.m.JEFFERSON CITY • Missouri Attorney General Josh Hawley is headed to the U.S. Senate after handily beating Democratic U.S. Sen. Claire McCaskill on Tuesday.In a race that saw massive amounts of outside spending, Hawley was poised to win by a 55-42 margin buoyed largely by strong support in rural areas of the state.

He spoke to a crowd gathered in Springfield moments after McCaskill conceded."Tonight the people of Missouri have said we're up to the challenge," Hawley said.. "Tonight the people of Missouri have said we're ready to answer the call at this hour. Tonight the people of Missouri have said we believe in America, we believe that our best days are ahead, we believe in our future and we are ready to fight for it."McCaskill, speaking to supporters in St. Louis, said there were some positive moments to the evening, including Democrats taking control of the U.S. House."Obviously we fell short and that's disappointing," said McCaskill, who will leave after two terms in the Senate.

    var pymParent1000 = new pym.Parent('map-us-senator', '//graphics.stltoday.com/apps/elections/livemaps/missouri.html?race=missouri-us-senate', {});
McCaskill decried the nastiness of the campaign, but said she's been blessed to have worked in an interesting job seeking to help people."I want to save my biggest thanks for the people of Missouri," McCaskill said. "This state drives me crazy but I love every corner of it."Hawley, 38, tied himself closely to President Donald Trump, who won the state by 19 point in 2016. Trump contacted Hawley to congratulate him as the votes were being counted.Republican Sen. Roy Blunt lauded Trump’s campaigning on Hawley’s behalf.“No president in the history of the country has made this kind of effort for a ticket he is not on,” Blunt said.While he noted the loss of the House of Representatives, Blunt said the pickup of several Senate seats was significant because an individual senator’s leverage over legislation goes down.“You can do a whole lot more with 53 Republican or 54 Republican senators than you can with 51,” Blunt said.EARLIERUpdated at 10:25 p.m.Jefferson City • Although votes were still being counted in Democratic strongholds, the chairman of the Missouri Republican Party believes Attorney General Josh Hawley has won one of the most pivotal Senate races in the nation.In a statement, Missouri GOP chief Todd Graves said Hawley's vote totals are a carry over from 2016, when voters gave President Donald Trump a resounding 19 point victory."Tonight, we kept the winning streak going with Josh Hawley's incredible defeat of Claire McCaskill," Graves said."Months of hard work, knocking on doors, and tireless efforts to get out the vote across the state contributed to this win. I couldn't be prouder of the hundreds of volunteers and staff that sacrificed their time and resources to make this happen, and I'm honored to call Josh Hawley our next Senator from the great state of Missouri," Graves added.With more than half of the precincts reporting, Hawley held a 59 percent to 37 percent lead over the two term senator.Hawley tied himself closely to Trump during the high profile campaign that saw more than $76 million in outside spending, much of that from leaders in the Senate on both sides of the aisle.In Springfield, at Hawley's election night party, former Lieutenant Gov. Peter Kinder told the crowd that with Kansas City in and most of St. Louis County in “we don’t think Claire McCaskill can climb the wall that outstate Missouri is delivering.” “You and I both know this should have happened six years ago,” Kinder said.Moments later he came back out to tell the crowd Fox News had called the race for Hawley. The room erupted.Updated at 10:10 p.m.JEFFERSON CITY • Attorney General Josh Hawley continued to hang on to a sizable lead in his bid to oust Democratic U.S. Sen. Claire McCaskill Tuesday.Although Missouri's reliably Democratic urban areas were still not fully counted, attendees at McCaskill's election night watch party were showing concern as the results rolled in.As of 10 p.m., Hawley was up by a 60-37 margin.“I’m trying to stay as optimistic as I can,” said Laura Rossmann, of St. Louis County, who watched the results with her hand covering her face at the McCaskill party’sA groan went through the crowd when it was projected that Democrats would not be able to take control of the Senate.St. Louis Mayor Lyda Krewson stopped by the McCaskill party about 9:30 p.m. to show support for McCaskill.“All we can do is wait now,” Krewson said. “And hope that the senator will get another six years to represent Missouri.”In Springfield, where a crowd had gathered for Hawley, top state officials stopped by in support of their GOP candidate, who was the recipient of multiple visits by President Donald Trump over the course of the campaign.Gov. Mike Parson revved up the crowd around 10 p.m., telling them Hawley would truly represent them and support “Christian” and “moral” values in the Senate.EARLIERUpdated at 9:25 p.m.JEFFERSON CITY • Republican Attorney General Josh Hawley was making a strong showing in rural Missouri Tuesday as vote totals in one of the most closely watched U.S. Senate races continued to trickle in.According to early returns reported by CNN, Hawley was up by 60 percent to 36 percent over Democratic incumbent U.S. Sen. Claire McCaskill.The vote tallies looked to mirror the 2016 election, in which President Donald Trump beat Democrat Hillary Clinton by 19 points. Rural areas were strongly red. Vote totals in Missouri's urban areas were not complete.Trump's presence in the race drove big turnout numbers in some precincts, where long lines meant the polls stayed open well after their 7 p.m. scheduled close.In St. Louis, Stephen Webber, chair of the Missouri Democratic Party, took the stage at the McCaskill watch party at about 9 p.m. to say election officials expected the last vote to be cast around 9:30 p.m.“It’s shaping up to be a typical Missouri election night,” Webber said, adding it would be a long night but they are hoping for good news for McCaskill.Kevin McGilly attended the McCaskill watch party after a week of knocking on 432 doors as a volunteer for the campaign. McGilly traveled from Washington D.C. to volunteer because he said he’s long respected McCaskill and thought it was one of the most important races in the country.“Whatever ways this goes Claire is a survivor,” McGilly said.In Springfield, where Hawley was holding his watch party, Frank Gillham of Springfield talked enthusiastically about Trump.
“Half of my Teamster buddies supported Trump,” he said. “They still do.”Hawley is more of an unknown for Gillham. But he took a similar leap of faith with Trump and “has never seen the country turn around this quick.”“You just have to trust he’ll do the right thing,” Gillham said of Hawley.Missouri Treasurer Eric Schmidt addressed the Springfield crowd shortly after 9 p.m., and said models based on rural vote tallies made Hawley’s camp “cautiously optimistic” about the night’s outcome.EARLIERUpdated at 8:45 p.m.JEFFERSON CITY • With an estimated 16 percent of the vote counted, Republican Attorney General Josh Hawley is leading Democrat Claire McCaskill in her bid for a third term in the U.S. Senate, according to one report.With Missouri Secretary of State Jay Ashcroft holding off on releasing vote counts until all polls are closed, CNN is reporting that Hawley is up by a 58-38 margin.The vote totals show Hawley running strong in rural areas of the state that helped propel President Donald Trump to a 19-point victory in 2016.Meanwhile, the New York Times reports McCaskill with a lead of about 5 percentage points. The Times relied on different county election data than did CNN.The Missouri Secretary of State's Office is keeping the official tallies secret until all voters are able to cast ballots. "We are estimating the final vote cast will be after 9:30 p.m.," the office tweeted at 8:51 p.m. Among the places voters were waiting more than an hour after polls closed: Washington University in St. Louis.Hawley ran much of his campaign on a promise to support the president, while McCaskill argued that she will support Trump initiatives when they make sense for Missourians.Springfield resident Jeremy Boyts, selling "Make America Great Again" hats outside of Hawley’s election night party in Springfield, was confident the night would end well for Republicans. He sees how many people come to rallies for Trump and other candidates when he sets up his merchandise stand.“There is no blue wave. It’s a fallacy,” he said. “The amount of people I see who take off work on a Tuesday to go support Trump or Josh amazes me.”EARLIER
Updated at 7:50 p.m.JEFFERSON CITY • The first unofficial returns in the pivotal race for U.S. Senate in Missouri have been reported, with incumbent Democrat Claire McCaskill leading by a slight margin over Republican challenger Josh Hawley.The 51 percent to 46.5 percent count comes primarily out of Jackson County in the Kansas City region, an area where McCaskill is expected to fare better than her GOP counterpart.The tally represents just 10,755 votes out of an expected turnout of more than 2 million voters.In Springfield, where Hawley is holding his election night party, Will Shafer, sporting a Make America Great Again hat, cast his first vote this year.  The 18-year-old who worked on the presidential campaigns of both Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and later President Donald Trump, wasn’t ready to write off McCaskill.“In the past, I felt super-confident... I don’t today,” he said. “Claire, I have to give her credit, she did a good job of making herself look moderate.”His “jam-packed” polling place in Lampe, near Branson, made him feel better.“It made me more confident voting this morning,” he said.McCaskill supporters also were nervous as they began to gather in a ballroom of the Marriott St. Louis Grand hotel in downtown St. Louis after the polls closed.“I couldn’t sleep last night because I was so anxious, I don’t know if I can take another gut-punch like the 2016 election,” said McCaskill supporter Anne Schrupp, 30, a nurse from St. Louis, as she watched the results start to trickle in. “Trump was a wake up call for me.”EARLIERJEFFERSON CITY • With control of the U.S. Senate on the line, Democratic U.S. Sen. Claire McCaskill and Republican state Attorney General Josh Hawley closed out their often ferocious campaigns Tuesday hoping they’ve convinced their supporters to get to the polls.Fueled by over $76 million in outside spending, the marquee race in Missouri has been in a virtual tie for months, according to polls.McCaskill, who is running for a third term in a state where President Donald Trump won by 19 points in 2016, has focused on health care and Hawley’s attempt to get rid of Obamacare as she’s traversed the state in what will likely be her last election.

McCaskill, 65, has described herself as a moderate who also supports increased border security. She ran an ad in the closing week of the race trying to distance herself from what she called “crazy Democrats.”Hawley, 38, who is serving his first term as the state’s chief legal officer, has sought to cast McCaskill as out of touch with a state that has turned red in recent elections.He has made McCaskill’s votes against the confirmation of Supreme Court Justices Neil Gorsuch and Brett Kavanaugh a key component of his campaign, arguing that she won’t support Trump on major issues.Before making final campaign stops, Hawley voted in Columbia while McCaskill voted in Kirkwood.Those votes followed a day-long barnstorming tour by Hawley and top Missouri Republicans on Monday culminating in a rally with Trump in Cape Girardeau.McCaskill appeared in Columbia Monday with veterans, saying she had worked to improve veterans' livelihoods since taking office in 2007.Hawley is in Springfield awaiting vote tallies, while McCaskill will be in St. Louis Tuesday night.Jacob  Barker contributed to this story from Springfield.
