article headline: Voters say yes to 'Clean Missouri' ethics overhaul, $12 an hour minimum wage by 2023
Vote yes on Missouri’s Proposition D for safety and savings
body text:
Missouri’s population and economy are growing, which is great news for the strength and vitality of the state, but it also means our highways and residents are feeling the pressure — literally. Since 1996, drivers have been paying 17 cents per gallon in fuel tax to maintain Missouri’s roads and bridges. Meanwhile, the cost of construction materials, just like bread and milk, have tripled. Due to these rising inflation and construction costs, this 17-cent fuel tax that we have had for over 20 years now equates to seven cents in purchasing power.Residents are feeling the heat as they spend an average of $604 annually in vehicle repairs due to poorly maintained roadways, compared with $533 per driver nationwide. This money could instead be going toward our roads and bridges to make them safer and stronger. Our state’s highways need new investment in infrastructure because of new innovations in safety design of highways. In April, the American Society of Civil Engineers Missouri Sections (Kansas City and St. Louis Sections) released the 2018 Report Card for Missouri’s Infrastructure. The Report Card assessed infrastructure categories and assigned Missouri with the overall grade of “C-.” The Roads category received a D+, which means they are poor and at risk and the Bridges category received the grade of a C, which means they are mediocre and require attention. Missouri has the 7th largest system of roads and bridges in the country but ranks 49th in funding to maintain these investments, with only Alaska below us.Proposition D is a statutory referendum to fund Missouri state law enforcement and maintenance for highways, bridges, roads, and streets, which will be possible by increasing the motor fuel tax by 2 1/2 cents per gallon annually for four years beginning July 1, 2019. This initiative will cost the average Missourian only $1.28 per month initially and will improve the state’s roads and bridges. These improvements will save time spent in traffic, save money on maintenance costs, and allow $1 billion in federal matching funds for states and bridges. The Missouri State Highway Patrol is currently funded by the fuel tax. Prop D will provide new funding for highway patrol, which will free up current fuel tax revenues to go toward funding for construction and maintenance of roads and bridges. It will also ensure state law enforcement will have the funding needed to effectively protect the public. This initiative is a win-win-win.

While Missouri has made major strides in roadway safety, there is still work to be done. The American Society of Civil Engineers Missouri Sections offered a few solutions in the 2018 Report Card for Missouri’s Infrastructure, which provided steps we can take to work on how to raise Missouri’s infrastructure grades. Solutions including investment and preparing for the future. We argued that a long-term revenue stream for transportation must be identified in order to improve our competitiveness and keep residents safe. The full report card may be found online at infrastructurereportcard.org/Missouri.
As civil engineer experts, we are stewards of public health, safety and welfare as we plan, design, construct and maintain our infrastructure networks, which is why we endorse Prop D.On Tuesday , Missouri voters can have the final say on making roads and streets safer by voting yes on Prop D to ensure safety on roads and money back in the pockets of the driver. Missouri’s transportation infrastructure, with 34,000 miles of road and well over 2,000 bridges is a vital factor in our state’s economic growth. For these reasons, Prop D is a bipartisan effort supported by Gov. Mike Parson, Lt. Gov. Mike Kehoe, St. Louis County Executive Steve Stenger and St. Louis Mayor Lyda Krewson. Other supporters include a statewide coalition that includes business owners, labor, city and county leaders, farmers, law enforcement supporters, and professional associations.
The future of Missouri’s infrastructure investment is up to voters. Mark yes on Proposition D to build a better and safer future for Missouri. For more information on the on costs and community benefits, go to SaferMO.com.Chad Schrand is president of the St. Louis Section of the  American Society of Civil Engineers. He is currently the Structural Building Business Unit leader at Horner & Shiffrin Inc. in St. Louis.

Quaker Continues Strategic Growth with Land Purchase for New Manufacturing Plant in Eldon, MO
body text:
Freeburg, Mo.––Quaker Windows and Doors continues its strategic growth and expansion with the purchase of 127 acres in Eldon, Missouri, where construction has begun on a new 200,000 square foot commercial and architectural products production facility. The land purchased will also allow for the construction of additional manufacturing facilities in the future. “We love it when homegrown Missouri businesses choose to continue growing in our state,” Missouri Governor Mike Parson said. 

 Quaker’s strategic growth and expansion has recently included the opening of a 185,000 square foot facility in January 2018 for high performing wood windows and doors, construction of a new commercial and residential Vinyl facility in March of 2016, expansion of an Insulating Glass Plant in 2017 and the expansion of the ModernVu/M600 Architectural Aluminum Door line in their former wood facility in 2018. “Quaker Windows is at the top of their industry, in terms of both quality and customer service,” says Lt. Governor Mike Kehoe. “Given the continued steady growth of the company, I am certain they were heavily recruited to expand in other states,” he added. “Quaker is a fantastic corporate citizen, and I am pleased that they have chosen to continue to grow their product lines in central Missouri, using central Missouri employees.” Quaker’s current operations consist of their corporate offices along with wood, vinyl, aluminum window and door manufacturing facilities located on two campuses in Freeburg, MO. They currently have more than 950 employees and produce a variety of AAMA certified high performing residential, commercial and architectural window and door products that are delivered nationwide. “We are excited to be bringing new jobs to the Eldon region as part of our strategic growth plans moving forward to support our Customer’s needs and market demand,” says Quaker CEO Kevin Blansett.“This expansion is about growing our commercial and architectural window and door production capacity for years to come, while continuing to enhance our vinyl and wood production capacity on the main campus to effectively meet the growing needs of our lumberyard and residential Customers,” explains Blansett.  
 About QuakerQuaker Windows and Doors will be celebrating 70 years in business in 2019. Headquartered in Freeburg, Missouri, Quaker is a family owned business originally founded by the Knoll family in 1949.  
Quaker, a leading national manufacturer of Aluminum, Wood and Vinyl Windows and Doors for the Architectural, Commercial and Residential New Construction, Replacement, Historic, Blast and Impact Resistant markets. The Quaker window and door product portfolio includes –– Single Hung, Double Hung, Sliding, Awning, Hopper, Casement, Fixed, Impact, Geometric Shapes, Specialty, Bays/ Bows, French Doors, Sliding Doors, Folding Doors and Entry Doors. The complete line of Quaker custom designed products, options and accessories are designed to satisfy projects in a variety of market segment including–– Single Family, Multi-Family, Education, Hotel/Motel, Office, Healthcare, Government, and Assisted Living.  Quaker is an active member of both WDMA, AAMA and an EnergyStar Partner. Quaker also works closely with Architects, State and National Park Services concerning Historic Renovation Design and Tax credit opportunities, in order to ensure that their extensive Historic product offering meets and exceeds standards and guidelines set for Historic projects throughout the country.   Quaker has continually set a very high standard of Quality for all of their products. That dedication to providing the best products in the industry has resulted in continuous Product and System Design Innovations, Green Enrichment Initiatives and a Mission of Continuous Innovation, Improvement, Integrity and Total Customer Satisfaction.  For more information, email Quaker at marketing@QuakerWindows.com, visit our website at www.QuakerWindows.com, or our commercial window division at www.QuakerCommercialWindows.com. You can also contact Quaker at (800) 347-0438.                                                                                ###

Josh Hawley has announced multiple lawsuits and investigations. What has he accomplished?
body text:
JEFFERSON CITY • Gov. Eric Greitens stormed into power the same day Attorney General Josh Hawley took his seat in a suite of offices across from the Capitol. A year passed before Greitens’ administration began to collapse. Greitens made few friends in the capital city. In April, he took aim at Hawley.Hawley had said at a news conference that Greitens likely committed felony computer tampering before taking office. Greitens fired back with a statement saying that Hawley was “better at press conferences than the law.” A little more than a month later, Greitens resigned, retreating to his Warren County lake house.The episode was striking — two young, conservative outsiders trading barbs.

But Greitens is not the only person to question Hawley’s motivations and effectiveness.Adversaries portray Hawley, 38, as a young man in a hurry — someone more interested in headlines than results.Hawley points to accomplishments that range from helping to orchestrate a sex trafficking sting in Springfield, Mo., to launching an initiative seeking to link service members with pro bono legal help.Now that Hawley is running for U.S. Senate against Democrat Claire McCaskill, his two years as attorney general — the only public office he’s ever held — provide the only work sample voters have to judge his effectiveness as an elected leader.AccomplishmentsWhen he took office in early 2017, Hawley oversaw a chaotic office-wide restructuring that was followed by high turnover, the Post-Dispatch reported Sunday.Despite that turnover, Mary Compton, Hawley’s spokeswoman, cited several accomplishments, including: settling a lawsuit with the Bridgeton Landfill that Hawley’s predecessor filed; collecting a record amount of Medicaid fraud restitution; and earning more than 100 convictions at the trial court level.Hawley also settled a decadelong legal battle between blind Missourians and the state over the Blind Pension Fund.After reporting by the Columbia Missourian on the state’s sexual assault kit testing backlog, Hawley launched an audit of the problem. He documented 5,424 untested kits, though many police agencies did not respond to questions. His office also landed a federal grant to help ease the backlog.Hawley said his consumer protection section has obtained $30 million for Missourians; it was not immediately clear how that figure compares to past administrations. He praised his prosecutors for their criminal convictions and successful judgments on appeal.“They often do it at less pay than they could get in the private sector,” Hawley said in an interview. “And they’re doing a good job.”Hawley’s new Federalism Unit took 14 actions to torpedo federal laws and regulations, including the Affordable Care Act, the Consumer Finance Protection Bureau and several environmental protections. Some former employees complain the emphasis diverted attention away from more pressing (and less glamorous) state business.The attorney general has made other moves that garnered both praise and criticism.On Aug. 31, Hawley filed a lawsuit seeking to enjoin Branson Duck Boats and Ripley Entertainment from operating the vehicles in Missouri. In July, 17 people died when a duck boat sank in Table Rock Lake in Branson during a storm.The company owners questioned the accuracy of his allegations and insinuated the lawsuit was filed to burnish Hawley’s credentials.“The Attorney General’s suggestion that BDV and Ripley flouted safety concerns in the name of profits is nothing more than baseless hyperbole, aimed at leveraging and stoking passions in the aftermath of this tragedy in an effort to polish the Attorney General’s prosecutorial credentials,” the companies’ attorneys wrote in court documents.“People will fight me, accuse me of things all the time,” Hawley said. “I would just say to the Branson duck boat folks — Duck Boat Vehicles and Ripley Entertainment — they better check their rhetoric and take responsibility for their actions, because they’ve got a long road ahead of them.“I don’t want them operating duck boats anywhere in Missouri,” he added.Hawley also has announced several investigations during his tenure, including one into possible Catholic clergy sex abuse, two related to tech companies Google and Facebook and another related to pharmaceutical companies under allegations of opioid pill pushing. He also announced an investigation into Equifax after a data breach last year.“I’m most proud of standing up to the big and powerful on behalf of the people of Missouri — no matter what, no matter who,” Hawley said. “We’ve done that, whether it’s big pharma, big tech or organized crime — human traffickers, Medicaid fraudsters.”Hawley sued several pharmaceutical companies last summer. The Google and Facebook investigations are ongoing. His Catholic clergy probe involves potentially hundreds of thousands of documents.Joseph Bindbeutel, who served three of Hawley’s predecessors, said he was struck by how many times Hawley has publicized his probes.
“Those investigations are going to take years to complete,” Bindbeutel said, referring specifically to the tech probes. “When you yell them (investigation announcements) from the mountaintops, it makes one wonder, ‘Is this about yelling from the mountaintops, or is this about doing a straight up, legitimate, thorough investigation of an issue?’”Greitens’ ghostsHawley has not updated the public in months on his investigation into Greitens’ former charity, The Mission Continues, and whether Greitens or others illegally used charity resources for personal or political gain.He was also investigating to see whether Greitens or his staff illegally used taxpayer resources for campaign purposes, but it is unclear where that probe stands.Hawley said at an August press gaggle that the probes were ongoing. He has unsurprisingly avoided mention of Greitens on the campaign trail.“Greitens’ resignation handed Hawley a great gift,” said Terry Smith, political science professor at Columbia College. “I’m sure Claire was really sad when he left office. It was going to be a real albatross.”Meanwhile, two private attorneys have continued to probe the Greitens administration. Elad Gross, a former assistant attorney general under Democrat Chris Koster, sued Greitens’ nonprofit, A New Missouri, in June after the dark money group declined to turn over financial information to Gross.
Gross is sparring with Gov. Mike Parson’s office over a $3,618 bill for documents. He sued Parson’s administration last week. He also mailed Hawley’s office a packet explaining why he thinks Hawley can investigate A New Missouri, but the office still contends it cannot.Mark Pedroli, a St. Louis County attorney, sued the Greitens administration in December over Greitens’ use of the text-message destroying smartphone app Confide, which he says violated state records retention laws.While Pedroli continues to gather evidence that he says shows Greitens and his staff broke the law, Hawley’s office said in March it found no evidence of wrongdoing.In another case, Hawley used the merchandising practices law to sue the St. Louis Housing Authority and McCormack Baron Management, which both manage the Clinton-Peabody Housing Complex south of downtown St. Louis.Hawley alleged in his August lawsuit that the housing authority and McCormack Baron fraudulently marketed complexes as habitable, when, in fact, the units were not. He wants the two entities to return rent payments to tenants.Problems at the complex, built in 1942, became widely known after mice invaded the complex last fall. While mice infested an estimated 165 of 358 units last December, the St. Louis Health Department said in August that an estimated six units showed evidence of mice after an inspection that month.The housing authority and McCormack Baron have called the lawsuit unhelpful. Cheryl Lovell, director of the authority, said her staff has worked “tirelessly” to solve the problems on a shoestring budget. She said Hawley did not meet with the housing authority before filing a lawsuit.The housing authority and McCormack Baron also say that Clinton-Peabody has not been able to access federal funds that would allow for interior renovations.Hawley says the criticisms sound like “excuses.”“We are going to hold them accountable no matter how much they kick and scream and make excuses,” he said. “These are people’s homes were talking about.”To Hawley’s critics, the headline-grabbing announcement was just that: a headline-grabbing announcement. The two sides are not even scheduled to appear in court for an initial review until Nov. 13, after the election.“I think it’s more political than anything,” said Sen. Jamilah Nasheed, D-St. Louis. “He’s trying to keep his name out there.”

article headline: Parson names SLU president Pestello to Bi-State/Metro board
Violence down in St. Louis but homicides hold steady. Are tougher penalties for gun crimes the answer?
body text:
ST. LOUIS • Violent crime in the city is down 10 percent compared to last year, St. Louis Police Chief John Hayden said Tuesday, but the homicide rate is fairly constant, with 152 homicides in 2018, compared to 158 at the same time last year.At least half are drug-related, Hayden told members of the city’s Board of Aldermen.There was a flicker of hope in September, when the city was down 25 homicides compared to the previous year, but that shifted after six murders were reported during a particularly violent weekend toward the end of that month. Twenty-eight slayings have been reported in St. Louis since Sept. 23, less than a month ago.

Hayden and St. Louis Public Safety Director Jimmie Edwards provided the numbers as they spoke to members of the Board of Aldermen on Tuesday about the police department’s effort to address crime in St. Louis.They also delivered some more positive news: There have been decreases in robberies and aggravated assaults citywide, the officials said, and police have seized 2,085 guns this year.One specific area where officers have seen progress is in “Hayden’s rectangle,” a trapezoidal area named for the police chief, where law enforcement has focused resources due to its high crime rates. It’s bordered by Goodfellow Boulevard to the west, Vandeventer Avenue to the east, Martin Luther King Drive to the south and West Florissant Avenue to the north.In that rectangle, homicides are down from last year by 13, or 19 percent; robberies are down by 38, or 16 percent; and aggravated assaults with weapons are down by 62, or 11 percent; with violent crime overall down 13 percent, Hayden said.“That strategy is continuing to work,” Hayden said.But many challenges remain, official said. The department is still down more than 130 officers. Witnesses to crimes remain reluctant to come forward for fear of retaliation, making it difficult to close cases. And a lack of state laws to deter gun crimes has forced the police to turn to federal courts to indict some suspects.On Tuesday, Edwards made a new pitch: He wants to see the mandatory minimum sentence for armed criminal action raised from its current ceiling of three years to at least 15 years for nonfatal shootings, and 25 years for fatal shootings.Anyone who commits a felony through the “use, assistance or aid of a dangerous instrument or deadly weapon” in Missouri is also guilty of armed criminal action, in addition to the underlying charge. Edwards said amending this state statue provides a new avenue to crack down on gun crimes in Missouri’s urban areas.
“What I want is for the offender, the person with that gun, to think about the consequences,” Edwards said. “People commit crimes based on risk and reward. What I would like to do is put some teeth in our law and to have this law to address risk and consequences. And the consequences must be significant enough that I am somewhat deterred, or will pause and think about my actions.”Some aldermen expressed concern over that proposal: over its potential effectiveness, if it would lead to higher numbers of incarcerated people, or if it would disproportionately target poor, marginalized communities. Edwards argued it would be applied “irrespective of one’s station in life,” and only to those who intended to do harm with a gun.But it’s unclear whether the idea would get traction in the GOP-led Missouri Legislature, which in 2016 passed a measure allowing gun owners to carry weapons without a state-issued permit, to the chagrin of city officials already facing a region awash with firearms.
“With all due respect to our rural legislators, we don’t shoot turkey and deer and duck with AR-15s and AK-47s in the city of St. Louis,” Edwards said.The public safety director said he has already begun discussions with Missouri Gov. Mike Parson and state legislators to begin pursuing the change, and the next step will be to make sure St. Louis and Kansas City present a united front on the matter.St. Louis Mayor Lyda Krewson and Kansas City Mayor Sly James have already met with Parson in recent months to appeal to him for stronger local control on gun policy, arguing that St. Louis and Kansas City should be able to more tightly regulate guns in their respective regions for the sake of public safety.Parson hasn’t taken a firm stance, but he said he’d keep an open mind should a bill be introduced in the Legislature to address it.In the meantime, St. Louis aldermen on Tuesday asked the police department to begin tracking and reporting the numbers of guns stolen from homes and cars throughout the city the same way they track and report other crimes.{p style=”text-align: center;”}• Crime Tracker: St. Louis city{p style=”text-align: center;”}• Map: St. Louis-area homicides in 2018

article headline: WGU Missouri Added to Eligible Institutions List for Access Missouri Program
body text:
Thanks to bills passed in Missouri’s House and Senate, eligible WGU Missouri students who already enjoy the university’s low-cost tuition are now able to apply for grant money at the state level – making college even more affordable for hundreds statewide. Effective immediately, low-income students attending the online, nonprofit university can apply for funds through Access Missouri, the state’s need-based grant program. WGU Missouri students have always been able to apply for financial aid through the federal student loan program, however, this is the first time students are also eligible to receive funds through Access Missouri since the university was established in 2013 by former Gov. Jay Nixon. The original bills, Senate Bill 682 and House Bill 1267, introduced by Sen. Brian Munzlinger and Rep. Donna Lichtenegger, respectively in 2017, were amended in March 2018 to SB 807, sponsored by Senator Jay Wasson, and SB 603, co-sponsored by Sen. Robert & Rep. Bryan Spencer. The bills were officially signed into law this summer by Gov. Mike Parson, naming WGU Missouri as an approved virtual institution. Previously, students at all brick-and-mortar colleges in Missouri could apply for Access Missouri funds, but there was debate about whether online institutions like WGU Missouri, which has 750 students eligible for the funds this year, fit the criteria.

“We’ve been working with legislators over the past several years to have WGU Missouri added to the list of institutions whose students are eligible to receive funds through the Access Missouri program, and we are thrilled that our low-income students now have a chance to access these much-deserved funds,” said Dr. Angie Besendorfer, Chancellor of WGU Missouri. “WGU Missouri was created to help meet the needs of working adults by providing them with an affordable, flexible, high-quality, higher education option, and the Access Missouri program will help thousands of students around the state to fulfill their educational goals for years to come.”Financial eligibility for Access Missouri is determined by the Missouri Department of Higher Education using a student’s Expected Family Contribution (EFC) as calculated through the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA). Award amounts for eligible students range from $1,500 to $2,050 each school year, depending on expected family contribution, which must be $12,000 or less to qualify. For a complete list of requirements, visit https://dhe.mo.gov/ppc/grants/accessmo.php.
WGU Missouri offers more than 50 bachelor’s and master’s degree programs in business, information technology, teacher education and health professions, including nursing. Unlike a traditional college program, WGU caters to adults with previous work experience or who are currently working and looking to further their careers through education. WGU Missouri’s competency-based education model allows adult students to take advantage of prior learning and experience to move quickly through material they already know so they can focus on what they still need to learn. For more information, visit Missouri.wgu.edu.
About WGU MissouriWGU Missouri is a competency-based, online university created to expand access to higher education for Missouri residents. The university offers more than 50 undergraduate and graduate degree programs in the fields of business, K-12 teacher education, information technology, and health professions, including nursing. WGU Missouri faculty members provide one-on-one guidance, support, and instruction.Established through a partnership with nationally recognized Western Governors University, WGU Missouri is open to all qualified Missouri residents. The university is nonprofit and self-sustaining on flat-rate tuition of about $7,000 per year for most programs.Degrees are granted under the accreditation of Western Governors University, which is accredited through the Northwest Commission on Colleges and Universities (NWCCU). Teachers College programs are accredited by the National Council for Accreditation of Teacher Education (NCATE), and nursing programs are accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (CCNE*).

article headline: Parson joins St. Louis area leaders in pushing for state gas tax hike
After hospital visit, Missouri governor says his heart is fine
Proposition D is essential to maintain safe highways
body text:
The Nov. 6 election is only weeks away. The people of Missouri have a rare opportunity to do something great on that day for our state, our counties and our cities that will benefit not only our generation but that of our grandchildren and their grandchildren.Proposition D will ask voters to raise the per-gallon fuel tax in 2½-cent increments totaling 10 cents over four years. If this ballot issue is passed, then Missouri will almost catch up with the loss in purchasing power that the current 17-cent gas tax had in 1996, which is the last time that tax was adjusted.I was a panel member of the 21st Century Missouri Transportation Task Force, and we heard testimony from stakeholders from every corner of Missouri. The consensus was that the Missouri Department of Transportation has been an outstanding steward of our limited highway resources, and that with more resources MoDOT is definitely positioned to provide Missourians with safe roads, bridges and overpasses to ensure that travel on our roads is safe and comfortable.

Unfortunately Missouri is ranked 47th in highway funding with the seventh-most miles of roads to maintain. One of every 10 bridges and overpasses in Missouri is compromised, and eventually when a bridge and overpass is closed or weight limits are reduced, we are in big trouble.There is a roadblock ahead if Prop D does not pass. Instead of “Caution, construction ahead” signs, we will see “Detour, road closed ahead” signs that will take us miles and hours out of our way and discourage anyone from investing in our community or state.Fortunately, the campaign to pass Proposition D has endorsements from many organizations, from both rural Missouri from farm organizations and urban Missouri from municipalities and industry organizations. Prop D has bipartisan support, led by Gov. Mike Parson and Lt. Gov. Mike Kehoe, and many cities, including Florissant, have passed resolutions in favor of the passage of Prop D.Over the next 10 years, Proposition D funds will mean more than $2 billion in new state funding for roads and bridges. That will pay for about 46,000 miles of highway pavement and fixing or replacing more than 1,700 bridges on the state system. The federal government is matching the funding states put toward building and maintaining roads and bridges. This initiative will allow Missouri to receive more than $1 billion over just four years in federal funding that would otherwise go to other states.
Prop D is needed to continue funding safety improvements, like adding guard rails and repairing the more than 2,000 bridges rated in poor condition or weight restricted that are getting more dangerous for our families, school buses and emergency responders to cross every day. Proposition D will add more than $100 million in funding to state law enforcers, who risk their lives for us every day.
For every $1 spent on highway construction, $4 of economic activity is generated, meaning that Proposition D will result in over $1 billion of new economic activity and will also generate more than 5,000 jobs a year. That means more money for our schools and better-paying jobs, all while improving our roads.Missouri is in an enviable geographical location in the heart of our nation’s breadbasket, at the confluence of two mighty rivers and at the very center of the continental United States. But we must be able to compete with surrounding states with highways that encourage investment and travel. A safe and efficient highway infrastructure is vital to take advantage of our tremendous potential for economic growth and the jobs that will come with it.The revenue generated from Proposition D will be regularly audited and constitutionally designated to ensure it is spent the way it was intended — on vital repairs and improvements to Missouri’s roads and bridges.My plea is to not take this issue lightly because this important decision has been kicked down the road for way too long already. Please visit the campaign website Safermo.com and learn how Missouri can win big with Proposition D.Thomas P. Schneider has been the mayor of Florissant since 2011 and was a member of the 21st Century Missouri Transportation Task Force.

With Missouri Gov. article headline: Editorial: Missouri is failing domestic violence victims. The good news is, it's fixable.
body text:
In 2017, more than 45,000 Missourians reported incidents of domestic violence. In about 28,000 of those cases, the victims — usually women and children — were unable to obtain shelter or other requested services because of inefficient and uneven distribution of domestic violence funding across the state.That’s according to a recent state audit that shows Missouri is failing badly in this important area. The problem isn’t just inadequate funding but a more frustrating issue: bureaucratic morass that is preventing existing funds from getting to the people they’re meant to serve.The audit provides a list of common-sense, uncontroversial fixes that deal largely with cutting red tape and allowing more efficient disbursement of funds. Missouri’s leaders should read it cover to cover and get moving on its recommendations.

One of the first and most important things domestic violence victims need is somewhere to go — immediately — when staying home isn’t a safe option. It is in this crucial area that Missouri’s failure is most apparent. As the report by state Auditor Nicole Galloway notes, Missouri has just two domestic violence shelters for every three counties.And even among those existing shelters, services are hampered by funding lapses caused in part by burdensome and duplicative regulations on the shelters, and inefficiency in the way state and federal funds are disbursed to those shelters via local governments.
“State statutes regarding the distribution requirements for domestic violence fees collected are burdensome and unclear, resulting in a lack of compliance with requirements, and some county funds going undistributed,” the audit states.
As Galloway put it in a news conference: “Victims of domestic violence shouldn’t be turned away because red tape is holding up shelter funding. Unfortunately, that’s happening in Missouri.”Another problem is that state law doesn’t specify requirements for how or when local authorities are supposed to distribute funding to the shelters. This “decentralized” system, the audit says, means “funds are not being distributed where there is a demand for services,” with some counties just holding onto unused funds rather than getting them to other counties that might have unmet funding needs.Recommendations in the audit include rewriting documentation requirements for the shelters to make them easier to follow, and revamping the funding disbursement system so money isn’t sitting unused in one place while it’s needed somewhere else.Not that more funding wouldn’t always help, but how refreshing to be told that much of Missouri’s failure here could be turned around before spending the first additional dollar. The audit charts a clear path. Gov. Mike Parson and legislators should start fixing this eminently fixable problem as soon as possible.

Robberson: It's candidate endorsement time. Why do editorial boards do this?
body text:
It’s election time again, which means endorsement time for this newspaper. Which means a lot of people will be upset when we don’t see it their way regarding the candidate we recommend for major elective offices. Elections are all about differences of opinion. Relax, it’s democracy, not war.The most important thing for readers to remember with endorsements is that we are not handicapping this election as if predicting the winner in a football game. We don’t know any better than you who will win any given race. And after the outcome of the 2016 presidential and Missouri gubernatorial elections, many voters have learned that the best candidate isn’t always the person who ultimately gets the job or whom the polls projected as the likely winner.Our editorial board does its best with a small staff and grueling daily schedule to bring in as many candidates as we can for hour-long interview sessions. The questions we ask are designed to test candidates on their breadth of knowledge about the office, preparation on the major issues the office deals with, and candidates’ ability to engage in intense discussion while keeping the conversation civil.

We also want to know whether their political values align with this newspaper’s modern editorial priorities as well as the time-honored traditions outlined in The Platform, Joseph Pulitzer’s 1907 declaration that we publish on our editorial pages every day.But a candidate’s alignment with us is not necessarily a deal-breaker. If, say, a Republican candidate disagrees with us editorially but is more civil, better informed and politically engaged than his or her opponent, that’s someone we definitely can endorse.We poke for holes in their arguments and try to force them to go deeper than mere surface knowledge to make sure candidates aren’t merely reciting talking points by rote memory. This experience rattles and flusters some candidates. In 2016, then-gubernatorial candidate Eric Greitens lost his cool simply because I asked him, in response to his plan for an urban anti-crime initiative, whether he supported police stop-and-frisk policies.“You’re making my head hurt,” he complained, insisting that Missourians don’t care about that stuff. Later, still flustered, Greitens got in my face while we were standing in the Post-Dispatch newsroom. Reporters were watching. He left and never came back.We don’t play favorites. We put Greitens’ Democratic opponent, then-Missouri Attorney General Chris Koster, through the same wringer. Koster left our building red-faced and angry, accusing me of asking “gotcha” questions.
Our editorial board split on whom to endorse but wound up supporting Koster because Greitens came off as untrustworthy, uninformed, insincere and a political opportunist. Voters disagreed and elected him. Greitens was able to complete fewer than 18 months in office before resigning in disgrace amid multiple criminal investigations.We didn’t endorse Greitens’ successor, Gov. Mike Parson, when he ran for lieutenant governor, but we were careful in our endorsement not to criticize him because he struck us as sincere, earnest and likable. We had no major argument with him, but his Democratic opponent had positions closer to those we’ve advocated editorially. Parson took no offense. He keeps in touch with us, sends us an occasional op-ed, and recently made a point of visiting our offices for a chat.
In the race for the Metro East 12th District congressional race, we chose Republican incumbent Mike Bost over his inexperienced and unprepared Democratic challenger in 2016. But we made a point of holding onto the recordings and notes of Bost’s remarks — including his criticisms of then-presidential candidate Donald Trump. This year, we’re measuring Bost on whether he honored his promises and stayed true to his values — exactly as Illinois voters should do.We’ve repeatedly asked Rep. Ann Wagner, R-Ballwin, to come talk to us. She has declined, despite having received our endorsement in 2012. All we want is to hear her explanations about her political choices, including her reversal after initially rejecting Trump’s presidential bid.So why does the editorial board go through this contentious exercise? First and foremost, we recognize that voters rarely have the time to attend all the campaign rallies and public debates to fully inform themselves about the candidates. And even in those forums, the candidates aren’t always pressed on the issues they need to address. We do our best to fill in the gaps and serve as the eyes and ears of our readers.To reiterate: We are not picking winners and losers. All we’re trying to do is tell readers that we’ve spent a lot of time investigating these candidates and hammering them with tough questions designed to test their knowledge and preparedness. This is our assessment.Many readers take our recommendations with them to the voting booth. Some use it, as it’s designed, to better inform themselves. Others call in to boast that they deliberately vote against the candidates we recommend, as if to punish us. The latter do themselves — and democracy — a disservice.

Citing success in other cities, Lewis Reed urges St. Louis to adopt anti-violence program
body text:
ST. LOUIS • Aldermanic President Lewis Reed is calling on city officials to adopt a nationally known program to curb violence in St. Louis, citing the project’s success in cities including Boston and Chicago.The “Operation Ceasefire” initiative was first developed in Boston in the 1990s by criminologist David M. Kennedy, and the city saw a 63 percent reduction in youth homicides two years after it was implemented, prompting dozens of other cities to attempt their own versions of the program.Proponents of what is now known as Group Violence Intervention say it reduces crime through a network of law enforcement and social service providers, who engage with a small but active number of people involved in street groups.

“It would allow us to begin to break down those silos that exist between all these agencies that are all out there working to do good things for the city,” Reed said. “There are families being devastated daily by the crime happening in our city. When there’s something out there that can work, that is within our grasp, I think we should pursue it.”According to the National Network for Safe Communities — a research center directed by Kennedy that works to introduce similar anti-violence initiatives locally — readily identifiable groups of individuals commit the majority of homicides, shootings and other acts of extreme violence. Using data and shared information in a network of police, local nonprofits and service providers, high-risk individuals can be targeted for resources and support and deterred from violence.Reed announced on Wednesday that he had been in contact with the U.S. Department of Justice and St. Louis Public Safety Director Jimmie Edwards about the program, and that he also had support from organizations such as the NAACP and Civic Progress.His announcement comes in the wake of six homicides in the city in a 24-hour period. St. Louis Police Chief John Hayden and Mayor Lyda Krewson have already called on the public to help them solve the crimes.
“Going into Friday afternoon, we were 25 homicides down compared to last year, so we were trending in the right direction,” Hayden said on Monday. “Now we are 19 homicides behind last year.”
Reed said he had been interested in bringing the program to St. Louis for several years, and floated the idea again in 2017 when the city surpassed 200 murders in a single year for the first time since 1995. There hasn’t been any real momentum before now, he said.“Everyone is working hard and doing their best, but this tool begins to focus all of that energy, and begins to unify that energy, in a way that will address our public safety issues in a much more meaningful way, taking many more guns off the streets,” Reed said. “This gives us that structure.”Reed said Edwards was receptive to exploring the idea, but it’s unclear if the city will ultimately take steps to implement the program in St. Louis. Edwards could not be reached for comment.Reed could not offer an estimate of the program’s cost, but he argues that most of the money is already in the city’s public safety budget and could be paid for with “a realignment of resources.”Discussion of the program is on the agenda for a meeting between Reed and Missouri Gov. Mike Parson this week. A spokesman for Krewson said that she did not connect with Reed before he gave a news conference about the program on Wednesday but that they would try to talk soon.

article headline: Missouri school officials put finishing touches on next year's budget plan
body text:
JEFFERSON CITY • Buoyed by encouragement from Gov. Mike Parson, state education officials are asking Missouri lawmakers to earmark $140 million more for schools next year.In a meeting Tuesday, the state Board of Education unanimously endorsed a proposed $6.3 billion budget that attempts to ramp up funding for school transportation costs, which are only being funded at about 17 percent of the total need.Jennifer Jordan, chief budget officer for the Missouri Department of Elementary and Secondary Education, said the agency is asking for more money over a five-year span to get to 75 percent of busing costs.

“Transportation is short of full funding by $198 million,” Jordan told the board.About $77 million of the proposed increase would go toward fully funding the foundation formula, which sets out how much each school district will receive in the next fiscal year.In May, lawmakers approved a budget that included $3.49 billion for the formula. But, the base level of state funding is going up to $6,370 per student, resulting in the request for more money.Despite the proposed increase, board member Mike Jones bemoaned the shortfall in transportation funding."There's no way for the public to understand how under-resourced K-12 education is in Missouri,” Jones said.But, board president Charlie Shields said the Parson administration has encouraged the agency to tell lawmakers what is actually needed to fund schools, rather than tailoring their requests for money to a limited amount of dollars.“What’s being presented is radically different from what we’ve been doing in previous years,” Shields said. “This is what we think the priorities are.”Shields also said he expects the Legislature to have a “robust” discussion on increasing funding for early childhood education programs.
“I think it’s a high priority for the governor,” Shields said.The request now heads to Parson’s budget office, where it will be combined with other proposed state spending. Parson, the former lieutenant governor, is crafting his first budget blueprint after taking over for scandal-plagued former Gov. Eric Greitens, who resigned June 1.This year, the budget that went into effect in July gave schools a nearly $99 million increase, allowing lawmakers to claim the state is meeting its core school funding goals outlined in state law. It also boosted state aid for school transportation costs by $10 million.
The board also approved a plan for hiring the next commissioner of education. Roger Dorson has been serving as the interim head since Margie Vandeven was terminated on December 1 after Greitens had stacked the board with his own appointees.Shields said the process would be similar to the last two searches for commissioners. The job will be posted this week and stay open for a month. A small committee of the board would then narrow down the applicants with an eye on making an offer in November.Shields said Dorson might be considered for the top post.“We have a very high functioning interim commissioner in Roger Dorson,” Shields said.The board attempted to launch a hiring plan after Vandeven was ousted, but the ongoing wrangling over Greitens’ intervention on the board may have tamped down interest in the high-profile post.The board received just 10 applications for the job before the process was halted.That compared to more than 40 applications for a similar job opening in Ohio and more than 50 in Michigan.

Governor's callous action hurts neighbors of radioactive landfill
body text:
Throughout my nearly 20 years in public service, no issue has affected me more personally than the lasting damage to my constituents from radioactive waste migration, storage and dumping. The radiation waste that sits just beneath the surface at the West Lake Landfill is no exception.I have held 100 town hall meetings and conducted over 1,000 interviews with St. Louis County residents regarding their experience with radioactive waste. I have personally witnessed the incredible pain and suffering that this toxic waste has brought on so many lives.For those who may not be aware, a little history. In 1942, a St. Louis company began processing vast amounts of uranium as part of the Manhattan Project. Over the next 25 years, the company’s uranium processing created enormous amounts of radioactive waste, which was secretly discarded at sites throughout the St. Louis area, including West Lake.

Today, West Lake’s radioactive waste sits on the outskirts of a former quarry with practically none of the standard safety features found in most municipal landfills. The dangerous materials dumped in this area will continue to pose a hazard for hundreds of thousands of years. A few feet south of this radioactive site, an underground fire is constantly burning at the Bridgeton Landfill. This ongoing public health disaster is a prime suspect behind the deaths of scores of residents through cancer, stillbirths and other diseases.As an elected leader who represents the area around the West Lake and the Bridgeton landfills, I cannot heal those inflicted with cancer. I cannot bring back those lives tragically cut short. One thing I can do is fight for better policies and more funding for those affected.This year, I secured a $1 million appropriation in the state budget to begin a home buyout program for owners of homes near the toxic waste. Through my line item, the state was poised to take a definitive step to begin addressing the crisis at West Lake Landfill.Unfortunately, Gov. Mike Parson stopped this progress and canceled the funding, leaving hundreds of families languishing in the path of death and disease. His excuse for doing so is Attorney General Josh Hawley’s latest example of selling out the people of Missouri.
As you will recall, in June, Gov. Parson stumbled into the state’s highest office by succeeding the scandal-prone Eric Greitens. Only days after he assumed office, Gov. Parson vetoed the entire $1 million for the Contaminated Home-Acquisition Program. In explaining his veto, his office said: “Recent actions in an agreement with the attorney general’s office and owners of the Bridgeton Landfill ensure that remediation and cleanup efforts will occur, leaving this appropriation unnecessary.”Hidden in the governor’s lie is the fact that the settlement engineered by Attorney General Hawley’s office forbids money to pay residents or fund home buyout programs. Hawley did secure a $1 million civil penalty for his own office. Think about that: The people living near the radioactive waste won’t see their $1 million, but Josh Hawley’s office will.Meanwhile, Gov. Parson’s administration also gets a payout with $2 million going to his Department of Natural Resources for staff time and other expenses.
Even the $12.5 million included in the settlement for “nonprofit entities surrounding the landfill” does nothing to assist those people who own radioactive homes. Not only is the settlement devoid of language requiring or authorizing a home buyout program, but the settlement itself (on page 8, schedule B of Exhibit 1) contains language expressly forbidding money in the fund to pay individuals directly for a buyout program.While it is an outrage that Gov. Parson used Hawley’s weak settlement to justify vetoing money to help Missouri residents escape their radioactive homes, in retrospect, it should be no surprise that Gov. Parson acted so callously.This is the same man who put money in the state budget to pay for a private Capitol valet service. The same man who tried to get even more state money so he could hire a personal driver. The same man who now lives in a taxpayer-funded mansion because of a toxic politician, while real Missourians are trapped in their homes because of toxic pollution.The fire at Bridgeton Landfill is now burning on Gov. Parson’s watch. It’s time he stops ignoring the heat.

St. Louis police union requests restraining order to prevent release of blacklisted officers' names
body text:
ST. LOUIS • The city police union filed on Tuesday a request for a temporary restraining order against the circuit attorney’s office and a commander of the police department to block them from releasing the names of officers whose cases prosecutors will no longer pursue.The filing came as Police Chief John Hayden met with Circuit Attorney Kim Gardner to discuss her concerns and the two “agreed that issues concerning a St. Louis City police’s officer’s credibility shall continue to be reviewed on a case-by-case basis,” a statement issued late Tuesday afternoon by Public Safety Director Jimmie Edwards said.“The conversation was candid and respectful, and they are committed to working together to conduct fair investigations and to do justice in the prosecution of anyone accused of a crime,” Edwards said. “Chief Hayden and Circuit Attorney Gardner also agreed to meet regularly to ensure open communication between their offices.”

The moves are the latest chapters in a controversy that began Thursday after the Post-Dispatch reported that Gardner would quit accepting cases from or allow 28 officers to serve as witnesses because of “credibility” issues.Since then, Gardner and Hayden have issued statements that appear to contradict each other. Gardner insists Maj. Michael Sack asked her for the list of officers and thanked her for helping him hold his “guys accountable” in an email.A request made under the Sunshine Law for that correspondence or the names of the officers on the so-called list was rejected Tuesday by Gardner’s office. “Any such record, and records relating to any such list, are closed records,” Assistant Circuit Attorney James A. Michaels said by email.He cited sections of the law that exclude communications because of attorney-client privilege and if they are “legal work product.”Gov. Mike Parson, in town to talk about the special session he’s calling to expand drug treatment programs and raise awareness about job opportunities through STEM education, said he was “deeply concerned” about the situation.“For a prosecutor to do that — you also have victims out there,” said Parson, a former sheriff in Polk County. “Now, are you taking away their rights as victims (as) to whether you’re going to prosecute or what you’re going to do. I think that’s beyond what the scope of her job would be.”Sack and Gardner’s Chief Warrant Officer Chris Hinckley were served with notice Tuesday that the temporary restraining order was requested. The order states that Hinckley and the police department have “declined to explain the reasons for placement upon this list, the criteria considered in determining whether an individual would be placed on this list, and procedures by which an individual could challenge placement on this list.”“Placement on the list does potential harm and damage to the reputation of the petitioner, defamation of his or her character, impedes the ability to perform current employment duties, jeopardizes potential for advancement and promotion and violates the due process rights of the named petitioner. Furthermore, public disclosure of plaintiff’s name puts his safety at risk in the performance of his duties,” according to the document.A judge has yet to rule on whether to grant the order, and a hearing has not yet been scheduled.Hayden has insisted that no one from his department would ask for such a list.Hayden was questioned about the situation with Gardner’s office at the annual St. Louis Police Foundation luncheon, where he was sitting with Mayor Lyda Krewson and former Police Chief Dan Isom.
“I am interested in moving on and I look forward to meeting with the Circuit Attorney’s Office soon and improve the relationship between her office and my agency,” Hayden said. “I believe there is room for us to grow and become more effective and get back to the business of protecting the citizens of St. Louis.”He refused to answer any other questions about the situation, specifically Gardner’s latest assertion that Sack had asked for the list.“I’ve already made my statements regarding that,” he said.In a statement issued Saturday, Hayden denounced the list as “unnecessary overreach.”
“No leaders from our Department asked the Circuit Attorney’s Office to compile an Exclusion list, nor do we have any need for such a list,” Hayden wrote. “I was quite surprised to have received it.”Edwards also refused to answer questions at the luncheon Tuesday, saying only that he hoped to “have a comment by the end of the week.”In addition to filing the temporary restraining order, the police union sent on Tuesday a letter to Hayden demanding that the union be invited to any meetings with Gardner as it is representing “all of the officers whose reputations have been sullied by inclusion on the list.”“I would humbly propose that without the input of the rank-and-file, there will be no moving on from this travesty. Not now. Not ever,” Jeff Roorda, business manager for the St. Louis Police Officers’ Association, wrote in the letter, a copy of which was obtained by the Post-Dispatch.Of Edwards’ statement Tuesday afternoon, Roorda said that it “doesn’t change anything.”“We’ve still got 28 officers who’ve been notified that the circuit attorney won’t take their cases and they haven’t been notified that anything has changed,” he said.“They’re trying to get the genie back in the bottle.”Roorda added that officers on the list had already had their cases refused by Gardner’s office.“So while Chief Hayden and Kim Gardner were having high tea and crumpets, we still have 2.5 percent of the workforce that can’t put bad guys behind bars,” he said.The Associated Press and Joel Currier of the Post-Dispatch contributed to this report.

body text:
JEFFERSON CITY • Gov. Mike Parson on Thursday appointed two new members to the state's Board of Education, which was hobbled and unable to meet under Parson's predecessor, former Gov. Eric Greitens.Parson named Kim Bailey of Raymore and Don Claycomb of Linn to the panel, which oversees K-12 education.According to a news release, Bailey holds a bachelor's in psychology from the University of Missouri-Columbia. She earned a master's degree in marriage and family therapy from Friends University.

Bailey, a Republican, is a licensed therapist and adjunct professor who has served on the Raymore Peculiar School Board and on the Raymore Home Educators Association, according to the release.Claycomb, an independent, earned a Ph.D. in education and a bachelor's degree in agriculture from the University of Missouri-Columbia. He has a master's in education from Northwest Missouri State University, according to the release.With the two nominations, the board now has seven of eight seats filled.St. Louis School Guide: Get test scores and moreGreitens, a Republican, stirred controversy in December when allies he had appointed to the board voted to oust popular Education Commissioner Margie Vandeven.Greitens withdrew and then resubmitted his five controversial nominations in January, allowing the Missouri Senate all spring to consider the nominations. Senators did not approve any of them.
Because the nominations were in limbo, the board did not have enough members to meet and was unable to consider Vandeven’s replacement. A short-lived search yielded 10 applications, but the applicants were told after they applied that the search was put on hold, Board President Charlie Shields said.Now, interim Commissioner Roger Dorson is leading the department. Shields said he had brought a “calming presence” to the department and educators. He said Dorson possessed valuable knowledge of the way district finances work and had earned the respect of senior staff.Shields has said the board would debate in September whether to launch another search for Vandeven's replacement.
Parson on Thursday also made six other appointments. Among the appointments: he named two Republicans to the state's Clean Water Commission.Republican Patricia Thomas, treasurer for the state party, was already on the panel but was serving an expired term. Parson reappointed her. He also named Allen Rowland, a Republican from Dexter, to the commission.














        
            Greitens stacks clean water commission with farm-friendly allies

Missouri’s Clean Water Commission now has a majority of farm-friendly members as it considers granting permits to large factory farms.




With Rowland's appointment, the commission now has four Republicans, two Democrats and one independent, John Benton Hurst of Kansas City.Though Hurst is listed as an independent, he works for the Graves Garrett Law Firm in Kansas City, which often represents Republicans and Republican interests.State law forbids any more than four members of the same party from serving on the seven-member panel.
