Missouri school board says state should reconsider how it measures charter schools
body text:
At its first business meeting this year, the Missouri Board of Education renewed three St. Louis charter schools for five more years on Thursday, while questioning whether the state is evaluating charter schools appropriately.Charter schools are independently run public schools. In Missouri, charter schools exist only in St. Louis and Kansas City. They are designed to be innovative alternatives to the school districts in which they operate. Missouri law requires charter schools to be renewed, in most cases, every five years by the state board.Thursday’s renewals drew frustration from state board members who were dissatisfied with charter schools’ test scores. The state board’s comments in turn frustrated charter school leaders, who don’t think it’s fair to compare charter schools to entire school districts. The state board has long evaluated charter schools’ effectiveness primarily by comparing them to public districts.

St. Louis School Guide: Explore area charter schools“That may not particularly be a good measure,” said state board President Charlie Shields.The debate led state board members to conclude that Missouri needs to revisit its charter school laws, particularly in the area of evaluation.“I think there’s an opportunity to revisit the entire charter issue,” said Shields. “The politics about this have really been about expansion or nonexpansion. What we have not had, in my mind, is a significant discussion around our charter school laws.”Shields was critical of the performance of the St. Louis charter schools renewed Thursday, arguing that they do not convincingly outperform St. Louis Public Schools. He said the state Legislature allowed charter schools to operate in Missouri on the premise that charter schools would be easy to open, but poor-performing charter schools should be easy to close.Charter school leaders often argue that it’s difficult and unfair to compare charter schools to St. Louis Public Schools as a district overall because Missouri charter schools are much smaller and consist of one or a handful of campuses, while St. Louis Public schools has more than 70 schools.“We’re comparing a school against a system, so it is truly not apples” to apples,” said state board member Mike Jones.Jones suggested comparing charter schools to a district’s highest-performing school, but board member Vic Lenz argued that that would be unfair because some of St. Louis’ highest-performing district schools selectively admit students based on academic performance, while charter schools are not allowed to do so.State board member Peter Herschend also stressed that he doesn’t want to see charter schools “judged against mediocrity.”“I just want to hold the bar higher,” Herschend said.Herschend of Branson was appointed to the board this week, along with Carol Hallquist of Kansas City, by Gov. Mike Parson. The new members gave the state school board the quorum it had lacked since January because of political maneuvering by former Gov. Eric Greitens, who resigned June 1.Shields said he wants Missouri leaders, including legislators, the governor’s office, the Missouri Charter Public School Association and others to discuss revising Missouri’s charter school laws.
It is up to a charter school’s sponsor, not the state board, to ensure that schools are meeting the state’s and their own performance expectations. Every charter school has a sponsor, usually a university, that monitors the school’s performance through a contract with the school.The state board is required by law to renew a charter school as long as that school meets statutory requirements, even if the board is unhappy with the school’s performance.Lift for Life Academy, which opened in 2000, met only half of the academic achievement goals outlined in its contract with Southeast Missouri State University, which sponsors the school. The school has met its annual performance report goal just once in the past four years, but it met its goals for science and social studies achievement, attendance and graduation rate.Lift for Life leaders attribute performance shortfalls largely to the fact that students enroll at the middle school and high school as sixth-graders with pre-existing achievement gaps. They hope to close those gaps by eventually offering elementary grades.“The ability to support those children earlier will also help support our middle school and the challenges you see,” said Diana Rogers-Adkinson, dean of Southeast Missouri State’s college of education, at Thursday’s state board meeting.
Lafayette Preparatory Academy, meanwhile, met four of six of its contract performance goals in English but did not meet its math and science goals. Percentage-wise, its students outperformed St. Louis Public Schools students in comparable grades on English and math tests in 2017. Lafayette is sponsored by the University of Missouri-St. Louis.Eagle College Prep, which is sponsored by University of Missouri-Columbia, met all its contract goals and outperformed St. Louis students in comparable grades in English and math in the past three years. But it performed worse than St. Louis students in science all three years.Commissioner searchOne of the last actions the state school board took in December, before losing its quorum in January, was to fire Missouri’s education commissioner, Margie Vandeven. The move was an objective of the former governor.On Thursday, the board said it’s in no rush to set a timeline for the search for a new commissioner because it’s happy with the leadership of interim Commissioner Roger Dorson“I think we need to be very deliberate about this. We need to take our time,” Shields said. Shields asked board members to think about what they want to see in a commissioner, for discussion at the next board meeting.Other pending business includes:• A planned revamp of Missouri’s school accountability system, known as the Missouri School Improvement Program. The board can expect a final draft of changes in September, said Assistant Commissioner for Quality Schools Chris Neale.• A decision on St. Louis Public Schools’ governance, Shields suggested that making the final decision to return the district to an elected school board should wait until certain criteria are met, such as training.St. Louis School Guide: Get test scores and more

article headline: In another break from Greitens, Parson says he won't shy away from using state plane
Editorial: Gov. Parson's education board appointments reflect a welcome new approach
body text:
Missouri’s education leaders can get back to business with enthusiasm and optimism this week now that Gov. Mike Parson has made two new appointments to the state Board of Education. The board, which oversees about 900,000 students in K-12 education, has had too few members since December to appoint a new state schools commissioner.A hefty agenda awaits members, including whether to let an elected school board take control of St. Louis Public Schools. Parson would be wise to give the board a wide berth to conduct its business without executive meddling.The board’s problems were created when Gov. Eric Greitens stacked it last year in a drawn-out effort to oust the widely respected education commissioner, Margie Vandeven. He succeeded in ousting her, but the Missouri Senate retaliated by not confirming Greitens’ board appointees.

Parson delivered on the promise he made when he assumed office June 1 that one of his first orders of business would be to fill five vacancies on the eight-member board. Three vacancies remain, but with Tuesday’s appointments, the board has enough members to convene for a required semiannual meeting.Parson understands the urgency parents and families of schoolchildren feel after Greitens steamrolled the public education system to advance his political agenda. The former governor never clearly indicated why he wanted to replace Vandeven, but his efforts appeared aimed at installing someone determined to expand school choice through charter schools and increased use of vouchers. The formerly constituted school board had never turned down a charter school application, and critics contended the move was simply a power grab by Greitens.
Parson is taking a far more collegial approach, reflected by his appointees. One is Peter Herschend, a former president of the education board and one of the members Greitens’ booted off last year. Herschend, a Republican, is co-owner of the company that owns Silver Dollar City. The other is Democrat Carol Hallquist of Kansas City, a former Hallmark Cards executive and founder of PrincipalsConnect, a nonprofit that provides volunteers to urban schools.
With the state Senate out of session, the two new members do not need confirmation and can begin serving immediately.The unprecedented fiasco caused by Greitens’ meddling paralyzed the board, forcing cancellation of five of its last 11 meetings and leaving several important issues hanging. Parson’s new board has no time to waste on key education decisions, including what kind of board should govern St. Louis Public Schools and its roughly 24,000 students. Other top priorities are deciding how to remake the state’s public school evaluation system and whether five low-performing charter schools should lose their ability to operate at the end of the month.Parson is mending fences, ending acrimony and getting on with the job of governing Missouri. His quick action on the school board is a welcome change of course.

article headline: Low-income housing tax credit program deserves a critical evaluation
body text:
For more than 30 years, the low-income housing tax credit program has enjoyed bipartisan support despite being poorly designed and having a poor track record at improving housing for low-income families. In fact, Congress recently expanded the program.But we hope the controversy over the program playing out in Missouri will lead to a critical evaluation of the tax credit program for the entire nation.Disgraced former Gov. Eric Greitens moved to end state funding for Missouri’s participation in the program, which would eliminate federal matching funds. Many assume that Gov. Mike Parson, who was sworn in Friday, will now work to reinstate the program’s funding. However, the state’s House budget chairman has indicated that he will attempt to thwart such moves.

Nationally, the low-income housing tax credit program provides $9 billion a year in tax subsidies for rental housing construction plus $100 million in administrative costs. In exchange for the subsidy, developers cap rents for tenants who meet income criteria.The program has several shortcomings. First, it yields little additional housing per dollar spent. Second, the program doesn’t adequately target the poor. New tenants can have incomes up to 60 percent of area median income. For the city of St. Louis, for example, that income limit amounts to $46,080 annually for a family of four. Once in the program, participants can continue to receive subsidies with incomes as high as 140 percent of the area median.Third, the tax credit program is excessively bureaucratic, which has made it susceptible to corruption. The federal government distributes the funds to state housing authorities, who then issue grants to private developers. Developers usually sell their credits to banks, allowing them to offset taxes and fulfill Community Reinvestment Act requirements. The application process has spawned an industry of accounting and law firms specializing in securing grants.Meeting the eligibility criteria does not guarantee one a unit. In fact, most low-income people do not benefit from the tax credit. Residents, while not well off, are not necessarily poor. Those not receiving units often pay higher rents for inferior units elsewhere, sometimes waiting years for a subsidized unit to become available.Construction based on the tax credits does not simply add to the housing stock. It also crowds out housing from private markets. Researchers report that each dollar of low-income housing tax credit subsidy yields only between 50 and 80 cents of additional housing.
A 2009 study by economist Michael Eriksen found that the program’s construction costs were 20 percent higher than for similar unsubsidized projects, partly due to rules and regulations intended to improve developments. Another factor may be that the program generally funds new constructions, even though renovating existing housing is more cost effective.The low-income housing tax credit program is not merely inefficient, it also fosters corruption. The program was central to the 2010 conviction of 14 Dallas politicians and real estate developers on charges that included bribery and extortion. The Dallas Morning News referred to the scandal as “the largest public corruption investigation in Dallas history.” Similar cases of fraud, amounting to tens of millions of dollars, have occurred in Florida and California.
Policymakers should consider more effective approaches for increasing the supply of affordable housing. For example, providing housing vouchers directly to individuals, with few restrictions, would be a better approach. However, the most obvious alternative is to make building less costly by eliminating some land use regulations. Unfortunately, over the past 50 years, many cities have moved in the opposite direction, producing unaffordable housing by severely restricting building.There is ample evidence that easing building regulations would be a more effective way to promote affordable housing than programs such as the low-income housing tax credit program. This is especially true in cities in the northeast and coastal California, where regulations have made cities unaffordable even for middle- and upper-middle income households.We agree with Harvard economist Edward Glaeser, who writes that “growth, not height restrictions and a fixed building stock, keeps space affordable and ensures that poorer people and less profitable firms can stay.”After more than 30 years of the low-income housing tax credit program, it is past time to explore alternative paths for addressing the very real problem of unaffordable housing.Seth H. Giertz is an associate professor of economics and a senior research fellow with the Colloquium for the Advancement of Free-Enterprise Education, both at the University of Texas at Dallas. Matt Kelly is a research fellow with the Colloquium for the Advancement of Free-Enterprise Education at the University of Texas at Dallas.

article headline: Editorial:  Parson, the anti-Greitens, hits all the right notes
body text:
It wasn’t exactly, “My fellow Americans, our long national nightmare is over,” but Gov. Mike Parson struck the right tone Monday in his first address to the Legislature since taking over from Gov. Eric Greitens on June 1. Parson’s call for a “fresh start” and an elevated “tone of our political discourse” recalled President Gerald Ford’s reassuring remarks upon being sworn in to replace Richard Nixon.Parson’s remarks were balm to a state battered by sleazy controversies since news of Greitens’ extramarital affair broke on Jan. 10. There followed seven months of scandal, legal proceedings and pre-impeachment hearings that embarrassed Missouri.But even before Jan. 10, Greitens had a difficult relationship with many of his fellow lawmakers. He had campaigned against “career politicians,” sparing neither Democrats nor his fellow Republicans. On his Facebook page, he had called them “liars, cowards, sociopaths” and people “drawn to politics as vultures flock to rotting meat — and they feed off the carcasses of vice.”

After that, almost anything Parson could have said would have been soothing. But he took special care to praise legislators as “honorable men and women” and “citizen patriots” who weren’t looking to build careers but “were called to be a public servant.”In a gesture of humility rarely witnessed under Greitens, Parson even entered the House chamber through a side door instead of staging a triumphal march up the middle aisle. He was a familiar face, having served in the Legislature for a dozen years before being elected lieutenant governor in 2016. Indeed, he is a recognizable type, a middle-aged rural conservative similar to dozens who sit in the Legislature. He is unlikely to rappel into a bull-riding arena, as Greitens did.“The atmosphere of the Capitol has lightened considerably,” Sen. Rob Schaaf, R-St. Joseph, who had been singled out by Greitens’ political hit-squad for special harassment, told the Springfield News-Leader. “You just walk into the building and you don’t feel that oppression every minute of being here.”
Parson took a few not-so-subtle jabs at Greitens. He reminded his fellow lawmakers that “we serve the people and the state of Missouri — not the other way around.“Sadly, much of the political turmoil that has engulfed our state is a result of these truths being forgotten. When the public’s trust is violated, we are obligated to act.”
He praised the “care, prudence, and professionalism” of lawmakers who dug into the allegations against Greitens.It would have been nice to hear him take such a stand while Greitens was still in office, though admittedly as lieutenant governor he couldn’t appear to be too eager to take over.Parson’s legislative voting record favored conservative positions that we believe have not well served the majority of Missouri citizens. We expect to disagree with him on the issues. But on character and the sincerity of his beliefs, we stand with him.

article headline: New Gov. Parson attempts to end acrimony, fills Board of Education vacancies
body text:
JEFFERSON CITY • Gov. Mike Parson named two members to the state’s Board of Education on Tuesday, a move that will allow the panel to establish a quorum and meet for the first time in five months.Parson, a Republican, named Carol Hallquist and Peter Herschend to the panel, which oversees K-12 education in Missouri.Parson’s predecessor, Eric Greitens, picked Herschend, of Branson, for the board last July but pulled his appointment later that year as he was trying to cobble together enough votes to boot former Education Commissioner Margie Vandeven.

While Greitens was ultimately successful in ousting Vandeven last December, the move triggered immediate fallout, with the Senate refusing to confirm Greitens’ appointees when it reconvened in January.Parson’s move seemingly ended the five-month standoff. The two new members will be able to serve immediately because the Senate is not in session to confirm them. The next education board meeting is set for Thursday.Hallquist, of Kansas City, is the former president of the Hallmark Corporate Foundation at Hallmark Cards Inc. She also founded the nonprofit Principals-Connect, according to a news release.Herschend, according to the release, co-founded and co-owned Herschend Family Entertainment Corp., which owns the Silver Dollar City amusement park. He retired in 2006 and previously served three terms on the Board of Education, including stints as president of the panel.Herschend is a Republican; Hallquist is a Democrat. State statute requires the board to maintain a bipartisan makeup. Parson’s decision means there are now five members on the eight-member panel — enough to form a quorum.“We owe it to our students to provide the best, high quality public education in Missouri,” Parson said in a written statement. “It was important to act quickly to restore and provide functionality to the State Board of Education.”Greitens, also a Republican, spent several months last year filling board vacancies — and then removing his appointees when they signaled they would not do his bidding.
Greitens’ aim was to orchestrate the firing of Vandeven. After finally succeeding, Greitens met swift backlash for the maneuver from lawmakers who had yet to vote to confirm any of the then governor’s appointees. Because the Legislature was not in session in December, the appointees were able to cast the controversial votes without having received confirmation from the Senate.Greitens withdrew his nominations as the Legislature was convening its regular session in January, and shortly thereafter reappointed them, giving the Senate all spring to consider the nominees.But senators refused to confirm Greitens’ appointees, leaving the board powerless and unable to meet.Parson said the board would continue with a “diligent national search, to find a capable, qualified candidate to serve as Missouri’s commissioner of education.”
Parson met with Charlie Shields, the Board of Education president, last week to discuss the picks.“Governor Parson’s decision to appoint Carol and Peter will help restore and maintain stability,” Shields said in a statement. “As a board, we are ready to work together to give Missouri students what they deserve — the best public education.”Sen. Gary Romine, a Farmington Republican who chairs the Senate Education Committee, said he and others had screened potential nominees for “the last several months” in an effort to jolt the board back into action. Because of that, Romine said, Parson was able to act quickly to make his appointments.“A lot of good things will come out of this,” Romine said.Melissa Randol, the executive director of the Missouri School Boards’ Association, also praised Parson’s move.“We thank Governor Parson for placing such a high priority on appointments to the State Board of Education,” she said in a written statement. “The extraordinary experience of the two appointees will enable the State Board to resume its responsibilities quickly.”

article headline: Greitens broke law by hiring taxpayer-paid impeachment attorneys, House committee chairman says
body text:
JEFFERSON CITY • The former chairman of a Missouri House committee that was investigating ex-Gov. Eric Greitens said Monday the governor broke the law when his office hired two taxpayer-paid impeachment attorneys.Rep. Jay Barnes, R-Jefferson City, made the charge in a three-page letter delivered Monday to Sarah Steelman, commissioner of the state's Office of Administration. He also argues that Greitens should be on the hook for about $153,000 attorneys Ross Garber and Ed Greim charged the state through the end of May.

"Instead of placing the burden on Missouri taxpayers, those legal fees should be borne exclusively by Eric Greitens himself," Barnes wrote.Barnes argues that agreements the state signed with Garber and Greim are not valid because state law forbids officials from making contracting decisions that result in a personal benefit to the official.Barnes also said Greitens violated his own executive order which states that administration employees cannot "participate in a proceeding or decision in which the state employee's impartiality might be reasonably questioned due to the state employee's personal or financial relationship with a participant in the proceeding.""In addition to violating the criminal conflict of interest provisions" of state law, Barnes wrote, "the Garber-Greim purported contracts also violate Greitens' first official act as governor."Barnes argues that Steelman should not approve the $153,000 Garber and Greim billed the state. A spokeswoman for the Office of Administration said Monday that the bills were still under review.Garber, a Washington, D.C.-based attorney who has represented troubled governors in Alabama, Connecticut and South Carolina, said Tuesday it was "common practice" for administrations to seek outside legal help."This is a sound practice because it recognizes the significant public interests at stake in these matters," Garber said.
He said he represented the interests of the governor's office, not Greitens himself. Without him, "advocacy would be left to lawyers representing solely the interests of the current occupant of the office."Greim, who works for the GOP-connected, Kansas City-based Graves Garrett law firm, said the "underlying mistake" in Barnes' analysis is that he assumes "the office of the governor is simply an empty chair that different occupants fill from time to time."
He said that over time, "precedents develop that change the powers, rights and duties of that office. If the constitutional balance is not kept true, then it will be too easy — and if you look at it the other way, too hard — to remove officeholders."Greim also said that it was his and Garber's job to advocate preferred versions of impeachment procedures and standards for impeachment, not the facts of the case."Personal counsel argued the facts," Greim said. "That was not our job."He also said the Office of Administration is "under a clear legal duty to pay us" and said he believed they ultimately would.Auditor Nicole Galloway, a Democrat, and Attorney General Josh Hawley, a Republican, both raised concerns last month about the hiring of the Garber and Greim.Hawley wrote in a letter to Galloway that while state agencies can hire outside legal counsel, they must first seek permission through the attorney general's office — something the Greitens administration had not done, Hawley said.It was unclear Tuesday what Gov. Mike Parson, who oversees the Office of Administration, would do regarding the legal bills. His spokeswoman, Kelli Jones, said Parson had yet to take a stance.

article headline: Missouri's new governor offers 'fresh start' in first address to state lawmakers
Editorial: Getting a fuel tax increase on the ballot was the easy part
body text:
Last month the Missouri Legislature, after years of nervous dithering, finally decided to ask voters whether they wanted to raise the state’s motor fuel tax for the first time since 1992. If voters approve the ballot measure in November, the 17-cents-a gallon tax would rise to 27 cents in four increments by 2022.That the Republican-dominated Legislature would put a potential 63 percent tax increase on the ballot in an election year is a mark of just how bad the roads have become. But putting it on the ballot was the easy part; lawmakers must now get out in front and sell a tax increase. This will be heresy for some of them. Gov. Mike Parson must lead the way.Parson was asked about the fuel tax proposal last week in one of his first meetings with reporters since assuming office June 1. He said he was for it. Sort of.

“I’m going to be supporting infrastructure in the state of Missouri and, yes, if that’s [the tax hike] part of the infrastructure plan,” he said. “I think that is important. We need to make sure we’ve got a good plan in place.”The Missouri Department of Transportation has a long list of plans and projects and can provide Parson all the plans he’d ever want. The agency says it needs $825 million more each year to adequately maintain the state’s vast system of 33,856 miles of highway and 10,403 bridges. When fully implemented in 2022, the 10-cent increase would yield about half of that. Some of it would fund the Highway Patrol, and a fourth would go to cities and counties for road work.
In outstate Missouri, there’s still some residual resentment over what happened the last time the fuel tax was increased. In 1992, the tax went up 6 cents on the promise that the state’s “total transportation plan” would link every city with a population of 5,000 or more with four-lane highways. The grand scheme would have required a massive bond issue that never materialized.
Any tax increase is a tough sell. Because of 20 years of corporate tax cuts, families and individuals are stuck with an unfair share of the total tax load. For every $1.28 in income, sales and miscellaneous taxes paid by families and individuals, Missouri corporations pay about a nickel.The trucking industry isn’t thrilled with it, either. The industry paid 39 percent of all taxes and fees owed by Missouri motorists, though accounting for only 15 percent of vehicle miles traveled. However, by some estimates big trucks cause 90 percent of the damage to roads and bridges.Fuel taxes are user fees, by far the fairest way to pay for highways. That shouldn’t be a hard sell, but the governor and other state leaders are going to have to make it.

article headline: Editorial: Voters should select a new lieutenant governor
body text:
As inconsequential as the Missouri lieutenant governor’s job usually is, it should be filled. As John Adams, America’s vice president put it, “I am vice president. In this I am nothing, but I may be everything.”Gov. Mike Parson knows this first-hand, having ascended to the office June 1 upon the resignation of Gov. Eric Greitens. Parson and the Legislature should address the vacancy as quickly as possible.Right now legal experts disagree on what, if anything, can be done. Former Missouri Supreme Court Chief Justice Michael Wolff and former Missouri House Chief Clerk and Administrator Stephen S. Davis recently have argued on our commentary page that state law prevents governors from appointing lieutenant governors.

Joe Bednar, who was chief counsel to Gov. Mel Carnahan when Carnahan was killed in an October 2000 plane crash, immediately advised Gov. Roger Wilson, who had been lieutenant governor, that he must appoint a successor. Wilson waited three weeks until Election Day and appointed Joe Maxwell, the winner of the lieutenant governor’s race, to take over immediately.Bednar said the state constitution says “there shall be a lieutenant governor” and the “governor shall fill all vacancies … unless otherwise provided by law.” The law doesn’t otherwise provide.
Davis suggests Parson should provide new instructions to the current special session of the Legislature to deal with the vacancy. The text of Senate Bill 1038, which Sen. Bob Dixon, R-Springfield, introduced after the Greitens scandal erupted last January, could serve as a starting point.
The bill never got out of committee, but it calls for the governor to set an election to fill a lieutenant governor’s vacancy at the next general election, assuming the election date is at least 120 days away. Otherwise the office remains vacant. The Nov. 6 election is 149 days off.Parson could take Bednar’s advice and appoint someone on his own. No doubt he’d appoint a fellow Republican, and there are lots of qualified candidates. Among them are former Lt. Gov. Peter Kinder, who offers 12 years’ experience, and popular leaders like House Speaker Todd Richardson of Poplar Bluff and Senate President Pro Tem Ron Richard of Joplin, both of whom are leaving the Legislature because of term limits.The salary is only $86,600, less than someone could make as a lobbyist, but unless Parson found a caretaker candidate, the new lieutenant governor would immediately become a potential rival for the likes of state Treasurer Eric Schmitt and Secretary of State Jay Ashcroft, who might also want to move up.With the law unclear, a unilateral appointment might be challenged in court. It would cut voters out of the decision-making process. They lost a governor just 17 months into his term. They shouldn’t be denied a chance to elect a new No. 2.

article headline: One week into office, new Missouri governor adds prosecutor to his staff
New Missouri governor to announce school board picks next week
body text:
JEFFERSON CITY • Missouri Gov. Mike Parson is expected to appoint at least two new members to the state school board next week in a bid to close a controversial chapter of the state’s education bureaucracy.Parson, who took over for former Gov. Eric Greitens last week, has said getting the board up and running after five months in limbo is a priority. And under state statute, the board is required to meet in June.“We are very well aware of the state school board,” Parson said after he was sworn in last week. “We aim to get that board up and running as soon as we can.”

Word of the pending appointments came after a meeting Thursday between Parson and state school board President Charlie Shields. Shields, a former state senator, said he expects an announcement Tuesday or Wednesday.“I think they’ve got a couple of people in mind,” Shields told the Post-Dispatch.The board has had to cancel five of its 11 meetings scheduled for this year because it lacks enough members to meet and take action. It has just three of eight members because the Senate refused to confirm five Greitens appointees after he stacked the board in order to oust former schools commissioner Margie Vandeven last year.Parson would need to appoint at least two people for the board to have a quorum and hold its next meeting, which is set for Thursday.“We’ve been working constantly behind the scenes here just to make sure we are ready with everything that needs to go before the board the minute that they can meet,” said DESE spokesman Tyler Madsen.As a backup, the board also has scheduled June 26 for a meeting if Parson doesn’t act next week.“We’ve had these dates circled for quite a while because we knew that by state statute we’ve got to have a meeting in June,” Madsen said.
Current board members are Shields of St. Joseph, Mike Jones of St. Louis and Vic Lenz of St. Louis County.Among items facing the board is the hiring of a replacement for Vandeven, who had been in the post since 2015.Shields said making the hire is a priority, but there is no need to rush the process because the interim commissioner, Roger Dorson, is well qualified to handle the duties.The board also must decide whether to renew six charter schools, including Lafayette Preparatory Academy, Lift for Life Academy and Eagle College Prep, all in St. Louis.
And, it must weigh in on whether an elected school board should regain control of St. Louis Public Schools from the appointed Special Administrative Board.“There are a lot of things that are not complicated but they have been backed up,” Shields said.An announcement on the appointees is not expected to come when Parson addresses a joint session of the House and Senate at 5 p.m. Monday.The Legislature is currently in a special session that was called to consider the impeachment of Greitens over the circumstances of an extramarital affair and his use of a charity donor list to raise money for his campaign.With the former governor now gone after his abrupt resignation, the two chambers will hear from Parson and then adjourn.If Parson were to make the picks before the Senate adjourns from its special session, the appointees would need to be confirmed by the Legislature’s upper chamber. If he waits until the session is over, the new members can be sworn in as interim appointees and begin serving immediately.

article headline: Lawmakers drop subpoena seeking Greitens dark money donors, for now
body text:
JEFFERSON CITY • A panel of lawmakers investigating former Gov. Eric Greitens has dropped its attempt to secure records showing who secretly contributed money to the ousted chief executive.An attorney for the special House committee that had been deliberating on whether to recommend Greitens be impeached withdrew a request Wednesday seeking records from the ex-governor’s campaign committee and a dark money nonprofit called A New Missouri.The withdrawal notes that the panel may again seek the records. At issue is the wording of the committee’s purpose, which is to investigate issues related to Greitens.

“The Special Committee on Oversight believes the requested records are relevant to its charge and should be produced for the committee and all Missourians to see. However, the committee has determined to withdraw its pending request as it reviews its options,” attorney Mark Kempton wrote in a document obtained by the Post-Dispatch.Now that Greitens isn’t governor, it is unclear whether the committee has the power to subpoena those particular documents.The decision came a day before a hearing was scheduled to argue whether the records should be released.On Friday, the same day Greitens formally resigned from office under the cloud of an ongoing scandal, Cole County Circuit Judge Jon Beetem granted a reprieve from an order requiring the two organizations to turn over a list of donors.As part of the investigation, the nonprofit and the campaign committee had been facing a Friday deadline to disclose the evidence, but Beetem allowed for a delay because of the extraordinary circumstances of Greitens’ abrupt departure.
Attorney Catherine Hanaway, a former House speaker who is representing the two campaign organizations on behalf of Greitens, argued that the House panel created to investigate the governor no longer has the authority to demand the documents because of Greitens’ resignation.In a statement Wednesday, Hanaway said, “Our motion to reconsider was so persuasive the House dismissed its case.”
A New Missouri is overseen by Greitens’ former campaign manager and has been active in supporting his causes and rallying against opponents who disagreed with him during his 17-month tenure.Because of its nonprofit status, the group doesn’t have to publicly reveal its financial and other information the way a regular PAC would. That has led to criticism that Greitens, a Republican, and his allies were using the nonprofit to hide their political donations and activities from public view.The future of the committee could be decided as early as Monday when lawmakers convene to hear a joint address by new Gov. Mike Parson, who stepped into the post when Greitens left.House Speaker Todd Richardson, R-Poplar Bluff, could remake the panel and charge them with continuing to probe Greitens.Or, the committee could compile the evidence it already has collected into a final report.

article headline: Having Missouri Highway Patrol return to St. Louis interstates under consideration by governor
body text:
JEFFERSON CITY • Gov. Mike Parson said he wants to help the St. Louis region combat crime, but he’s not yet sold on whether to restart one crime-fighting initiative launched by his predecessor.On his third full working day as Missouri’s new governor Wednesday, the Republican from Bolivar said he is unsure whether he’ll back a plan that saw the Missouri Highway Patrol boost its presence on interstates running through the city.Last year, at the direction of former Gov. Eric Greitens, troopers began working along portions of Interstates 55 and 70 in July with a goal of freeing up city police officers to patrol troubled neighborhoods.

The program was pared back in late October.Although troopers issued thousands of tickets and arrested hundreds, there was no concrete way to determine the effect of the program. Homicides were up overall over 2016, but were down by about 9 percent during the pilot program period compared with the same period a year earlier. Assaults involving guns were up by about the same amount when comparing July through September 2017 to the same months in 2016.“I need an opportunity to meet with the colonel of the Highway Patrol and meet with the mayors to figure out how we best do that,” said Parson, a former Polk County sheriff. “I’m sure there are other models out there. We’ve just got to figure out a solution to how we’re going to fight crime in Missouri.”His comments came before a meeting with St. Louis Mayor Lyda Krewson and St. Louis County Executive Steve Stenger — one of a series of sit-downs Parson has been doing since taking over for his scandal-plagued predecessor.Parson said he wants to work with the duo to address crime issues.“I’m going to talk about the crime issue across the state and how important that is for all Missourians. It’s not in isolated areas. It’s all of our problem,” Parson said. “My plan is to be able to give them the tools they need to get the job done.”Afterward, Krewson and Stenger said it was significant that they had a 40-minute meeting with Parson so early in his tenure.“We talked about MetroLink safety. We talked about safety in our schools. I think this meeting is the first of many. We identified key issues that our region is facing,” Stenger said.
“We talked about summer jobs for kids. We talked about after-school jobs. We talked about how important it is for folks and young people to get that feeling of a job well done,” Krewson said.Greitens left office Friday after a five-month-long scandal enveloped his administration. The self-described outsider had faced a felony charge for using a fundraising list from his former veterans charity to raise money for his political campaign. The charge was later dropped in an agreement with the St. Louis circuit attorney that resulted in his resignation.At the time, a separate House committee was compiling information that could have led to his impeachment and removal from office.
Krewson and Stenger described the meeting with Parson as warm and informative.“This was different than meetings with the last governor,” Stenger said.“I think that we’re going to have a really good working relationship with Gov. Parson,” Krewson said. “We share a lot of common concerns. I think he understands the importance of the St. Louis region to the economy of the state. As St. Louis does better, the whole state does better.”Parson, the former lieutenant governor, also met Wednesday with the state auditor and treasurer as he pushes to get up to speed on issues facing his fledgling administration.Treasurer Eric Schmitt said he briefed the governor on the state’s unfunded pension liability.“It’s the No. 1 threat to our triple A bond rating, so I’ve been focused on that,” Schmitt said.Parson is scheduled to address a joint session of the House and Senate on Monday.

article headline: Office may be called 'light gov,' but it’s still needed
body text:
Although capital insiders refer to the lieutenant governor as “light gov,” we still need one. As Gov. Mike Parson can attest, Missouri’s lieutenant governor is not someone who just sits around waiting to take the reins temporarily when the governor is out of town.Our “light gov” fills other crucial roles, too. Our state constitution created a Senate with an even number (34) of senators. This design purposefully anticipated tie votes and an executive branch check on the Legislature. As the president of the Senate, our lieutenant governor casts tie-breaking votes, which can resolve simple procedural issues or be much more weighty.In 2000, when I was working in the Legislature, the November election led to neither party winning a Senate majority. The Republicans held a plurality of 16 seats. (There were 15 Democrats and three vacancies.) At times like that, the “light gov” can fill an extraordinarily heavy role.

As former Missouri Chief Justice Michael A. Wolff ably explained on this page last week, current law does not provide for the filling of this vacancy, and in my opinion, prevents the governor from appointing a lieutenant governor. See Mo. Rev. Stat. § 105.030. Nearly a hundred years ago, the Missouri Supreme Court ruled the governor had no authority to fill vacancies in a way that conflicts with applicable statute. By contrast, there is constitutional and statutorily provided process to fill all other elective state offices, either by appointment or special election.Gov. Parson says he is considering calling the Legislature into session to fix this problem. He should immediately do so. The cost is minimal, and the opportunity is prime.
Upon the tragic death of Gov. Mel Carnahan in 2000, Lt. Gov. Roger Wilson became governor and appointed Joe Maxwell as his successor. But because Maxwell had actually just been elected lieutenant governor (but had not yet assumed office), the issue fizzled. The issue resurfaced in 2013, briefly, when Lt. Gov. Peter Kinder ran for Congress. Gov. Jay Nixon said he could appoint Kinder’s successor if Kinder left office. Legislative leaders disagreed. Kinder wasn’t successful in his congressional bid, and the debate faded once again.
Since the Legislature is currently meeting in an unfortunately called and unprecedented “special” session, Gov. Parson calling a concurrent “extraordinary” session would impose little or no additional cost or time. (The terms “extraordinary” and “special” are constitutional terms-of-art. Suffice it to say, an “extraordinary” session is one called by the governor, and a “special” session is called by the Legislature itself.)Our state constitution mandates a minimum five-day process to pass a bill. The Legislature can accomplish this task in that short time frame (if it waives some of its normal procedural rules), and the entire membership of the House and Senate only need be present for one day each. Almost all of the work can be performed by presiding officers and committees, which reduced cost and time. And doing this in June — the final month of the fiscal year — further reduces any impact on the Legislature’s budget.In 2005, Gov. Matt Blunt called an extra session to pass an abortion-related bill. This took the Senate only three days and the House an additional five. If an abortion bill can be passed in eight days, this task should be a breeze. In fact, the Legislature has already considered and debated legislation as recently as this year on this very topic. It’s time to fix this issue and put the debate to rest.Stephen S. Davis is an attorney with the St. Louis office of Arent Fox LLP. He previously served as the 62nd chief clerk and administrator of the Missouri House of Representatives and as an assistant United States attorney.

article headline: CEO of Bi-State/Metro announces he's quitting in the fall
Missouri governor signals support for gas tax boost
Greitens' exit puts review of St. Louis death penalty case on hold
body text:
JEFFERSON CITY • The abrupt resignation last week of former Missouri Gov. Eric Greitens has again put the fate of a man convicted of murdering a former Post-Dispatch reporter in limbo.













Marcellus Williams, who was convicted of fatally stabbing a former Post-Dispatch reporter in 1998, was set for execution, but the governor granted a stay.


Marcellus Williams, who was sentenced to death in connection with the 1998 murder of Lisha Gayle, was hours from being executed last August when Greitens stopped the process and invoked a rarely used state law to appoint a special board to review the case and recommend life or death.

That panel, which comprises five retired judges, had been scheduled to meet Tuesday. But, with Greitens’ departure and the swearing-in of new Gov. Mike Parson, the judges decided to cancel the meeting.“The board felt, in light of Governor Greitens’ resignation, it called into question whether our authority would continue after he left office,” said former U.S. District Judge Carol Jackson, who is chairing the panel.Jackson said the board didn’t want to presume that Parson would want to continue the process set forth by Greitens.“We felt like we needed to just put this on pause for a minute,” she said. “Governor Parson had nothing to do with the cancellation of the meeting.”The canceled meeting has raised red flags for some groups that had hoped Greitens would commute Williams’ sentence before his resignation was final, but a spokesman on Friday said Greitens wouldn’t make a decision before leaving because he wanted the special panel to continue its work.On Tuesday, the NAACP organized a rally in the capital city to shine a spotlight on the racial disparities of the death penalty in Missouri.“This process is so broken and steeped in patterns of systemic racism and prosecutorial misconduct that an innocent man came within just hours of execution by lethal injection,” NAACP Missouri conference President Nimrod Chapel said.“We think a lot of the problems are highlighted by the prosecution of Marcellus Williams,” Chapel added.Chapel said he is hopeful that the activists can meet soon with Parson to discuss the case.The fates of Williams and the board are among a lengthy list of items facing Parson. The former lieutenant governor is in the midst of hiring a staff to replace those who left with Greitens, including an attorney to take over for former general counsel Lucinda Luetkemeyer, who had overseen the formation of the special panel.
Parson spokeswoman Kelli Jones indicated the governor hasn’t decided what to do next.“The Board of Inquiry will suspend its work pending guidance from Governor Parson,” Jones said in a statement.













Lisha Gayle



Williams was convicted in 2001 of murdering Gayle at her home in University City. Prosecutors said Williams was burglarizing the home when Gayle, who had been taking a shower, surprised him. The former reporter, who left the paper in 1992, fought for her life as she was stabbed repeatedly.The Missouri Supreme Court in 2015 postponed Williams’ execution to allow time for the DNA tests. Using technology that was not available at the time of the killing, those tests show that DNA found on the knife matched that of an unknown male. Williams’ DNA was not found on the knife.Despite that finding, the state’s high court denied his petition to stop the execution and either appoint a special master to hear his innocence claim or vacate the death sentence and order his sentence commuted to life in prison.The panel formed by Greitens has met twice since it was formed. The first meeting was held in November, when the jurists received transcripts of Williams’ trial, information on DNA testing that was done in 2016 and other background information on Williams’ case, including opinions from various state and federal appeals.The second meeting came in March.Members of the panel are Jackson, former 22nd Circuit Judge Michael David, former Circuit Judge Peggy Fenner of Jackson County, former Missouri Court of Appeals Western District Judge Paul Spinden and former Circuit Judge Ellen Roper of Boone County.Jackson said the members were awaiting direction from Parson.“The board members are still interested in pursuing this issue,” she told the Post-Dispatch. “I’m hopeful that’s going to be resolved soon.”

Missouri’s next governor has not veered from high road in scandal
body text:
Regarding “Missouri’s next governor: Mike Parson” (May 30):I know very little about Missouri Lt. Gov. Mike Parson other than that I disagree with his position on just about everything. However, I was very impressed with how he took the high road during the Gov. Eric Greitens debacle and I thought his comment on it was true class.

I have heard and read that he is respected and very well liked by members of the legislature. That in and of itself is a positive change over Greitens’ time in office. So maybe now something can be accomplished.
This ultra-liberal wishes the very best to incoming Gov. Parson in his new position.

article headline: Mike Parson pledges fresh start as he is sworn in as Missouri's new governor
Editorial: Dark money giveth Eric Greitens, and taketh away
body text:
The bizarre 17-month Eric Greitens era in Missouri government ended quietly on Friday afternoon. Missourians surely want and deserve to move on from the arrogance, the secrecy, the stonewalling and the sleaze that dominated the news in recent months.Mike Parson, who just five days ago as lieutenant governor had plenty of time to work cattle on his Polk County ranch, must now rebuild the executive branch. It will take some time, but normalcy can return to state government. Parson is as conservative as Greitens pretended to be, but should be a far less divisive figure.But before Missouri moves on, some questions need to be answered. They fall into two broad categories: How did this happen? What can be done to make sure it doesn’t happen again?

The answers to both questions have to do with money — millions upon millions of dollars in campaign contributions, secret and fully disclosed alike. More than $17 million of Greitens’ campaign money was paid to a California consulting firm where Nick Ayers, a Georgia-based strategist who is now Vice President Mike Pence’s chief of staff, was a partner. Greitens’ campaign began with local supporters he had met through The Mission Continues, the veterans charity he’d founded and later exploited, but more than any other individual, Ayers, the 35-year-old Georgia whiz kid, is responsible for Greitens’ election.He looked at Greitens’ résumé — Rhodes scholar, Navy SEAL, veterans charity founder, best-selling author — and determined to make him governor. Never mind that he had no working knowledge of state government nor any discernible allegiance to the Republican Party.Ayers brought in other Georgia guys like Austin Chambers and Roberts Edens Davis who helped run Greitens’ campaign. They turned him into a Stepford candidate, one with bumper-sticker appeal to Missouri’s white rural and suburban Republican base and disdain for the state party establishment.Ayers has a reputation as a dark-money wizard, someone who served as a liaison between rich business interests and the Republican Governors’ Association, selling tickets on someone who could be president someday. Greitens jump-started the campaign with $2 million raised from donors to The Mission Continues. After that it was dark money and money from out-of-state donors with no particular interest in Missouri that won the primary.One of the matters that must be cleared up before the Greitens saga is closed is whether that money was acquired and used legally. Felony charges have been dropped — one for taking a nude photograph of a woman during a sexual encounter in 2015, the other for exploiting his veterans charity.But the mere possibility that the House committee investigating the charges against Greitens would begin digging into the dark money panicked Greitens’ backers and brought pressure to resign. Within hours of Cole County Circuit Judge Jon Beetem’s decision Tuesday that Greitens and his finances were fair game for the House committee, Greitens announced his resignation.
His lawyers — and he had a lot of them, most paid by mysterious sources — had anticipated Beetem’s decision. They cut a deal last weekend with St. Louis Circuit Attorney Kim Gardner: She’d drop the felony charge related to the donor list and Greitens would resign.Parts of the deal were redacted, which is simply not appropriate for a judicial officer and a state official. No one knows details of what both sides promised. The public has a right to know what was done in its name.The House investigative committee wants to continue probing the Greitens’ campaign’s finances, but it may no longer have jurisdiction. Missouri Attorney General Josh Hawley could investigate the possibility of fraud. He should do so. Judge Rex Burlison should reconsider his decision to allow secret parts to the deal.
Yes, it’s good that Greitens is gone. But not all the secrets in the Greitens’ saga took place in the basement gym of his home in 2015. Lawmakers, judges and the prosecutor should refuse to blindfold Missouri citizens.To that end, the Legislature must codify the opinion issued May 10 by James Klahr, the executive director of the Missouri Ethics Commission: States write their own election laws. Never mind that courts have allowed dark money to proliferate in federal elections. Nonprofits that donate to Missouri political campaigns can’t conceal the identities of their donors.Backers of the so-called “Clean Missouri” ballot initiative have submitted signatures to get a comprehensive ethics measure on the state ballot in November. Had it been in effect in 2016, it might have been harder for Ayers’ Georgia cabal to stage the Greitens coup.Missouri got rolled. A handful of people, most with limited experience in Missouri politics, managed to elect an utter novice with a fabulous résumé and no discernible political qualifications beyond naked ambition, to the state’s highest office.They may not have known about his personal problems, but they knew his ethics were malleable. He could keep a secret; in fact, he loved keeping secrets, as indicated by his reluctance to answer questions from reporters and lawmakers; his use of a dark-money committee to attack lawmakers, his penchant for burner phones and heavy use of the Confide app that makes text messages disappear.With his remarkable résumé, his talent and good looks, Greitens seemed like the total package. But as Gertrude Stein said in a different context, there was no there there, only relentless ambition. Unless Missouri regains control of its government from moneyed interests, it could happen again.

article headline: Here are the bills Gov. Eric Greitens signed before leaving office
Short takes: Misplaced civility, news priorities and rejected recyling
body text:
SBUX for unityIt’s easy to poke fun at Starbucks for its foofoo coffee and jacked-up prices, but the chain deserves credit for its effort to instruct about 175,000 employees in racial-bias training.The coffee giant closed more than 8,000 U.S. stores for four hours on Tuesday to kick off the training, and paid all employees who participated. The closures could cost $16.7 million in lost sales, according to Bloomberg media.

Starbucks’ image as a welcoming place to hang out, look at your computer and get caffeinated took a big hit in April when a manager at a Philadelphia store called the police because two black men were sitting there waiting for a friend.The men were arrested for no reason, causing a social media firestorm. Starbucks’ leaders apologized profusely, arranged a financial settlement with the men and parted ways with the manager. They say the training sessions were the first step in an ongoing attempt to teach employees about discrimination. For the company that got the nation hooked on venti-size coffee, teaching employees some venti-size consciousness is not a bad idea.Mayor NiceLike many elected officials, St. Louis Mayor Lyda Krewson opened Twitter, inserted foot. After Gov. Eric Greitens’ resignation Tuesday, the mayor chose moderation, thanking him for his service. Krewson got a timeline-full of hostility from St. Louisans and some Democratic officials who called her tone-deaf and questioned why she would be so polite to a governor who savaged St. Louis.In reply, Krewson tweeted Wednesday morning: “It is said that the road to hell is paved with good intention …,” she wrote, adding that Greitens’ actions were “inexcusable, embarrassing and disgusting.” She said her tweet from the day before was “well intended but missed the mark.”She tweeted further, apologizing for choosing civility and saying it was past time for Greitens to get the message, and that she looked forward to working with incoming Gov. Mike Parson.Like “The buck stops here” sign that Harry S Truman kept on his desk, modern politicians should have one that says, “Think first, tweet later.”Roseanne 20, Puerto Rico 1The progressive website Media Matters reports that on Tuesday, the three major cable news networks devoted more than 10 hours of coverage to ABC’s decision to cancel Roseanne Barr’s popular TV show because of a racist tweet. Meanwhile, the news that the death toll in Puerto Rico from Hurricane Maria last September may have been 72 times higher than official estimates got a grand total of 30 minutes of coverage.This is an old conundrum for people in the news business: Celebrity news drives viewers and readers far more than serious news. Wednesday’s print edition of the Post-Dispatch carried 13 paragraphs on the Roseanne story on page A10, but skipped the hurricane deaths entirely. In our defense, Gov. Eric Greitens’ resignation ate five news pages that day. Stltoday.com, the online version of the newspaper, covered the hurricane death study extensively.
Harvard public health researchers carried out a scientific survey of the island’s residents to come up with a conservative estimate of 4,645 deaths attributable to the disaster. The official death toll is 64. If celebrities had been among the victims, the coverage might have been more extensive.No assault rifles? No problemAfter the Feb. 14 mass shooting at a high school in Parkland, Fla., executives at Dick’s Sporting Goods announced the company would no longer sell assault-style rifles like the one used to kill 17 people. Dick’s said it would no longer sell high-capacity magazines, either, and would raise the minimum age to purchase guns to 21.The company braced for a backlash, and this week came the first quarterly earnings report since the decision in February: Sales were up as much as 27 percent and earnings guidance was raised by 12 cents per share.Smart gun policy is smart business.
Why mass shootings? PornWhile we’re on the subject, U.S. Rep. Diane Black, R-Tenn., thinks she’s identified the core problems that lead to mass shootings: violent movies, the breakdown of the family and easy access to pornography in grocery stores.“Pornography. It’s available. It’s available on the shelf when you walk in the grocery store. Yeah, you have to reach up to get it, but there’s pornography there,” Black told a group of pastors last week. “All of this is available without parental guidance.”She might be shocked to learn porn is available online, so kids don’t even have to go to the grocery store to paw through all the gun magazines to get to the porn. Black is a candidate for the GOP nomination for governor. Good luck with that, Tennessee.Why recycling bins are blueSo you’ve been diligently separating paper, plastic, aluminum, cardboard and glass and putting it into a blue recycling dumpster or a bin you haul to the curb. Here’s some bad news: Since Jan. 1, China — which used to accept most of the recycled materials from the United States — no longer wants it.“All of a sudden, material being collected on the street doesn’t have a place to go,” Pete Keller of Republic Services, one of the largest waste managers in the country, told the New York Times this week.A few bulk recyclers have been able to find new markets, but it’s a low-margin operation. The trashy little secret is that all that stuff you’re so carefully sorting and recycling may be winding up in the landfill, anyway.

Office of lieutenant governor deserves some respect
body text:
At 5 p.m. Friday, the office of lieutenant governor will become vacant when Lt. Gov. Mike Parson becomes governor. In response, the constitution and laws of Missouri, in effect, say: So what?The lieutenant governor’s office has taken on great importance in recent years. In the past 20 years, lieutenant governors have twice become governor: in 2000 with the death of Gov. Mel Carnahan, and this year with the resignation of Greitens.But the state’s constitution and laws make no provision for replacing a lieutenant governor. Even its nickname — “light gov” — signifies an office that can’t get respect. Tom Eagleton, who was elected to the post in 1964 and served until he was elected to the U.S. Senate in 1968, once told me that his main duty as lieutenant governor was to call the governor’s mansion in the morning and inquire whether the governor was still alive.

The office was considered a part-time position until Republican Bill Phelps ran and won in 1972 on the platform that he would serve as a full-time lieutenant governor. His nickname — “full-time” Phelps — stuck, and candidates since then have been well advised to promise full-time service.In recent years the Legislature has passed laws filling out the job description with about 11 duties, in addition to the constitutional duties to preside over the Senate, cast tie-breaking votes in the Senate and serve as governor if the governor becomes disabled or leaves the state.The Missouri Constitution says: “The governor shall fill all vacancies in public offices unless otherwise provided by law, and his appointees shall serve until their successors are duly elected or appointed and qualified.” “Provided by law” means that the legislature has enacted a law.There is no law, however, authorizing the governor to appoint, or the voters to elect, a person to serve as lieutenant governor to fill a vacancy in the office. To the contrary, the applicable statute says: “Whenever any vacancy, caused in any manner or by any means whatsoever, occurs or exists in any state or county office originally filled by election of the people, other than in the offices of lieutenant governor, state senator or representative, or sheriff, the vacancy shall be filled by appointment by the governor …”
By contrast, there are laws providing for the appointment of persons to fill vacancies in the offices of secretary of state, state auditor, treasurer and attorney general. A bill passed in 2013 provided for election of a lieutenant governor, but the governor vetoed it. A 2018 bill to provide for appointment of a lieutenant governor passed the Senate, but died in the House.
There have been 47 lieutenant governors since Missouri became a state in 1821. In at least 11 cases, there were deaths or resignations — and the office remained vacant, sometimes for years. The office was vacant in October 2000 when Roger Wilson became governor after Gov. Mel Carnahan’s death. Gov. Wilson appointed Joe Maxwell to fill the vacancy in November after Maxwell won election to the office but before he was inaugurated. No one objected. When Lt. Gov. Tom Eagleton resigned after the 1968 election to be sworn in as a U.S. Senator, William Morris, who had won election to the office, was sworn in to fill the vacancy. But the 1968 Senate leader objected because there was no authority for the appointment. These were appointments of a few days or weeks, and no precedent was established.Article 4, sec. 11(a) of the Missouri Constitution provides for an order of succession when there is a vacancy in the office of governor. If there is no lieutenant governor, the order of succession skips to the president pro tempore of the senate, the speaker of the house, the secretary of state, the state auditor, the state treasurer and the attorney general, respectively.The meaning of this provision seems to be that it is not essential to have a lieutenant governor. The governor, in whom the constitution vests the state’s executive power, presumably can assign the lieutenant governor’s executive duties to others in the executive branch. As for the lieutenant governor’s legislative role as presiding officer of the senate, the senate can, and often does, function without the lieutenant governor as its presiding officer, although there would be no tie-breaking vote.But given that a lieutenant governor on occasion becomes governor, should the law provide for the people to elect a successor?Michael A. Wolff, a retired judge of the Missouri Supreme Court who served a two-year term as chief justice, is professor emeritus and former dean of St. Louis University Law School.

article headline: On the new Missouri governor's to-do list: revive the state school board
body text:
The resignation of Gov. Eric Greitens may help put the state school board back in business after a nearly half-year hiatus that was forced by the governor’s actions.The Missouri Board of Education has had to cancel five of its 11 meetings scheduled for this year because it lacks a quorum. It has just three of eight members because of Greitens’ maneuvers with five school board appointees, whom he appointed in order to fire former state schools commissioner Margie Vandeven. That move angered education leaders and legislators alike.State education leaders are now looking to Lt. Gov. Mike Parson to restore the board to full membership. Parson will become governor at 5 p.m. Friday.

Parson would need to appoint at least two people for the board to have a quorum and hold its next meeting, which is set for June 12. Because state education officials were not expecting the board to regain a quorum in time, they are tentatively planning to reschedule the meeting for June 26, said interim Missouri Education Commissioner Roger Dorson.State law requires the board to meet by the end of June, but Dorson said he doesn’t know what kind of consequences the board would face if it doesn’t.Technically, Greitens could still appoint board members before he leaves office. But Senate Majority Floor Leader Mike Kehoe, R-Jefferson City, said it would be in bad taste if Greitens used his final hours in office to stack boards and commissions with his people.“I wouldn’t think it would be appropriate for him to do that,” Kehoe said. “I do not anticipate him making any of those appointments.”Parson also will likely wait to make appointments, at least until the special session adjourns. Anyone he appoints while the Legislature is in session would have to be confirmed by the Senate before the session ends, or would become ineligible to serve.The special session must end by June 17, but could end sooner.If Parson waits, his appointees would be able to act as full board members without confirmation until the next session convenes. Parson could not be reached for comment.After Greitens appointed five members last year, the board voted in December to remove Vandeven. In January, Greitens withdrew the names of his nominees and then reappointed them, in an effort to preserve their eligibility.The Senate voted April 24 to reject one Greitens appointee, Eddy Justice of Poplar Bluff. The Senate did not take action on the other four appointees, who all withdrew themselves from consideration before the end of the regular legislative session, said Lauren Hieger, spokeswoman for the Senate Majority Caucus.Hieger said Senate leaders do not know whether those four are now banned for life from serving on the board. There is no precedent for such a scenario, so the issue would have to be decided by the courts, she said.Learning curveEven after Parson appoints new state school board members, they will face a huge learning curve and shouldn’t be rushed into the job, says board member Mike Jones. Vic Lenz of St. Louis County, Charlie Shields of St. Joseph and Jones of St. Louis are the three current board members.“Bottom line, even if Vic and Charlie and I could literally pick up where we left off, you’ve still got new board members who still have to literally be put back up to speed,” said Jones.The board was designed to avoid such dramatic turnover. The eight members serve staggered eight-year terms, with one member’s term expiring each year. The intent was to replace board members slowly.“Your most inexperienced members got a chance to learn the system without really risking anything,” Jones said. “You were able to get stability while at the same time not getting static because you were always getting new people on there. But they didn’t come in numbers that were disruptive.”Greitens was able to stack the board with five people at once after former Gov. Jay Nixon let four terms expire without replacements.Moreover, Parson will be able to appoint a sixth member as soon as July 1. Jones’ term will expire at the end of June.
Unfinished businessThe board has a long to-do list to tackle when it meets again. Arguably of most importance is the hiring of a state schools commissioner.Ten people applied for the position in January. Lenz said he thinks the board needs to redo the application process and conduct a wider and longer search.“The application process we used at that time was rushed by the same five people who voted to remove the commissioner,” Lenz said. “I think we need to start all over.”Other action items include:• Deciding whether to renew six charter schools, including Lafayette Preparatory Academy, Lift for Life Academy and Eagle College Prep, all in St. Louis.
• Deciding whether an elected school board should regain control of St. Louis Public Schools from the appointed Special Administrative Board.• Voting on disciplinary action for at least two dozen teacher licenses.• Hammering out details of a makeover of Missouri’s school accountability system.Dorson said that if the board doesn’t meet in June, the education department might approve the charter school renewals, pending final board approval, so as not to disrupt students’ schooling.Greitens’ legacyIn the eyes of education leaders, Greitens is leaving no legacy at best and a negative one at worst.“I think we ought to be grateful, and I said it before, that he was leaving,” Jones said. “We ought to be grateful for his political incompetence. He could have done a lot more damage.”Greitens will undoubtedly be remembered for his successful but highly unpopular mission to oust Vandeven.Other than that, Greitens leaves no significant education policy accomplishments. He signed a bill to create four adult high schools and approved budget increases to fully fund the school aid formula last year. But he championed no major education initiatives, did not communicate with education leaders and never visited a school in the St. Louis area as governor.“What he did work on was certainly stuff that we didn’t find as positive for public education in Missouri,” said Melissa Randol, executive director of the Missouri School Boards’ Association. “He wasn’t as engaged on a number of education issues and so it’s really hard to evaluate him beyond his actions with the state board.”Parker Briden, Greitens’ spokesman, did not immediately respond to a request for comment.Randol said she has higher hopes for Parson, who seems to enjoy a better reputation among education leaders.“He has been someone who supports public education,” Randol said. “We are looking forward to working with him.”

Governor's attorneys approached St. Louis prosecutor with deal: He'll resign, you drop felony charge
body text:
ST. LOUIS • Attorneys for Missouri Gov. Eric Greitens contacted St. Louis prosecutors on Saturday, proposing that he would resign from office if Circuit Attorney Kim Gardner would drop a felony charge against him.














        
            Embattled Missouri Gov. Eric Greitens resigns; 'resolution' reached in St. Louis

“The last few months have been incredibly difficult for me, for my family, for my team, for my friends, and many, many people that I love,” he…




Both moves came to fruition this week, with the governor’s abrupt announcement Tuesday that he’d leave office by the end of the week, and Gardner’s agreeing to drop the computer tampering charge he faced in St. Louis.

Gardner, a Democrat, announced the dismissal Wednesday in a news conference at the Carnahan Courthouse in St. Louis. Her office had charged Greitens, a Republican, on April 20 with illegally using a donor list from Greitens’ former charity for political fundraising toward his 2016 campaign for governor. Greitens, a former Navy SEAL, founded the nonprofit, The Mission Continues, in 2007.
